Ita fac cum eis uno post unum, donec uenias super omnes qui ex eis sunt in corpore.	So do with one after the other, until you have completed all that is in the body from the cautery.</start_of_turn>
Deinde cura eos postquam eradicantur, cum eo quod generat carnem ex unguentis.	Then care for them afterwards when they have been eradicated, as when that which generates flesh from moisture remains.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tremore.	Once the [disease] has been eradicated, care must be taken of the remnants, for what remains after the moisture has been consumed generates flesh.
Caput LVI.	Chapter LVI.
Quando accidit alicui Tremor ex frigore in neruo, aut ex febre quartana, aut alio: tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis, aut quinque super spondiles dorsi, et inter omnem spondilem cauterio, et in pectore eius cauterio, et super stomachum eius cauterio.	When fever occurs from cold in the nerve, or from the fourth [stage] of fever, or from anything else: then it is necessary to cauterise the four corners and the five spaces between the vertebrae, and between every vertebra cauterise, and in the chest cauterise, and on the stomach cauterise
Tremor enim quiescit cum cauterio oliuari, et festinat sanitas aegritudinis frigidae.	The tremor will cease when olive oil is cauterised, and health will return to its normal state against the cold.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Albathir.	The method of cauterising for Albathir.
Caput LVII.	Chapter LVII
Quandoque expelluntur in corpore Albathir foedae, id est, pustulae, quae fiunt a materiis grossis corruptis.	When pus is expelled from the body of Albathir, that is, from corrupt large matter
Oportet ergo in primis cum apparent, ut cauterizentur super omne caput pustulae cauterio subtili cum ligno myrti, cuius extremitas accensa est cum igne.	Therefore, in the first place, when it appears, it is necessary to cauterise over every head of the pus with a fine cautery with a twig of myrrh whose extremity is ignited with fire
Aut cum radice aristolochiae longae.	Or with a cautery like that of aristolochia longae root
Aut cum cauterio lenticulari.	Or with a lentil-shaped cautery
Et quandoque cauterizantur ademenul, in principio expulsionis suae secundum hunc modum: et non augentur: et disrumpitur superfluitas faciens eos, et sanatur ex eis.	And when they have been cauterised, at the beginning of the expulsion, in this manner: and they do not grow: and the superabundance is broken, making the matter thin, and it heals from the inside out
Verumtamen oportet ut fiat illud post euacuationem cum phlebotomia.	However, it is necessary to do this after the evacuation with a bloodletting.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fluxu sanguins ex arteria in uulnere.	The method of cauterising in the flow of blood from an artery to a wound.
Caput LVIII.	Head Chapter LVIII.
Multotiens accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, quae incisa est apud uulnus, quod accidit extrinsecus, aut apud incisionem apostematis, aut cauterium membri, et similia eis: et fit difficile abscindere eum.	Many times blood flows forth from an artery that has been incised near the elbow, which happens externally, or at the incision of the apostemate, or by cautery of the limb, and the like: and this makes it difficult to close it off.
Cum ergo accidit alicui illud, tunc propera cum manu tua ad orificium arteriae, et pone super ipsum digitum tuum indicem: et stringe eum multum, donec obsessus sit sanguis sub digito tuo, et non egrediatur ex eo aliquid.	When this happens to anyone, then act promptly with your hand at the orifice of the artery, and place your finger over it: and tighten it much, until blood is stopped below your finger, and nothing escapes from there.</start_of_turn>
Deinde pone in ignem cauteria oliuaria parua, et magna numero plura: et suffla super ea, donec fiant ignita ualde.	Then put in the fire a small olive-oil cautery, and many in number: and blow over them, until they are ignited cool.</start_of_turn
Deinde accipe ex eis unum, aut paruum, aut magnum, secundum uulnus et locum, in quo disrupta est arteria, et depone cauterium super ipsam uenam, post quam tu remoues digitum tuum festinanter: et tene cauterium, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then take from these things one, or two, or three, according to the elbow and the place where the artery has been ruptured, and place the cautery over the very wound: and immediately remove your finger: and hold the cautery until the blood is stopped.</start_of_turn
Quod si expellatur cum eleuas digitum ab orificio arteriae, et extinguis cauterium, tunc accipe cauterium aliud festinanter, ex cauteriis quae in igne sunt praeparata.	And if it escapes when you remove your finger from the orifice of the artery, and extinguish the cautery, then take another cautery quickly, from those which are prepared in the fire.</start_of_turn>
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum uno post aliud, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Do not cease to do this until the blood is stopped.</start_of_turn
Et caue, ne comburas neruum qui est illic, et accidat super infirmum malicia alia.	Beware, lest you burn the nerve that is there, and do not hurry over any other harmful matter.</start_of_turn>
Et scias, quod quando ex arteria fluit sanguis, tunc non est possibile abscindere ipsum: praecipue quaudo arteria est magna, nisi cum uno quatuor modorum.	And know that when blood flows from an artery, then it is not possible to close it off: especially when the artery is large, except with four fingers.</start_of_turn
Aut cum cauterio, sicut diximus.	Or with the cautery, as we have said.</start_of_turn
Aut cum extractione, quando non est extracta.	Whether during extraction or when it has not been extracted.
Nam quando extrahitur, contrahuntur extremitates eius, et abscinditur sanguis.	When it is extracted, its extremities recoil and blood is separated.
Aut ligetur cum filo ligatione forti.	Or it is bound with a strong ligature.
Aut ponantur super ipsum medicinae de proprietate, quarum est abscindere sanguinem, et stringatur cum puluinari constrictione decenti.	Or a remedy is placed over it, which has the property of separating blood, and it is bound with a constrictive bandage of proper size.
Qui autem administrat abscisionem eius cum ligamento, et strictura cum panno, aut positione rerum comburentium, et similium, non confert ei penitus, nisi raro.	Whoever performs an incision with a ligature and a bandage, or with a burn or similar methods, does not cause him much pain, except occasionally
Si autem accidat alicui illud, et non sit ei praesens medicus, neque medicina: tunc incipiat cum positione digiti indicis super orificium uenae ipsius, sicut narrauimus, et constrictione eius ualde, donec obsessus sit sanguis a superiori parte uulneris, et super arteriam.	If, however, this should happen to anyone who has no physician present, neither medicine: then he should take hold of the tip of the index finger and place it over the orifice of the wound, as we have said, and constrict it tightly, until the blood is driven out from above the wound, and above the artery
Et digitus non remoueatur, desuper ipsum cum aqua frigida uehementis frigoris semper, donec congeletur sanguis, et ingrossetur, et abscindatur.	And the finger should not be moved, but should be held there with cold water or ice always, until the blood is congealed, and has become tough, and is separated.</start_of_turn>
Et interim consideret in eo, quid indiget ex cauterio, aut ex medicina.	And meanwhile consider whether it is necessary to cauterize, or to apply some medicine.</start_of_turn>
¶ Partis Primae Finis.	End of First Part.</start_of_turn>
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars II.	Book of Surgery by Albucasis Part II.</start_of_turn>
¶ De Incisione, Perforatione, et Phlebotomia in uulneribus, et his similibus.	On Incision, Perforation, and Phlebotomy in Wounds, and similar things.</start_of_turn
Iam Diximus in Capitulo Primo, omnem aegritudinem in qua conueniens est cum igne cauterium et medicina comburente, et occasiones eius, ipsius caussas, et instrumenta eius, et formas cauteriorum.	We have said in the first chapter that every ailment in which it is convenient to use either cauterium or burning medicine, and the causes and occasions of these, and the instruments for these.</start_of_turn
Et posui illic capitula a uertice usque ad pedem.	And I will treat of these chapters from the vertex to the foot.</start_of_turn
Et ego procedam in hoc capitulo illa eadem uia: ut alleuietur super quaerentem quaesitum eius.	I proceed in this chapter as before: to alleviate the seeker's inquiry.
Et antequam incipiam illud, oportet ut addiscatis o filii, quod in hoc capitulo est ex terrore illud quod est in capitulo primo de cauterizatione.	Before I proceed further, it is necessary to inform you that what is contained in this chapter concerning cauterization is based on an error that appeared in the first chapter.
Et propter illud oportet, ut sit cautela in eo uehementior, quoniam in operatione quae est in hoc capitulo, multotiens cadit euacuatio cum sanguine, cum quo stat uita apud apertionem uenae, aut incisionem super apostema, aut apertionem exiturae, aut curationem uulneris, aut extractionem sagittae, aut incisionem super lapidem, et illis similia: ex quibus omnibus associatur tremor, et timor, et cadit in pluribus eorum mors.	Therefore, it is necessary to exercise caution in this procedure, for in this chapter there is a great risk of bleeding during operations such as opening a vein, or making an incision over a swelling, or opening an abscess, or performing an excision, or extracting an arrow, or making an incision in a stone, and similar procedures. All of these are associated with tremors, fear, and bleeding that occurs in many of them
Et ego moneo uos, ne cadat super uos illud in quo est haesitatio, nam quandoque cadunt ad uos in hac arte modi hominum cum modis infirmitatum.	I warn you, do not be discouraged by this, for sometimes things happen to people in this art as they do in the art of healing the sick.
Ex eis enim est qui irascitur cum aegritudine sua, et est leuis apud eum mors: propter uehementiam eius quod inuenit ex infirmitate sua et longitudine eius maliciei.	For there is no greater madness than that which is provoked by pain: for it is light in this matter, as in the case of other maladies.
Et cum aegritudine est ex timore quod significat mortem.	And when pain is excessive, it signifies death.
Et ex eis est, qui dat tibicensum suum, et ditat te cum eo, sperans sanitatem, et aegritudo eius est perniciosa.	Therefore, when a physician gives you his remedy and says to you that it will bring you health, you must know that his words are deceptive and his medicine is harmful
Non ergo oportet ut consentiatis ei qui uenit ad uos ex eis, cuius modus est talis.	It is not right to consent to what comes from him who comes to you from outside, whose way of life is like this
Et sit cautela uestra uehementior, quam cupiditas et uestra rapacitas.	Therefore, you must be cautious and prudent rather than being greedy and reckless
Et non praesumatis super aliquid ex illo, nisi post scientiam certam, quae uerificat apud uos illud ad quod peruenit successio laudabilis.	Do not presume anything about it until you have learned something certain from science that confirms that this will be successful
Et utimini in curatione omnium infirmorum uestrorum, prognosticatione et indicatione de eo ad quod conuenienter sit salus.	Use for the treatment of all sick people, prognostication and indication of what is useful for health
In illo namque est uobis adiutorium super acquisitionem famae et gloriae, et memoriae et laudis.	In this name is for you an aid above acquisition of fame and glory, and memory and praise.
Inspiret uobis Deus o filii, intellectum suum, et non auferat uobis directionem et inspirationem: quoniam illud est in manu eius.	May God inspire you, son, your intellect, and not take from you direction and inspiration: for it is in his hand
Et ego quidem ordinaui hoc Capitulum distinguendo per capitula, secundum quod praecessit in capitulo Cauterii, a ceruice usque ad pedes: ut alleuietur uobis quaesitum quod uultis ex eo, et quo indigetis.	And I indeed order this chapter to be distinguished by chapters, according as it follows the chapter of Cautery, from the hip to the feet: so that you may be relieved of the thing which you desire most from this, and of what you need.
¶ De curatione Aquae quae aggregatur in capitibus puerorum.	Concerning the care of water which accumulates in the heads of children.
Caput I.	Chapter I.
Scias, quod haec infirmitas multotiens accidit pueris apud partum: aut quando stringit obstetrix caput pueri absque leuitate.	You know that this infirmity happens often to children at birth: or when the midwife tightens the head of the child without lubrication.
Et quandeque accidit etiam ex caussa occulta quae non scitur.	And sometimes it happens also from an occult cause which is not known
Et ego quidem non uidi hanc aegritudinem in aliis quam in pueris: et ad omnem quem ex eis uidi properauit mors: propter illud ergo uisum est mihi dimittere operationem in ea.	And I have not seen this ailment in anyone other than children: and I have seen it in all whom I have seen from among the masses: because of this it is useful for me to send away the operation in this case.
Et ego quidem uidi ex eis puerum, cuius caput impletum erat aqua, et caput magnificabatur in omni die, donec non poterat sedere super seipsum, propter magnitudinem capitis sui: et humiditas augmentata fuit, donec mortuus est.	And I have seen among the children whose head was filled with water, and the head grew bigger every day, until it could not sit on itself because of the size of its head: and the moisture increased until it died
Et haec quidem humiditas, aut aggregatur inter cutem et os: aut aggregatur sub osse super sifac.	And this moisture, or it accumulates between the skin and the bone: or it accumulates under the bone on the soft parts
Et operatio in illo, si est humiditas inter cutem et os, et apostema est paruum, tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis fissura una in latitudine: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo nodi, donec currat humiditas.	And the operation in this case, if there is moisture between the skin and the bone, and the swelling is small, then it is necessary to make a single split in the middle of the head: and the length of the split should be like two knots, until the moisture is cured
Et haec est forma spatumilis.	This is the form of a sponge.
Si ergo humiditas est magis augmentata, et apostema est maius, tunc pone eas duas fissuras, secundum formam hanc.	If there is too much moisture and the swelling is greater, then make two incisions according to this form.
Et si humiditas est sub osse, et signum eius est, quod uides commissuras capitis apertas ab omni parte: et aqua deprimitur quando comprimis eam manu tua ad interiora, et non occultatur tibi illud: tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis tribus fissuris, secundum hunc modum.	If the moisture is under the bone and its sign is that the fluid escapes from all sides of the head: and the water is withdrawn when you press your hand into the inside, and it does not remain hidden: then it is necessary to make three incisions in the middle of the head according to this manner
Et post incisionem extrahe humiditatem totam.	After the incision, remove all the moisture
Deinde stringe fissuras cum pannis et puluillis.	Then close the incisions with silk and wool threads.</start_of_turn>
Deinde embroca illud desuper cum uino et oleo usque ad diem quintum.	Then bandage it up with wine and oil until the fifth day.</start_of_turn>
Deinde solue ligamentum, et cura uulnus cum tentis, et unguentis.	Then loosen the ligament and care for the wound with tension and dressing.</start_of_turn>
Et non dimittas stringere caput cum aequalitate.	And do not tighten the head too much.</start_of_turn
Et ciba infirmum omni cibo sicco paucae humiditatis, usquequo confortetur membrum, et sanetur.	And feed the patient with little food and little moisture until the limb is comfortable and healed.</start_of_turn
Et modus alius incisionis est, ut consideres ubi apparet magnitudo apostematis, et collectio aquae.	And another method of incision is to consider the size of the swelling and the collection of water.</start_of_turn
Quoniam quandoque est in occipitio plus, aut in sincipite, aut in dextra, aut in sinistra.	For sometimes it is in the occiput more, or in the chin, or in the right, or in the left.</start_of_turn
Ascende ergo cum incisione ubi apparet tibi apostema et impletio aquae: et scinde illud secundum quod tibi possibile est.	Proceed therefore with the incision where you see the swelling and the collection of water: and cut it according to what you are able to do.</start_of_turn>
Et obserua, ne incidas arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis, et moriatur infirmus ex illo fluxu cum euacuatione humiditatis.	And be careful not to cut an artery, and cause the flow of blood, and that the patient should die from that flow of blood with the evacuation of moisture.</start_of_turn
¶ De incisione Arteriarum quae sunt post aures.	Concerning the incisions of the arteries which are behind the ears.
Caput II.	Concerning the incisions of the arteries which are behind the ears.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri ad oculos, aut ad pectus, et antiquatur illud, et non confert curatio medicinarum: tunc magis ultima curatio est in illo, incisio harum duarum arteriarum.	When any swelling occurs in the head, either to the eyes or the chest, and the condition persists, and no remedy has been of avail: then the last remedy in this case is the incision of those two arteries.
Oportet ergo quando uis incidere eas, ut radat infirmus caput suum.	One must be skilled when performing such an incision, so as to prevent the patient from fainting
Deinde frica locum cum panno aspero, ut appareant arteriae.	Then [the surgeon] should rub the area with a rough cloth so that the arteries become visible.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum, cum quolibet panno suo.	Then the patient should grip his neck firmly with his hand or any other available cloth
Deinde considera, ubi pulset uena.	Then consider where the pulse is to be found
Et loca utriusque sunt loca quae sunt post aures depressa: et raro occultatur, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	And the places where both of them are to be found are those which are behind the ears depressed: and they are rarely hidden, except in some people
Deinde signa cum encaustro super utraque: et incide utramque cum spatumili utrimque acuro, incisione perueniente ad os: et fiat illud per latitudinem capitis.	And mark with a burn each of them: and cut each of them with a lancet as sharp as a knife, incision running to the bone: and do this across the width of the head.
Et si uis, intromitte spatumile sub arteria, et incide eam ad superiora cum incisione.	And if necessary, introduce a sponge under the artery, and cut upwards with the incision.</start_of_turn>
Et sit longitudo incisionis quasi duo digiti iuncti.	And let the length of the incision be like two joined fingers.</start_of_turn>
Nam quando inciditur uena, egreditur sanguis egressione pulsatili, qui salit ad interiora saltu frequenti.	For when the artery is cut, blood flows out with the pulsation, which leaps inside frequently.</start_of_turn
Si autem arteria non apparet sensui, tunc oportet ut mensures ab aure quantitatem spacii trium digitorum.	If however the artery does not appear to the eye, then it must be measured by the breadth of three fingers.</start_of_turn
Deinde signa cum encaustro, et finde usque ad os.	And mark with a burn, and find until the bone.</start_of_turn
Et illud quod oportet emittere ex sanguine, est VI uncia et fortasse emittis ex eo plus, aut minus.	And that which must be emitted from the blood is six ounces, and perhaps more or less will be emitted from it.
Totum illud secundum quantitatem quae apparet tibi ex uirute infirmi et repletione arteriae eius.	The amount of that which must be emitted from the blood is according to the quantity which appears to you from the wound of the patient and the filling of its artery
Deinde considera ad uulnus.	Consider the wound.
Tunc si remanet ad os ex sifac aliquid, tunc incide illud, ut non accidat apostema calidum: tunc stringe uulnus cum liciniis ex panno lini.	Then if anything remains on the bone from the scraping of something, then cut that, so that no thick clot may happen: then bind the wound with strips of linen cloth
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for the wound with unguents, until it is healed.
¶ De extractione arteriarum, quae sunt in timporibus.	Concerning the extraction of arteries which are in their courses
Caput III.	(The text continues with the next chapter heading.)
Quando accidit homini hemicranea antiqua, aut catarri acuti propter humiditates acrimoniales, et caliditate in lacertis timporum, aut soda antiqua, uehemens, et similia illis: et medicatur cum modis curationis medicinae, et non confert illud: tunc experti sumus in his aegritudinibus extractionem arteriarum ex timporibus, aut cauterizationem earum, sicut narrauimus.	When it happens to a man an old hemorrhage, or an acute catarrh because of acrid humilities and heat in the wounds of the times, or an old soda, vinegar, and things like these: and it is medicated with the methods of the healing of medicine, and does not give relief from it: then we are experienced in these ailments of the arteries of the times, or their cauterization, as we have narrated.
Et modus operationis in extractione earum, est, ut radat infirmus pilos qui sunt in timporibus, et intendat ad arteriam apparentem in timpore.	And the method of the operation in the extraction of these is that the physician grasps the hair of the patient which are in the times, and brings it to the apparent artery in the time.
Ipsa namque ostenditur tibi ex pulsu suo, et raro occultatur nisi in paucis hominibus, aut uehementia frigoris.	It itself is seen by you from his pulse, and rarely is it hidden except in a few people, or the heat of cold.
Quod si occultatur tibi, tunc stringat infirmus caput suum cum quolibet panno suo: deinde frica locum cum panno aspero.	If it is hidden from you, then bind the patient's head with anything of his cloth: then rub the place with rough cloth
Aut uapora locum cum aqua calida, donec appareat tibi apparitione manifesta.	Or apply the place with warm water, until there appears to you a clear sign.
Deinde accipe spatumile, quod paulo ante formaui.	Then take hold of the sponge, which is before your form.
Deinde excoria cum eo cutem cum facilitate, donec peruenias ad arteriam.	Then cleanse the skin with the sponge, until you reach the artery.
Deinde proiice in eam uncinum, et extrahe eam ad superiora, donec extrahas eam ex cute, et facias eam euadere ex tunicis quae sunt sub ea ab omni parte.	Then pull out the thread from the wound, and draw it upwards, until you have drawn out the thread from the skin, and make the wound empty of any cloths that are under it from all sides
Si autem arteria est subtilis: tunc inuolue eam cum extremitate uncini.	If the artery is small: then bind up the wound with the end of a thread.
Deinde incide ex ea partem secundum quantitatem qua elongentur extremitates eius, et contrahantur, et non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Then cut away from that part as much as the length of its extremities, and contract, and let no blood flow forth
Nam si non inciditur, et si non abscinditur, non ascendit sanguis penitus.	For if it is not cut away, and if it is not bound, the blood does not ascend fully
Deinde euacua ex sanguine ana VI unci, usque ad .III.	Then wash out the blood with six ounces of vinegar, until .III
Quod si arteria est magna: tunc oportet ut liges eam in duobus locis ex filo duplo, forti, ex serico: aut ex chordis alhohod, ut non properet ad ipsam putrefactio ante consolidationem uulneris, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	If the artery is large: then it is necessary to bind up the wound in two places with a strong thread of silk: or with horsehair, so that it does not burst before the wound has consolidated, and that the blood flow may be restored
Deinde incide superfluitatem, quae est inter duo ligamenta.	Then cut away the excess, which is between the two ligatures
Fac illud in illa hora, aut post horam aliam.	Do this in an hour, or after an hour
Et si uis, cauteriza eam cauterio usque ad os, cum cauterio cultellari: donec incidantur extremitates eius, et stabit loco eiusdem operis.	And if necessary, cauterize the wound with a cautery until it reaches the bone, with a knife cautery: until its extremities have healed, and it has stabilized in the place of the work
Et est melius opus, nisi si infirmus habet febrem, autest calefactae complexionis.	It is better to do the work, if the patient does not have a fever, or has a flushed complexion.
Quoniam cauterium est ex eis, quae iuuant ad finiendas humiditates.	For cautery is from vapor, which dries up humors
Ergo est melius iuuamentum.	Therefore it is better to apply a remedy
Et oportet post extractionem arteriarum, ut impleatur locus cotto antiquo: et ponantur super ipsum puluilli decenter facti.	And it is necessary after the extraction of arteries that the cavity be closed up as before: and they are to be placed upon the middle of the wound.
Et post solutionem curetur cum medicinis siccis, quae faciunt nasci carnem, et cum liciniis, donec sanetur.	And after closure they are to be cared for with dry medicines which cause the flesh to grow, and with dressings, until they are healed.</start_of_turn>
Quod si interim dum operaris accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, tunc propera ad abscindendum eum cum cauterio, aut ut impleas locum cum zegi: et stringe manum tuam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	And if during the operation blood flows from the artery, then it is proper to bind it off with cautery, or to close the hole with silk: and grasp your hand until the bleeding stops.</start_of_turn>
Quod si nihil ex illis est tibi praesens, tunc pone super locum digitum tuum, donec congeletur sanguis.	And if nothing of these things is present, then place upon the place of the digit your hand, until the bleeding stops.</start_of_turn>
Et embroca locum cum aqua uehementis frigoris, donec quiescat acuitas, et stringatur secundum quod oportet.	And bind the place with cold water, until the pain subsides, and tie according as it should be.</start_of_turn
Et ex eo quod est leuius et facilius extractione arteriae, est, ut cauterizes uenam cum hoc cauterio habente duos cultellos: sitque acuitas duorum cultellorum similis almagdatem.	And from this it is evident that the easiest and most straightforward extraction of an artery is with a cautery which has two blades: and let the sharpness of the two blades be similar to an almond.</start_of_turn
Verumtamen sunt multo minoris acuitatis, quam duo cultelli.	But truly they are much smaller in sharpness than two blades.</start_of_turn
Quoniam si sunt acutae, sicut duo cultelli, properat utrisque frigus: et non incidunt carnem cum uelocitate.	For if they are sharp, like two blades, they are proper for both heat and cold: and do not tear the flesh with speed.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo in eis est aliquantulum grossitudinis, tenetur in eis calor ignis, et abscinditur caro uelociter: cum hoc ergo opus est melius omni opere, et leuius, et facilius.	When therefore in this is some degree of thickness, it is held in the hand of the fire and is bound off more quickly: with this therefore the work is better in every way, and easier, and more straightforward.</start_of_turn
Et sit spacium quod est inter duos cultellos quantitas grossitudinis digiti, postquam tu signas duo loca cum encaustro: et depone utrosque ignitos ualde, donec perueniant ad os, et incidant uenam in duobus locis: ut elongetur quod est inter extremitates eius.	And let the space which is between the two blades be the size of the digit, after you have marked two points with the cautery: and place both ignited together downwards, until they reach the bone, and pierce the artery in two places: so that the length which is between the extremities is elongated.</start_of_turn
Nam non consolidantur cum hoc cauterio penitus.	They do not solidify with this deep burn.
Et haec est forma cauterii.	This is the form of the burn.
¶ De cura cursus lachrymarum acutarum assiduarum ab oculis.	Take care of the acute tears that run from the eyes continuously.
Caput IIII.	Chapter III
Quando sunt lachrymae assiduae, et est cursus earum ex uenis, quae sunt super craneum capitis exterius: et non confert in eis aliquid curationis medicinae cum medicinis, et uides faciem infirmi iam rubere, et sentit in fronte sua deambulationem, sicut est deambulatio formicarum: et oculi eius sunt extenuati, humidi, ita quod iam corrosi sunt pili eorum cum corrosione: et calefactae sunt palpebrae eius ex acuitate lachrymarum: tunc antiqui indiguerunt in curatione earum hac operatione, et denominauerunt eam curationem, cum Ense.	When there are continuous tears running from the eyes, which are above the outer part of the head: and there is no need for any medical treatment with doctors, and the tears cause the face of the patient to become red, and he feels a walk in his face like that of ants: and his eyes are expanded, wet, as if they were corroded with the tears: and his eyelashes are reddened from the intensity of the tears: then the ancients resorted to treatment for these with an operation, and they called this treatment, with Ense.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere pilos qui sunt in fronte sua.	It is that, especially for the patient, to shave off the hair on his face
Deinde incide in fronte tres fissuras aequedistantes secundum longitudinem frontis: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo digiti, et fissura una sit aequedistans longitudini nasi in medio frontis, et secunda secundum longitudinem parumper a motu lacertorum, et tertia a parte altera: et caue ab incisione arteriarum quae sunt in duobus lateribus: et elonga manum tuam a continuatione duarum mandibularum, et sit spacium omnis incisionis quantitas trium digitorum coniunctorum: et sit tibi frustum spongiae praeparatum, aut panni siccati multi, cum quibus exsicces sanguinem.	Then make three equal incisions on the forehead according to the length of the forehead: and let the length of the incision be like two fingers, and let one incision be at the distance of the nose from the middle of the forehead, and the second at the distance of the movement of the lacerations, and the third from the other side: and cauterize from the arteries which are in the two sides: and extend your hand from the continuation of the two mandibles, and let the space of the incision be as much as the thickness of three connected fingers: and let a sponge be prepared, or dry cloth, with which to soak up the blood
Deinde intromitte spatumile duarum acutarum extremitatum, cuius mox sequens est forma.	Then introduce two acute extremities of a sponge, whose following is the shape
Ab incisione quae est a parte timporis, usque ad incisionem secundam: et excoria cum eo totam cutem, quae est inter duas incisiones, cum sifac, quod est super os.	From the incision on the temporal side to the second incision: and scrape with it the whole skin which is between the two incisions, with a scraper, which is over the bone.
Deinde fac illud etiam ab incisione media usque ad incisionem secundam.	Then do it also from the middle incision to the second incision.
Deinde extrahe hoc spatumile, et intromitte in incisionem primam iterum instrumentum aliud, quod nominatur cultellare acutum, ab una parte lene, non acutum ab altera parte.	Then extract this sponge, and insert into the first incision once more a different instrument, which is called the sharp knife, from one side blunt, not sharp from the other side.</start_of_turn>
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its form.</start_of_turn>
Et pone latus eius acutum uersus carnem annexam cum cute, et latus eius lene uersus os: et impelle ipsum, donec perueniat ad fissuram mediam: et abscinde cum eo omnia uasa, quae descendunt a capite ad oculos: praeter quod continuetur incisio usque ad illud quod apparet de cute.	And place its edge sharp towards the flesh attached with skin, and its edge blunt towards the bone: and press it in until it reaches the middle incision: and cut through everything that descends from the head to the eyes: except that which appears on the skin.</start_of_turn
Deinde fac illud in fissura media usque ad fissuram aliam.	Then do it also from the middle incision to the second incision.</start_of_turn>
Et postquam currit ex sanguine quantitas aequalis, exprime loca ex frustis sanguinis coagulati.	And when the bleeding has ceased an equal amount, express the place from coagulated blood clots.</start_of_turn>
Deinde pone in omnem fissuram licinium ex cotto ueteri, et pone super eos puluillos imbibitos in uino, et oleo, aut aceto.	Then place in every incision a layer of old cotton, and place over it soaked sponges in wine, and butter, or vinegar.</start_of_turn
Et uide ut non accidat apostema calidum.	And see that no swelling arises.</start_of_turn
Et in die tertia solue ligamentum, et administra infusionem multam cum aqua tepida.	And on the third day heal the ligament, and give a plentiful infusion with warm water.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura illud ex unguento basilicon, et reliquis quibus curantur uulnera: usquequo sanetur.	And care for this from the basic ointment, and for the rest that heals wounds: until it is healed.</start_of_turn
¶ De cura lachrymarum acutarum et catarrorum ad oculos ex interioribus capitis.	Concerning the care of acute tears and catarrh of the eyes from the inside of the head.</start_of_turn
Caput V.	Chapter V.</start_of_turn>
Quando accidunt alicui catarri acuti, acres, assidui: et uides oculos eius extenuatos, paruos, et iam debilitatus est aspectus eorum: et palpebrae ulceratae, et cadunt pili ex eis, et in profundo capitis est dolor acutus, laedens, et sternutatio consequens: tunc sume ex istis accidentibus, quod illae materiae, et catarri non ueniunt, nisi ex uenis multis.	When someone has suffered from acute, severe, and sticky tears: and their eyes are swollen, parched, and pale: and their eyelashes are ulcerated, and hair falls out from the eyelashes, and there is severe pain in the depth of the head, with sighing: then take away from these causes whatever does not cause tears, and the catarrh is not from many.</start_of_turn
Et melior curatio in eis est haec.	The best treatment in these matters is this.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere frontem suam.	The best is to shave the patient's face promptly.
Deinde incide in eam fissuram unam in medio frontis, aut alterius parumper per latitudinem, et incipe cum fissura a timpore sinistro ad timpus dextrum: et sit incisio usque ad os: et elonga manum tuam a lacertis timporum, qui mouentur apud masticationem: donec quando detegitur os: et exsiccabis totum sanguinem cum spongia.	Then make a single incision in the middle of the face, or on the other side along the width, and commence the incision from the left ear to the right ear: and let the incision reach the bone: and stretch out your hand from the wounds which move at mastication until the bone is revealed: and soak up all the blood with a sponge.
Tunc separa inter duo labia fissurae cum cotto ueteri, aut cum liciniis ex lino.	Then separate the two lips of the wound with a piece of cotton wool, or with strips of linen.
Deinde stringe desuper cum puluillis: et imbibe puluillos cum uino et oleo, ut non accidat apostema calidum.	Then bind up above with thread: and soak the thread with wine and oil, so that it does not cause a swelling
Et quando soluis illud, et uides quod apostema calidum iam imminuitur: tunc oportet ut frices os, donec incipiat in eo nasci caro.	And when you have finished, and you see that the swelling is diminishing: then it is necessary to compress the bone until flesh begins to grow in it
Deinde cura ipsum cum regimine exiccatiuo quod facit nasci carnem: sicut si accipias ex farina tritici partes duas, et ex colophonia quatuor partes: et praepares ex eis emplastrum, et administretur ad natiuitatem carnis in istis uulneribus.	Then care for yourself with meticulous attention to the regimen of nourishment that makes flesh grow: as if you were to take two parts of wheat flour and four parts of colophony, and prepare from this a plaster, and administer it to the wound
¶ De cura eius quod cadit in Aurem.	And concerning the care of the wound during the Golden Age.
Caput VI.	(The text provided does not include any content for Chapter VI, so I am unable to translate it.)
Omne Quod in Aurem cadit, est una quatuor specierum: aut lapis mineralis, aut simile lapidi, sicut ferrum, et uitrum: aut est ex planta, sicut est cicer, et fabae: aut est res fluxibilis, sicut aqua, et acetum, et eis similia: aut aliquod animal.	Every thing that falls into the Golden Age is of four kinds: either a mineral substance, or one like stone, such as iron and gold; or it is of a plant origin, such as beans and peas; or it is a flowing substance, such as water, vinegar, and blood, and things that are like them; or it is some living creature.
Quando ergo cadit in aurem lapis, aut genus lapidis ex eis quae non adduntur, neque crescunt in aure, expone Aurem soli: si ergo uides lapidem, tunc distilla in Aurem aliquid ex oleo uiolato, aut sisamino.	When such a substance falls into the Golden Age, which is not from the earth and does not grow in the Golden Age, it exposes the Golden Age to the solid state: if you wash away the stone, then something distilled from oil or resin will remain in the Golden Age
Deinde administra extractionem eius, et fac sternutare cum condisi, et opila nares apud aduentum sternutationis, postquam tu ponis in circumitu auris frusta ex pannis, aut lana, et extendis aurem ad superiora.	Then perform the extraction and make the area firm with pressure, and pour oil into the nostrils opposite the area of pressure, after you have placed around the ear a ball of wool or cloth and extended the ear upwards.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum hac cura.	Many are grateful for this care.
Si autem non egreditur, tunc administra extractionem eius cum Gesti, id est, Pizigarolis subtilibus: cuius forma est haec.	If however they do not depart, then perform the extraction with sponges, that is, fine sponges: whose form is like this.
Si ergo egreditur cum gesti, est bonum.	If therefore they depart with the sponge, that is good.
Et si non, tunc administra extractionem eius cum uncino caeco subtili paucae duplicationis.	And if not, then perform the extraction with a blunt needle of small size.
Si ergo non egreditur per illud, tunc fac cannulam ex aere, et intromitte extremitatem cannulae in foramen auris multum, et opila quod est in circumitu cannulae cum caera mollificata cum oleo, ut non sit uento uia nisi cannulae: deinde extrahe cum uento tuo attractione forti.	If they do not depart by this, then make a hole in the air and introduce the extremity of the tube into the ear a great deal, and pour oil which is around the tube with wool which has been softened with oil, so that there is no air except for the tube: then extract with your hand with great traction.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus.	Many are grateful for this which we have mentioned
Si autem non egreditur hoc modo: tunc accipe ex helkalimbat, aut ex uisco, id est, gluten praeparato, cum quo capiuntur aues, rem modicam: et pone ipsum in extremitate radii postquam tu inuoluis super eam cotum decenter positum: deinde intromitte ipsum in foramen auris cum facilitate, postquam tu exiccas aurem ab humiditate.	If they do not depart in this way: then take from barley or from wheat, that is, prepared gluten, with which one seizes the wings, a remedy: and put it on the edge of the radius after you have enveloped above the ankle positioned centrally: then introduce it into the ear with ease, after you have dried the ear from moisture
Si ergo non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc propera ad scindendum, antequam accidat apostema calidum, aut spasmus.	If they do not depart with all that we have mentioned, then prepare to perforate, before the swelling becomes acute, or spasm.
Et modus fissurae est, ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis in cephalica: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum mensuram uirtutis eius.	And the method of perforation is like a phlebotomy in the first place in the neck: and extract from him from the blood according to the measure of his courage.
Deinde fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et conuerte aurem eius ad superiora, et finde fissuram paruam in radice auris apud adipem eius in loco depresso ipsi: et sit fissura lunaris figurae, donec peruenias ad lapidem: deinde aufer eum cum eo, quod est tibi possibile ex instrumentis.	Then make the patient sit between your hands, and support his ear upwards, and find the opening of the perforation parallel to the ridge of his ear in the hollow part of it: and make the perforation in the shape of a crescent, until you reach the bone: then remove it with the forceps which are possible from the instruments.
Deinde sue fissuram ab hora tua cum uelocitate, et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then seal the wound from the current hour with speed, and care for it until it heals.
Quod si res cadens in aurem est ex uno granorum, quae crescunt, et inflantur: tunc administra extractionem eius.	If anything falling from one grain has grown and become inflamed: then manage its extraction.</start_of_turn>
Si autem non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc accipe spatumile tenue, subtile, secundum hanc formam.	If it does not obey you with respect to its extraction, then take a soft sponge, fine and smooth, according to this shape.</start_of_turn
Et administra cum eo abscisionem illius speciei ex granis, quae cadunt in aurem, et non facias illud, quando tu cogitas, quod illud granum iam humectatum est per uaporem auris, donec ponis ipsum frusta multa: deinde extrahe ea cum uncinis, aut cum gesti subtili, aut cum suctione, sicut diximus, nam extractio eius alleuiatur.	And manage with it the excision of that kind of grain which falls into the ear, and do not make it bleed, when you think that that grain is already moistened by the vapor of the ear, until you put it out with many sponges: then extract it with hooks, or with fine graspers, or with suction, as we have said, for its extraction alleviates.</start_of_turn>
In aqua autem quae ingreditur in aurem, oportet ut utatur infirmus sternutatione cum condisi in primis: et iam impleuit aurem suam cum aliquanto cotto ueteri: et est iacens super illam aurem, in qua est aqua.	But in the water which enters the ear, it is necessary to keep the patient quiet with sneezing from the beginning: and immediately cover the ear with some cotton wool: and lie upon it the ear which is in the water.</start_of_turn
Si ergo egreditur per illud, est bonum.	If therefore it comes out through this, that is good.</start_of_turn>
Et si non: tunc accipe lapides multos, secundum longitudinem digiti, tenues, lenes, et calefac eos cum igne parumper, et intromittat infirmus ex eis unum in foramen auris suae: et saliat super pedem suum unum ex illa parte, et percutiat cum lapide alio super lapidem qui est in aure.	And if not: then take many stones, according to the length of a finger, thin and smooth, and heat them with fire together, and introduce the patient from one ear into the other: and pour some salt upon his foot from that side, and strike with another stone upon the stone which is in the ear.</start_of_turn
Non ergo cesset facere illud cum lapide et lapide, donec egrediatur tota aqua.	Do not cease doing this with the stone and the stone, until all the water has come out.</start_of_turn>
Et iam egreditur aqua ita, ut accipias ex parpyro, aut ex iunco unum, et intromittas extremitatem eius unam in aurem: et accendas extremitatem alteram cum igne, donec comburatur plurimum eius.	And when the water comes out like this, take it out with a scoop or with a single sponge, and introduce the extremity of it once into the ear: and burn the other extremity with fire, until most of it is consumed.</start_of_turn
Deinde itera iuncum alium, et fac illud multotiens, donec egrediatur tota aqua: et extrahe ipsam cum cannula secundum quod praemissum est in lapide.	Then repeat the process with another sponge, and make it much wetter, until all the water has drained out: and extract it with a tube as previously directed in the stone.
In extractione autem animalis intrantis in eam, si est parui corporis, ut pulex, et ei simile, cura ipsum sicut dixi in diuisione.	In the extraction of an animal that is within the body of the wound, if it is of small size, like a flea or similar, take care of it as I have said in the instructions
Sed si est corporis magni, quod appareat sensui: tunc administra extractionem eius cum gesti, et uncinis: et res eius est facilior omnibus, quae tenentur in aure.	But if it is of large size, which appears to the sense: then manage its extraction with hands and instruments: and thus it is easier for all who hold the vessel
In extractione autem uermis generati in aure, quando curas eum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et in tractatu distilationum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut aspicias aurem in sole.	When you have cured it with the things which we have mentioned in the instructions on distillation and treatment, and if your cure does not suffice: then you must bring the wound into the open air.
Si ergo apparet illic aliquid ex uermibus, tunc extrahe illud cum gesti, aut cum uncinis subtilibus.	If anything appears there from the worms, then extract it with hands or with fine instruments
Si autem non apparet illic aliquid, tunc accipe cannulam, cuius haec est forma, stricta inferius, ampla superius: et intromitte extremitatem subtilem in aurem secundum quantitatem quod tolerat eam infirmus: deinde suge cum ea suctione forti.	If nothing appears there, then take a tube, which has a narrow lower part and a wide upper part: and insert the lower part into the wound according to the capacity of the patient: then withdraw it with force.
Fac illud multotiens, donec egrediantur omnes uermes.	Make it much wetter, until all the worms have drained out.
Si autem non obediunt tibi ad exitum, tunc opila circumitum cannulae cum caera, sicut dixi in lapide.	If they do not obey you in leaving, then smear the circumference of the tube with grease, as I have said in the stone
Quod si non egrediuntur cum eo quod diximus: tunc administra distillationes quas iam experti sunt antiqui in interfectione uermium: et inuenies illud in tractatu distillationum.	If they do not leave when you have done what we have said: then perform distillations which the ancient experts have learned for the elimination of worms: and you will find it in the treatise on distillations
Et sit effusio tua qua effundis olea et medicinas in aurem cum hoc instrumento, cuius forma depicta est hic.	And let your effusion be such as you pour oil and medicines into the wound with this instrument, which has the shape mentioned above
Sicut uides fac ipsum ex argento, aut aere, inferius strictum, in quo sit foramen paruum, amplum superius.	As for wounds made by silver or by air, below a strict bandaging, there is a small hole, a wide one above.
Sit ergo ut impellens quod est in concauitate cannulae, sit ex aere decenter factum.	The force that is in the curvature of the tube is placed outside the air hole.</start_of_turn>
Et si uis, accipe radium, et inuolue in extremitate eius cottum inuolutione decenti: deinde proiice oleum, aut succum, aut quod uis ex istis medicinis in cannulam: et ipsa sit in aure: deinde intromitte radium cum cotto desuper, et exprime ipsum manu tua compressione temperata, donec impellatur oleum in concauitate auditus, et sentiat ipsum infirmus interius: et illud quod infunditur in aurem, sit iam calefactum cum igne parumper: et caue ne sit res quae distillatur in eam frigida ualde: medicinae enim non tolerant illud.	If you wish, take a radius and encircle in its extremity a piece of cotton. Then pour oil, or balsam, or whatever you wish of these medicines into the tube: and let it rest there. Then introduce the radius with the cotton above, and press it down with your hand in a temperate manner, until oil is driven into the curvature of the ear, and the patient feels it inside: that which is poured into the ear is to be warmed with a little fire: and take care that nothing distills in the ear when it is cold: for medicines do not tolerate this.</start_of_turn>
¶ De cura opilationis accidentis Auri.	Concerning the care of a burn.</start_of_turn>
Caput VII.	Chapter 7.</start_of_turn
Quandoque egrediuntur quidam infantes ex uentribus matrum suarum non perforati.	When some children emerge from the mother's womb without perforating them.</start_of_turn
Et iam accidit etiam quibusdam hominibus opilatio in meatu Auris a uulnere, aut carne nata in ea.	And sometimes it happens that some people suffer a burn in the ear from a wound, or from meat that is born there.</start_of_turn
Et haec opilatio quandoque fit in profundo foraminis Auris, quam non consequitur uisus: et quandoque accidit ad exteriora foraminis parum, et consequitur eam uisus.	And this burn sometimes happens in the depth of the earhole, as it does not follow custom: and sometimes it happens outside the earhole a little, and follows custom.</start_of_turn
Illa ergo quae accidit in profundo Auris, et quam non comprehendit aspectus, est in pluribus dispositionibus difficilis sanationis.	That which happens in the depth of the ear, and which does not comprehend the aspect, is in many positions difficult to heal.</start_of_turn
Et in illa quam consequitur uisus, oportet ut ponas Aurem infirmi in sole, et aspicias in ea: tunc si uides opilationem apparentem, aperi eam cum spatumili subtili, cuius forma est haec quae sequitur, sit extremitas eius in qua sit quaedam latitudo parua, cuius quaedam pars sit acuta: et reliquum spatumile sit duarum laterum lenium: ut non laedat aurem.	And in that which follows custom, it is necessary to put the ear of the patient on the sole, and to press on it: then if you see the burn appearing, open the wound with a fine needle, whose form is this which follows, so that its extremity is in the part which has a small width, whose part is acute: and the rest of the needle is soft: so as not to hurt the ear.</start_of_turn
Si ergo opilatio est a carne nata in meatu auris: tunc tene eam cum uncino subtili, et incide eam cum facilitate uehementi, donec auferatur tota caro.	If there is an opening from the cartilage to the meat of the ear: then hold the ear with a fine hook, and cut it off with ease until the whole flesh is removed.
Quod si opilatio est in profundo auris: tunc accipe radium subtilem, lenem, et calefac ipsum cum igne parumper: deinde mitte ipsum in meatum auris.	If the opening is in the depth of the ear: then take a fine needle, thread, and burnish it with fire: then remove it from the meat of the ear.
Si ergo senseris opilationem cum eo, quod inuenit infirmus cum grauitate auditus, conare apertionem eius cum facilitate: et caue, ne uulneres neruos auris.	If you feel a sense of opening with this, which the infirm has with a weighty deafness, try to open it with ease: and beware, lest you damage the nerves of the ear.
Deinde pone in aurem licinium secundum quantitatem amplitudinis foraminis, quod inuoluisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud aliquot diebus, donec sis securus de consolidatione uulneris.	Then put in the ear a patch according to the quantity of the breadth of the opening which you have cut with the Egyptian unguent: make this for a few days, until you are secure about the consolidation of the wound.
Aut accipe licinium, et infunde ipsum in aqua rosata, et pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, et utere ipso.	Or take a patch and soak it in rose water, and grind on it some powdered alum, and use this.
Quod si uides aurem iam apostemari: tunc oportet ut extrahas licinium, et permittas ipsum cum licinio alio, quod inuolues in caeroto quod sit factum cum oleo rosato, donec sedetur apostema calidum: deinde cura ipsum usquequo sanetur.	If you wish to dry up the ear: then it is necessary that you remove the patch, and let it dry with another patch, which you put on a wound made with rose water, until the swelling subsides: then care for it until it is healed
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis: tunc submerge spongiam, aut pannos in aqua frigida, et pone super eam aurem: et utere reliqua curatione, quae abscindit fluxum sanguinis praedicta in tractatu distillationum.	If blood flows: then immerse a sponge, or pack it in cold water, and put it on the ear: and use the rest of the treatment which expels the predicted flow of blood in the tract of distillation.
¶ De cura Altheli palpebrarum.	Regarding the care of the eyelids.
Caput VIII.	(The remaining text is not included in the provided context.)
Isti Althelil qui accidunt in Palpebris oculi, quandoque sunt humidi, et sunt sicci.	These are the Althelis which happen in the eyelids, when they are wet and when they are dry.
Oportet ergo ut teneas eos cum tenaliis: aut cum uncino, et incidas eos cum spatumili a radicibus suis.	It is necessary therefore to hold them with tweezers: or with a hook, and cut them away from their roots
Deinde pone super loca zegi tritum.	Then place above the wound a soft cushion.
Si autem ex eis fluat sanguis, tunc cauteriza eos cum cauterio lenticulari subtili.	If blood flows from the wound, then cauterize it with a fine lancet.</start_of_turn>
Et cauterizare eos, est melius post incisionem.	It is better to cauterize after the incision.</start_of_turn>
Multotiens enim redeunt quando remanet ex radicibus suis aliquid.	Many times they return when something remains from their roots.</start_of_turn>
Et quando cauterizantur cum igne, comburuntur illae radices, et non redeunt.	And when they are cauterized with fire, they burn those roots and they do not return.</start_of_turn
¶ De cura Grandinum palpebrarum oculi.	Take care of the large palpebrae of the eye.</start_of_turn>
Caput IX.	Chapter IX.</start_of_turn
Multotiens accidit in palpebris aliquid quod assimilatur Crandini in fortitudine sua, et sua duricie, et propter illud nominatur Grando: et est aggregatio humiditatis grossae in palpebra superiore, et palpebra inferiore.	Many things happen in the palpebrae of the eye which assimilate Crandinum in its firmness and its hardness, and because of this it is called Grandus: and it is the collection of thick moisture in the upper and lower palpebrae.</start_of_turn
Operatio ergo in eis est, ut consideres tunc, si est Grando procedens in eo, quod apparet de palpebra, et mouentur ad omnem partem, et res eius est facilis.	The operation is therefore in the eye, as you see, if there is a Grandus proceeding from the palpebra, which appears from the palpebra and moves to all parts, and its result is easy.</start_of_turn
Finde ergo super eam fissura per latitudinem.	Find therefore above the wound across the width.</start_of_turn
Deinde excoria eam ab omni parte cum facilitate, donec euadat.	Then scrape away the wound from all around with ease, until it is clean.</start_of_turn
Deinde suspende eam cum uncino, et abscinde ipsam.	Then suspend the wound with a suture, and cut it off.</start_of_turn
Si autem non praeparatur tibi abscisio eius, nisi postquam tu penetras palpebram cum incisione parumper, tunc nocet infirmo illud in aliquo.	If, however, you do not prepare the cut for abscission, except when you penetrate the palpebra with a small incision, then it will be harmful to the patient in some way.</start_of_turn
Quod si fissura est magna: tunc aggrega ipsam cum sutura: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	If the wound is large: then join it together with a suture: and care for it until it heals.</start_of_turn
Et si est parua, non superueniet tibi malum ex ea.	If it is small, it will not cause any harm from it.
Vnguentum enim restaurat ipsam, et incarnat eam.	The wound will restore itself, and the pain will vanish.
Et si grando est decliuis ad interiora auris uersus superficiem intrinsecam, tunc inuersa palpebram, et suspende grandinem cum uncino: praeter quod indigeas incisione, et preme eam ab omni parte.	If it is large, it is advisable to incline it towards the inner parts of the ear towards the surface; then palpate the area thoroughly, and suspend the large size with a loop: for otherwise you will be tempted to make an incision, and press it from all sides
Quod si elongatur palpebra per incisionem, non nocet illud in aliquo.	If the area is prolonged by incision, that does not harm in any way
Deinde ablue oculum post incisionem grandinis, cum aqua salsa: et cura locum cum eo quod incarnat, donec sanetur infirmus.	Then wash the eye after the incision of the large size with salt water: and care for the place with that which is incrusted, until the infirmity is healed.
¶ De cura Axirnath palpebrarum.	About the care of the eyelids.
Caput X.	Chapter X
Axirnath est adeps qui generatur in tunicis palpebrae superioris: et plurimum quidem accidit illud pueris: et ipsum grauat oculos eorum, et accidunt eis catarri in matutinis, et non possunt intueri lumen solis, propterea, quod lachrymae properant ad eos, et propter illud uides eos discumbere super facies suas semper, et super eas dormiunt, et sunt palpebrae eorum sub superciliis humidae, quas iam cooperuit inflatio: et eminentia quidem Axirnath apparens est oculo, et quando tu premis locum cum digitis tuis, sentis Axirnath inter eos.	The speck which is produced in the upper eyelid is called Axirnath: and this most frequently happens to children.  It weighs down the eyes, and causes tears to gather in the mornings, and they are unable to see the sunlight because of this, for the tears run down their face and over their eyes.  They sleep with their eyes always wet under their eyebrows, which have been puffed up by the inflation: and the prominence of Axirnath appears in the eye, and when you touch the place with your fingers, you feel Axirnath between your fingers.
Et modus operationis eius est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the method of treating it is to place the patient's head in your lap
Deinde accipe pannum lini, et praepara in eo licinia, et fac ex illo licinio circulum secundum quantitatem quod continet Axirnath ab omni parte.	Then take a piece of linen, and prepare in it a loop, and make from that loop a circle according to the quantity which contains Axirnath from all sides.
Deinde pone eum super eam, et preme cum digitis tuis ab omni parte, ut aggregetur Axirnath in medio circuli.	Then place it over the eye, and press with your fingers from all sides, so that the Axirnath is gathered in the middle of the circle
Deinde finde in medio illius humiditatis cum spatumili incidente fissuras per latitudinem, et non sit fissura maior illa quae fit in phlebotomia in profundo.	Then find in the middle of that moisture a swelling that has happened beside the heel of the foot, and let there be no greater split than that which is made in phlebotomy in depth.
Aut oportet ut findas cutem totam, donec peruenias ad Axirnath in pluribus enim dispositionibus procedit Axirnath ex fissura secundum formam frusti pinguedinis albae.	Or it may be necessary to find the whole skin, until Axirnath proceeds from the split according to the form of a white crust in multiple arrangements
Extrahe ergo eam cum panno, quem infiltrasti inter digitos tuos ad exteriora: et tu reuoluis manum tuam ad dextram et sinistram, donec dispergatur: et caue, ne addas in fissura, ut non peruenias cum spatumili ad oculum, et laedas eum.	Extract therefore the blood with the bandage which you have infiltrated between your fingers outwards: and you will move your hand to the right and left, until it is scattered: and take care, lest you add to the split, that you do not reach the heel with the blood, and stain it.</start_of_turn>
Si autem non appareat tibi Axirnath in principio fissurae, tu addas in fissura parum cum facilitate, donec procedat Axirnath.	If, however, you do not see Axirnath at the beginning of the split, you will add a little to the split with ease, until Axirnath proceeds.</start_of_turn>
Deinde extrahe eam, sicut diximus.	Then extract the blood as we have said.</start_of_turn>
Deinde submerge pannos in aceto et aqua, et pone eos super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis.	Then immerse the bandages in vinegar and water, and put them over the place, and bind them with threads.</start_of_turn>
Et ex hominibus sunt qui terunt salem, et ponunt ipsum in concauitate fissurae, ut liquefiat quod remansit ex illa humiditate.	And from men there are some who pour salt upon it, and put it into the hollow of the split, so that it may liquefy what remains of that moisture.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it until it is healed.</start_of_turn
Si autem accidat in loco apostema calidum, tune cura ipsum cum emplastris sedatiuis, donec sanetur.	If, however, there should happen in the place of the swelling a hard calcar, then take care of it with soft plasters until it is healed.</start_of_turn
¶ De modis Ataxmir oculi, id est, cum palpebra mollificatur oculi, unde fit ut rugetur sicut non debet.	As regards the methods of treating the eye, that is, when the eyelid is softened, from which it results in redness as it should not.</start_of_turn
Caput XI.	Chapter 11.</start_of_turn>
Quando nascuntur in palpebris oculi pili additi praeter cursum sub pilis naturalibus, et antiquantur: tunc ipsi nocent oculo, et faciunt accidere modos aegritudinum, sicut lachrymas assiduas, et mollificationem palpebrarum, et albuginem, donec fit illud caussa destructionis oculi.	When hairs grow in the eyelids beyond the normal course among the natural hair, they cause damage to the eye. This brings about symptoms such as excessive tears, softening of the eyelids, and discharge, until such time as the eye is destroyed.
Et Ataxmir quidem oculi curatur secundum quatuor modos.	The eye is cleansed according to four methods.
Aut per cauterium cum igne.	Or with the use of fire.
Aut cum medicina acuta, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo cauterii.	Or with sharp medicine, as has been mentioned previously in the chapter on cautery
Aut curatur Ataxmir per incisionem et suturam.	Or by incision and stitching of the eye
Aut per cannas, secundum quod ego dicam.	Or with needles, as I shall explain later.
Oportet ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	It is necessary to place the patient's head in your lap
Deinde conuerte palpebram oculi manu tua sinistra.	Then take hold of the patient's left eyelid with your left hand
Si ergo conuertitur, bonum est.	If you grasp it firmly, that is good
Et si non: intromitte acum in eam, in qua sit filum ab inferiori parte palpebrae, et fac penetrare acum cum filo desuper, et sit illud prope pilos ipsos, id est, prope marginem palpebrae, in quo nascuntur pili: et trahe filum ad superiora cum palpebra, et conuerte eam cum radio.	And if you do not grasp it firmly: insert the needle at the base of the eyelashes, and pierce the needle with the thread that is above, and let the needle lie close to the eyelashes, that is, at the margin of the eyelid where the hairs grow: and draw the thread upwards with the eyelid, and tie the knot.
Deinde finde in interiori parte palpebrae sub pilis additis cum spatumili incidente a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus.	And find within the inner part of the eyelid under the added hair a mark that comes from the greater lachrymal gland down to the lesser lachrymal gland.
Deinde extrahe filum, et pone sub palpebra puluillum paruum ex cotto, aut panno: deinde signa super palpebram cum encaustro, quod sit sicut figura folii myrti.	Then draw out the thread and place under the eyelid a small piece of cotton wool or gauze: then close the eyelid with stitches that look like the figure of a myrtle leaf
Verumtamen oportet, ut fit figura secundum quantitatem et eleuationem palpebrae: quoniam iam diuersificatur illud in hominibus.	Indeed it is necessary to observe that the figure should be made according to the quantity and elevation of the eyelid: for this varies among people
Ex eis enim est, qui indiget ut incidatur ex palpebra quantitas magna, secundum quantitatem quae mollificatur a palpebra.	The eye is harmful if it requires more to be excised from the eyelid than is necessary for the amount that is softened by the eyelid.
Deinde cum spatumili finde super duas lineas quas signasti, et incipe a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus, et sit fissura una prope pilos naturales, sicut est grossitudo radii.	When the swelling has spread over two lines which you have signed, and you begin from the greater tear gland towards the lesser, let there be one opening near the natural hair, as is the thickness of a radius.
Deinde intromitte uncinum in uno duorum angulorum cutis.	Then introduce the hook into one of the two angles of the skin.
Deinde excoria ipsam totam.	Then scrape away the whole thing.
Deinde aggrega cum sutura duo labia, cum acu et filo lana subtili: et absterge sanguinem, et fac adhaerere quod superfluit ex filis super duo supercilia, cum quibusdam rebus inuiscantibus, si uis facere illud: et si non, non cures.	Then bring together with two sutures the two lips, with a needle and a fine thread: and stop the bleeding, and make fast what has been excised from the two superciliums, with some astringents if you wish to do so: or if not, do not cure it
Deinde dimitte suturam et fila usque ad tres dies, aut quatuor: postea cura illud.	Then remove the suture and the thread for three days, or four: then care for it.
Et si uis, dimitte uulnus absque sutura, et cura ipsum cum eo, quod exsiccat et constringit.	And if you wish, remove the swelling without sutures, and care for it as before, which dries up and contracts it
Nam palpebra eleuatur apud sigillationem uulneris et aggregationem eius: sed futura est melior.	For the eyelid is raised at the sealing of the wound and the adhesion: but the future will be better.
Hunc modum curandi Ataxmir docuerunt antiqui.	In this way of treating Ataxmir, the ancients taught.
Verumtamen in eo est sollicitudo super infirmum, et est ex bona operatione, et non est in eo timor.	It is true that there is anxiety over the infirm, but it is from a good operation, and not from fear
Et modus alius est in Ataxmir etiam: et est, ut signes super palpebram figuram, quae sit sicut figura folii myrti, sicut narrauimus.	And another way is in Ataxmir also: and it is that the sign on the eyelid should be like the figure of a myrtle leaf, as we have said.
Deinde eleua palpebram cum tribus uncinis separatis, aut aggregatis, secundum formam hanc quae sequitur, deinde incide quod superfluit cum forficibus paruis, secundum hanc formam, cum aequalitate incisionis.	Then lift the eyelid with three separate hooks, or gathered together, according to this figure, then cut away what is superfluous with small scissors, according to this figure, with equality of the incision.
Si autem non est tibi possibile tenere uncinum, et non aequatur illud: tunc accipe acum in qua sit filum, et intromitte ipsum in medio figurae: et intromitte filum aliud prope lachrymale maius, et filum secundum prope lachrymale minus: et aggrega inter digitos tuos fila cum aequalitate.	If, however, it is not possible to retain the hook and it does not suffice: then grasp the point where the thread is located and insert it into the middle of the figure. Insert another thread nearby the larger lacrimal gland and another nearby the smaller lacrimal gland. Gather the threads between your fingers with equality.
Deinde eleua manum tuam eleuatione aequali: et eleua cutem super quam est signatum cotum, sicut narrauimus.	Then elevate your hand with equal elevation: and elevate the skin above that which is signed with the mark of the pulse, as we have narrated.</start_of_turn>
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then gather together the two lips of the wound with the suture: and care for it until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Si uero accidat apostema apud incisionem tuam, aut fissuram tuam: seda illud apostema cum caeroto, et his similibus, ex unguentis sedantibus.	If, however, swelling occurs at the incision or the wound: hold that swelling with the thumb and index finger, and with like instruments from the stationary suture threads.</start_of_turn
Et quandoque accidit palpebrae etiam, ut conuertantur pili eius.	And when the eyelashes also swell, as they are twisted about their hair.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo ut utaris in ea quod diximus in incisione: sed sutura utrisque magis est artificialis.	It is therefore necessary to use what we have said concerning the incision: but the sutures on both sides are artificial.</start_of_turn>
¶ De cura Ataxmir cum cannis.	Concerning the care of wounds made with canines.</start_of_turn
ET Est, ut conuertas palpebram, et scindas fissuram quae est deintus, secundum quod narraui.	That you must cover the eyelash, and split the wound which is inside, as I have narrated.</start_of_turn
Deinde arte fac duas cannas, aut duo ligna subtilia: quarum longitudo sit secundum longitudinem palpebrae, et latitudo earum sit minor latitudine spatumilis: et tu iam incidisti in extremitatibus utriusque ab utrisque partibus ubi tenes fila.	Then make two needles, or two thin sticks: whose length is according to the length of the eyelash, and the width of them is less than the width of the pupil: and you will have pierced at the extremities from both sides where you hold the thread.</start_of_turn
Deinde aggrega utramque cum subtilitate super illud quod superfluit ex palpebra oculi, et stringe duas cannas ab utrisque partibus strictura forti, et dimitte eam diebus aliquot.	Then gather together both things with a slight pull over that which is superfluous from the edge of the eye, and bind two needles from both sides tightly, and let go of them every few days.</start_of_turn
Cutis enim stricta morietur, et denigrabitur, et putrefiet, donec cadet per se.	The skin, if tightly closed, will die, darken, and decay until it falls away of itself.
Si ergo tardatur, tunc incide eam cum forficibus.	If delayed, then cut it through with forceps.</start_of_turn>
Deinde cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.</start_of_turn>
Cum ergo consolidatur, eleuatur palpebra: et non pungunt pili.	When it has consolidated, raise the eyelid: do not pierce the hair.</start_of_turn>
Et haec est forma duarum cannarum, quas facies secundum hanc figuram, et quantitatem in longitudinem et latitudinem.	And this is the shape of two needles, which you make according to this figure and the quantity in length and breadth.</start_of_turn>
¶ De eleuatione pilorum pungentium in oculo cum acu.	Regarding the elevation of the plucked hair in the eye with a needle.</start_of_turn
Caput XII.	Chapter XII.</start_of_turn
Operatio in illo est, ut accipias acum subtilem, et intromittas in eam filum ex serico subtile, lene.	The operation in this is that you take a fine needle and introduce it under the thread of fine silk, which is soft.</start_of_turn
Deinde aggreges extremitates eius, et nodes utramque nodo subtili ualde: et sit longitudo filorum palmus unus.	Then you gather the extremities of it and knot both ends with a fine knot: and let the length of the thread be one palm.</start_of_turn
Deinde compone in Alinxotati filum aliud subtile sub eo in breui, et noda extremitates eius si uis.	Then make a second knot of fine thread under this one in a short space, and knot the extremities of it if you wish.</start_of_turn
Deinde ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo, et sit prope solem ut declaretur operatio: quoniam est operatio subtilis, uel minuta.	Then place the patient's head in your lap, and let it be close to the cheek so that the operation is declared: because the operation is slight, or even a moment.</start_of_turn
Deinde intromitte acum cum alinxotati in radicem palpebrae, et fac eam penetrare in palpebram festinanter, donec extrahas eam desuper pilum naturalem.	Then introduce the needle with the knot in the root of the eyelid, and make it penetrate the eyelid quickly, until you have pulled out the natural hair.</start_of_turn
Deinde trahe pilum usque supra alinxotati: et intromitte in alinxotati illum pilum: si est unus, aut duo, aut tres, non plures.	Then pull out the hair until above the knot: and introduce into the knot the light of the hair: if there is one, or two, or three, not more.</start_of_turn
Deinde trahe manum tuam cum eo, donec egrediatur pilus cum alinxotati in palpebra cum pilo naturali.	Then draw your hand with that [finger] which will cause the hair to emerge with the natural hair on the eyelashes.
Si autem trahatur alinxotati, et non egrediatur pilus cum ea: trahes alinxotati ad inferiora, cum filo quod tu composuisti in ea, donec egrediatur alinxotati ex foramine superiori, et uideas eam uisione oculi: tunc enim trahes alinxotati, et filum: et extrahe utraque, et claude oculum: et dimitte ipsum clausum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec adhaereat pilus loco suo, et nascatur super ipsum caro.	Then draw the [finger] which will cause the eyelashes to emerge with the natural hair on the eyelashes. If, however, the eyelashes are drawn out and do not emerge with the latter: draw the eyelashes downwards, with the thread which you have made in them, until the eyelashes emerge from the upper orifice and are visible: then draw out both the eyelashes and the thread and close the eye. Close the eye for two or three days until the hair has adhered to its place and has grown over the wound.
Quod si pilus est breuis, tunc aut associa ei pilum longum ex pilis naturalibus, et eleuatur cum eo: aut dimitte ipsum, donec elongetur post spacium, et tunc eleua ipsum.	If the hair is short, then either associate it with a long hair from the natural hair and elevate it with that: or leave it alone until it has grown out, and then elevate it.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae accidit in palpebra superiori.	Concerning the care of the eyelashes which occur in the upper eyelid.
Caput XIII.	Chapter XIII.
Quando accidit oculo haec Alxatrati, nominatur Leporina.	When this occurs in the eye, it is called the Leporina
Et haec Alxatrati est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	This eyelash is either natural or accidental
Accidentalis ergo fit ex consolidatione uulneris, aut sectionis, aut cauterii, et similium illis.	Accidental, therefore, is caused by the consolidation of a wound, or a section, or a burn, and the like of these
Et modus operationis in ea est, ut tu findas illam consolidationem, et ut separes labia eius, et ponas in eo quod est inter ea licinium ex lino, et liges eam, donec sanetur.	The way to operate in this case is to find the consolidation of this and to separate its lips, and to put between them a piece of silk, and to tie them together, until it is healed
Et non oportet, ut utaris in curatione eius rebus quae exiccant et constringunt: nam si tu facis illud, redit Alxatrati deterior quam fuit: imo utere in ea rebus quae mollificant, sicut foenumgraecum: et embroca cum aqua, in qua cocta sit althea, semen lini: et unguento dyaquilon, quod liquefactum sit cum aliquo ex oleis: et inuolue cum eo licinium, et cura cum eo.	It is not fitting, however, to use those things which dry and constrict: for if you do, the eyelash will be worse than before: rather use those things which soften, such as barley-straw: and mix with water, in which barley-meal is boiled, and oil: and smear with this the thread, and care with this
Et thesaurus curationis tuae est, ut coneris omni ingenio, ut non consolidetur, secundum formam quae fuit in primis.	Your surgical skill is such, that you can deal with every ingenuity, so that it does not waver, following the fashion which was first established.
Et haec quidem operatio quam diximus, non est nisi quaedam rectificatio Alxatrati, ut non redeat forma loci secundum quod fuit omnino.	This operation, as we have mentioned, is not without some rectification of Alxatrati, so that it does not deviate from its natural form altogether
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae fit in palpebra inferiori, et est rugatio uel contractio sursum ad dextrum et sinistrum.	Concerning the care of the eye which is in the lower eyelid, and that is the wrinkle or contraction above towards the right and left.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter 123.
Haec Alxatrati quae fit inferius, est quae uere nominatur Alxatrati.	This lower eye-lid swelling is called Alxatrati in truth.
Et est naturalis, et est accidentalis.	And it is natural, and is accidental.
Et accidentalis fit ex uulnere, aut fissura, aut cauterio, et illis similibus.	It is caused by a wound, or tear, or burn, or similar things.
Et uia operationis in ea est, ut accipias acum, in qua sit filum duplum, et tingas eam in carnem, et facias eam penetrare a lachrymali sinistro usque ad lachrymale dextrum, donec perueniat filum in duabus extremitatibus carnis.	As for the operation in this, you take a needle which has a double thread, and pass the needle through the flesh from the left lacrimal gland to the right one, until the thread passes through both ends of the flesh
Deinde extende carnem ad superiora cum acu, et incide eam cum spatumili lato.	Then stretch the flesh upwards with the needle, and cut the flesh with a wide blade.
Si ergo redit figura palpebrae secundum quod oportet, est bonum.	If the figure of the eye-lid returns to its natural form, it is good
Et si non, accipe radium, et pone ipsum in fissuram, et conuerte cum eo palpebram: et finde duas fissuras in latere interiore palpebrae, et sint extremitates duarum fissurarum ex duobus angulis incisionis, donec concurrant et fiat ex eis angulus: donec quando aggregantur fiat figura earum haec figura, et est litera lauda graeca.	If not, grasp the edge, and place it in the split, and join it to the eyelid: and find two holes at the inner angle of the eye-lid, and let the two ends of the holes be from two angles, until they converge and make an angle: until when they converge the figure of them both is like that of the Greek laudation letter
Deinde aufer illam carnem per quantitatem, quod est latus eius acutum inferius, ab eo quod sequitur palpebram.	Then remove that part of the flesh which is beyond the acute angle of the lower eyelid from the eye-lid which follows the eye-lid
Deinde aggrega partes separatas: sue eam cum filo lanae.	Then gather the separated parts: sow them with a thread of wool.
Deinde cura eas cum eo quod diximus, de medicinis mollificantibus, et liciniis, donec sanentur.	Then take care of them as we have said, of the physicians of soothing medicine, and of licenses, until they are healed.
Et si Alxatrati accidat ex fissura, et sutura, aut cauterio: tunc oportet ut findas fissura plana sub pilis palpebrarum, etiam secundum quod praecessit.	And if the Alexatrati occurs from a wound and suture, or cautery: then it is necessary that you find the wound even under the eyelashes, even as before
Deinde separa inter duo labia cum licinio, secundum quod diximus.	Then separate between two lips with a license, as we have said
Et summa sermonis de cura Alxatrati, quando est desuper, aut inferius, est, ut currat in ea operatio, secundum quod praeparatur ex forma Alxatrati.	And the sum of the sermon concerning the care of the Alexatrati, when it is above or below, is that you should take care of it in that operation, as it is prepared from the form of the Alexatrati.
