Postea fige in eis acum in qua sit filum duplum, et liga ipsum in primo locorum quibus accidunt Vites: et liga ipsum iterum in ultimo eorum.	And then fix it in wax in which there is a double thread, and bind it in the first place where it occurs with the veins: and bind it again in the last of them.
Deinde seca ea in media sectione recta secundum longitudinem corporis, et extrahe quod aggregatur ex humiditatibus faeculentis corruptis.	And then dry them in the middle of a straight section according to the length of the body, and extract what is gathered from the humours of corrupt faeces.
Deinde cura uulnus cum curatione reliquorum uulnerum, in quibus uis generari saniem, ut cadant uasa quae nutriunt unum testiculorum.	Then care for one wound with the care of the rest of the wounds, in which you wish to generate health, so that the masses that nourish one testicle fall down.
Non est enim malum per illud.	Then care for one wound with the care of the rest of the wounds, in which you wish to generate health, so that the masses that nourish one testicle fall down. There is no evil in this.
Si autem accidat Vitis omnibus uasis, tunc oportet ut extrahantur propter hoc testiculi cum uasis: ut non priuetur ouum nutrimento, propter incisionem, et tabescat, uel arescat, et non sit iuuamentum cum eis.	If, however, the veins of all the masses go together, then it is necessary to remove the testicles along with the masses: so that they do not receive nourishment through incision, and that they may rot or decay, and not be of any use.
¶ De cura Ramicis intestinalis.	Of the care of the intestinal branches.
Caput LXV.	Chapter 15
Euentus huius Ramicis est ex sectione, quae accidit in sifach extenso super uentrem in parte inguinum ex mirach uentris.	The event of this branch is from a section which happens in the large intestine above the belly in the groin part from the wonders of the belly
Quare descendunt intestina ex illa Ruptura ad unum testiculorum.	Why do the intestines descend from that rupture to one testicle?
Et haec Ruptura est aut ex sifach, aut extensione eius.	And this rupture is either from the siphoning or from the extension of it
Et accidunt istae duae species ex caussis multis: aut ex percussione, aut saltu, aut clamore, aut eleuatione rei grauis, et similibus.	And these two kinds of rupture happen from many causes: either from a blow, or a jump, or a shout, or elevation of a heavy thing, and the like.
Et signum, quando est ex extensione sifach.	And the sign that it is from the extension of the siphoning.
Est quod accidit paulatim in tempore longo, et non accidit subito: et est apostema aequale uersus profundum: propterea, quod sifach comprimit intestinum.	Is that which happens gradually in a long time, and does not happen immediately: and it is equal to the depth of the apostema: because the siphoning compresses the intestine
Et signum eius quando est ex sectione sifach, quia facit accidere ex principio sui dolorem uehementem subito: et est apostema diuersum, apparens sub cute propinque: et illud est propter exitum intestini, et cursus eius ad exteriora sifach.	And the sign of that is when it is from the section of the siphoning, because it makes the pain that is from the beginning to appear immediately: and it is a different apostema, appearing under the skin nearby: and that is because of the exit of the intestine, and the course of it to the outside of the siphoning
Et quandoque egreditur cum intestino zirbum: et nominatur haec Ramex intestinalis, et zirbia: et quandoque fit cum uentositate.	When the gut comes out with the intestines: it is called a ramex of the intestines, and the intestines. And when it is with swelling.
Et quandoque currit in intestinum stercus, et retinetur illic: et est cum eo pernicies infirmi: quoniam facit accidere dolorem prauum, et praecipue quando premitur.	When stool runs into the intestine and is retained there: it is with it a cause of sickness. For it makes the abdomen swell and especially when it is discharged.
Et in curatione specierum aegritudinis huius cum ferro est timor: quare oportet ut caueatur casus in ea.	And in the treatment of this disease of the intestines with iron there is fear: so one must be cautious of the cause of it.
Et modus operationis est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut reducat intestinum manu sua ad interiora concauitatis suae, si obedit reditui.	The method of treatment is to remove the major parts of the illness from the patient, so that the intestine may return to its natural place within the cavity of the abdomen if it obeys the return.
Deinde resupinetur super collum suum inter manus tuas: et eleua crura eius.	Then it is placed over the collar of its column between your hands: and lift its edges.
Deinde extende cutem quae sequitur cutem ad superiora, et seca cutem testiculorum totam per longitudinem.	Then stretch the skin which follows the skin upwards, and dry the whole surface of the testicles.
Deinde fige in duobus labiis sectionis uncinos, secundum quod indiges ad aperiendum sectionem cum eis: et sectio sit secundum quantitatem, quod sit possibile, ut egrediatur ex ea ouum.	Then fix in two hooks of section the intestines, according to what is necessary to open the section with the intestines: and the section should be made according to the quantity, as much as is possible, so that it may come out of it something.
Deinde excoria siphak, et quae sunt sub cute testiculorum, donec quando detegitur sifach album, durum ab omni parte: tunc intromitte digitum tuum indicem in eo quod sequitur testiculum, in eo quod est inter siphach album, quod est sub cute oui, et inter sifach secundum, et absolue cum eo adhaerentiam quae est in posteriori parte oui.	Then peel the fatty substance and what is under the skin of the testicles, until the white fat is detected, hard from all parts: then insert your finger into the index of that which follows the testicle, in that which is between the white fat and the fat under the skin, and between the fat of the following part and that which is alongside it at the back of the testicle
Deinde moue cum manu dextra ad interiora cutem testiculorum: et cum hoc extende sifach album ad sursum, cum manu sinistra: et eleua ouum cum sifach ad partem sectionis: et praecipe ministro, ut extendat ouum ad sursum: et tu solue adhaerentiam, quae est retro solutione completa.	Then move with the right hand the hand towards the inside of the skin of the testicles: and with this extend the white fat upwards, with the left hand: and lift the intestines with the fat towards the part of the section: and command the minister to extend the intestines upwards: and you will solve the adhesion which is at the back of the complete solution.
Et quaere digitis tuis, ut non sit aliquid illic ex intestino inuoluto in sifach albo duro.	And inquire about your fingers, that nothing is there from the intestines thrust into the flesh or hardened.
Si autem inuenis ex eo aliquid: tunc impelle ipsum ad uentrem inferius.	If, however, you find anything there: then push it down to the lower abdomen.
Deinde accipe acum, in qua sit filum grossum, factum licinium ex decem filis: et intromitte ipsam apud postremum sifach, id est, tunicae, quod est sub cute testiculorum quae sequitur sectionem: deinde incide extremitates quae eminent ex filo, donec sint quatuor fila.	Then grasp the needle, which has a thick thread made of ten threads: and insert it through the back of the flesh, that is, under the testicles which follow the incision: and cut off the ends which protrude from the thread until there are four threads left.
Deinde compone quaedam eorum super quaedam cum figura quae sit in modo crucis: et liga cum eis alsifach, de quo diximus, quia est sub cute testiculorum ligamento uehementi, donec non possit aliquod ex uasis, quae nutriunt eos mittere ad eos aliquid: ut non accidat inde apostema calidum.	Then make a loop with some of the thread over some other part with a shape like a cross: and tie it with a slip knot, as we have said, because it is under the testicles a ligature which should not hold anything which nourishes them from sending anything to them: so that it does not happen that the wound becomes cold again
Et pone iterum ligamentum secundum extra ligamentum primum, longinquum ab eo minus duobus digitis.	And make another knot outside the first knot, which is longer than the two fingers less two.
Et post ista duo ligamenta dimitte ex sifach, quod est sub cute testiculorum, quantitatem magnitudinis digiti: et incide reliquum totum secundum rotunditatem, et aufer ex eo ouum.	And after these two knots draw out the rest of the flesh from the flesh under the testicles as much as the quantity of the finger: and cut off the rest entirely following the roundness, and remove from it all the fat
Deinde seca in inferiori parte cutis testiculorum sectione, ex qua currit sanguis, et sanies: sicut narrauimus in eo quod praemissum est.	Then dry the lower part of the skin of the testicles which has been cut, from which blood runs, and heal: as we have said before
Deinde administra lanam submersam in oleo, et pone in uulnus: et administra ligamentum quod narrauimus.	Then apply soaked wool in oil, and put on a bandage: and administer the knot which we have mentioned.
Et quandoque cauterizatur sifach album quod diximus, post incisionem eius timendo de fluxu sanguinis.	And when the white gut which we mentioned has been cauterized after the incision, fearing the flow of blood.
Multotiens enim accidit illud.	Very often this happens.
Et dimitte ligamentum, donec cadat per se.	And draw out the knot, until it comes down by itself.
Si autem tardatur casus eius, tunc embrocetur cum aqua calida: et pone super ipsum illud quod diximus, donec cadat.	If, however, the case lingers, then it is embroidered with warm water: and place above that which we have mentioned until it falls.
Deinde cura uulnus cum reliqua curatione uulnerum, donec curetur.	And then care for the wound with the rest of the treatment for wounds until it heals.
¶ De Ramice uentosa.	Of a wound that is oozing.
Caput LXVI.	Chapter 66.
IN Hac Ramice non uidi aliquem qui ausus fuerit super curationem eius cum ferro.	In this wound no one should be allowed to remain above its treatment with iron
Et primi quidem dixerunt, quod fit sicut narrauimus in Ramice quae est cum Vite.	And first they say that it is like that which we have told in the wound which is like that of Vite.
Quod est, ut liges uasa post sectionem super ea cum facilitate inferius: deinde seca in medio, et cura postremo cum eo quod aperit ipsum, donec cadant uasa: et cura uulnus, secundum quod diximus, donec sanetur.	That is, as a belt after a section above that with ease below: then dry in the middle, and care afterwards with that which opens it up until it falls off: and care for the wound, as we have mentioned, until it heals
¶ De disruptione quae fit in inguinibus.	Of the disruption that is in the groin
Caput LXVII.	Chapter 67
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, sicut diximus, et eminet locus, et non descendit ad testiculos aliquid ex intestinis: et si descendit, est illud parum, et redit in omnibus horis: uerum si prolongatur cum ea tempus, additur fissura in sifach, donec descendunt intestina in sifach.	When it happens that there is a rupture in the groin, as we have mentioned, and the place is prominent, and does not descend to the testicles anything from the intestines: and if it descends, it is little, and returns in every hour: but if it is prolonged with that time, a tear is added in the groin, until the intestines descend into the groin
Et accidit illud ex extensione sifach, quod est in inguinibus, sicut diximus.	And this happens from the extension of the groin, which is in the groin as we have mentioned
Quod est, quia extenditur sifach: deinde mollificatur, et apostematur locus, et eminet.	That is, because the groin is extended: then it becomes softened, and the place is prominent, and it descends.
Et cura eius est cum cauterio, sicut praecessit eius narratio.	And its care is with cautery, as it has been mentioned before
Et quandoque curatur cum ferro, secundum hunc modum: et est, ut iaceat infirmus super dorsum suum inter manus tuas.	And when it is cured with iron, according to this manner: and the patient lies on his back between your hands
Deinde seca locum Rupturae apostematum et eminentem, sectione per latitudinem, secundum quantitatem trium digitorum.	Then dry the place of the rupture above the apostem and eminens, section through the breadth, according to the quantity of three fingers.
Deinde stringe alsifak et, quae sunt sub cute, donec quando detegitur sifach album, quod est sub cute quae sequitur ipsum.	Then tighten the ligature and what is under the skin until the white substance is detected, which is under the skin following the latter.
Tunc accipe radium, et pone ipsum super locum eminentem ex sifach, et preme ipsum ad profundum uentris.	Then take the needle and place it over the eminens from the substance, and press it down into the depth of the belly
Deinde sue duo loca eminentia super extremitatem radii ex sifach, et annecte cum sutura unum eorum cum altero: deinde extrahe extremitatem radii.	Then take two points of the eminences from the edge of the substance and join them with a suture: then draw out the edge of the substance.
Et non incidas alsifach omnino, neque tendas ouum, neque aliud, sicut feci te scire in curatione ramicis intestinalis.	And do not cut through the substance entirely, neither tighten anything, nor do anything else, as I told you in the treatment of intestinal branches.
Deinde cura illud curatione uulnerum.	Then care for the wound.
Cum ergo incidis fila, mundifica illud, et restaura uulnus, donec consolidetur.	When you have finished cutting the thread, close the wound and restore the skin, until it has healed together
Sisach enim contrahitur, et non additur eminentia Rupturae.	Do not draw the skin too tightly, and do not add to the thickness of the rupture
Et cauterium est melius in hoc loco: quoniam est propinquius ad salutem.	And the cautery is better in this place: because it is closer to the substance.
¶ De mollificatione cutis testiculorum.	Regarding the softening of the skin of the testicles.
Caput LXVIII.	Chapter LXVIII.
Multotiens mollificatur cutis testiculorum in quibusdam hominibus, propter quod mollificantur carnes quae sunt inter ea, et foedatur aspectus eius.	Many people soften the skin of the testicles because in some of them the meats which are between them are softened, and the sight is spoiled thereby.
Ergo necesse est ei qui rogatur in curatione eius, ut faciat iacere infirmum super dorsum suum, et incidat totam cutem quae mollificata est super cutem naturalem.	Therefore it is necessary for him who is treating him to make him urinate on his back, and to cut away the softened skin over the natural skin.
Deinde aggreget duo labia cum sutura: et si uis, sue in primis superfluitatem cutis mollificatae tribus suturis, aut quatuor, et firma suturam.	Then join together two lips with a suture: and if you wish, take away the excess of softened skin with three or four sutures, and tighten the suture
Deinde incide inter sututuras.	Then penetrate between the sutures.
Deinde cura curatione reliquorum uulnerum, usquequo sanetur, et cadant fila.	Then care for the remaining wounds until they are healed, and the sutures fall out.
¶ De Castratione.	¶ Of Castration.
Caput LXIX.	Chapter LXIX.</start_of_turn>
Scias, quod Castratio in lege nostra excommunicata est: et propter illud liceret mihi, ut non rememorarer eius in libro meo isto: et non est necessaria rememoratio eius, nisi propter duos modos.	You know that castration is prohibited in our law: and because of this I am forbidden to recall it in this book: and it is not necessary to recall it, except for two cases.</start_of_turn
Quorum unus est, ut sit illud in scientia medici quando interrogatur de ea: et ut sciat curationem eius cui accidit.	Of which one is that it is in the science of medicine when it is asked about: and to know its treatment when it happens.</start_of_turn
Et modus alter est, quod nos multotiens indigemus castratione quorundam animalium, propter iuuamenta nostra per illud, sicut arietum, hyrcorum, et gattorum, et similium ex animalibus.	And the other is that we often do not approve of castration for some animals, because of the groans we suffer on account of it, such as oxen, asses, and goats, and similar animals.</start_of_turn
Dico ergo, quod Castratio fit secundum duos modos.	I say therefore, that castration is done in two ways.</start_of_turn
Aut per attritionem.	Or by cutting.</start_of_turn
Aut per fissuram, et sectionem.	Or by incision, and section.</start_of_turn>
In illa autem quae fit per attritionem, uia operationis est: quod nos faciamus sedere animal in aqua calida, donec mollificentur testiculi eius, et leniantur, et pendeant: deinde attere eos manu tua, donec resoluantur et non appareant sub tactu.	In the former of these, the operation is painful: for we make the animal sit in warm water, until the testicles soften, and become limp, and hang down: and then cut through them with your hand, until they are dissolved and do not appear to the touch.</start_of_turn
In castratione autem per fissuram et sectionem, oportet ut teneas animal, et premas cutem testiculorum eius cum manu sinistra.	In castration by incision and section, it is necessary to hold the animal firmly, and grasp the skin of the testicles with your left hand.</start_of_turn
Deinde liga suspensorium, et seca super omne ouum sectione una, donec quando procedunt duo oua: tunc incide ea postquam excoriaueris utrumque, et non dimittas super ea ex sifaket aliquid praeter sifac subtile, quod est super uasa.	Then tie up the suspension, and dry over every wound a single stitch, until when two holes have come out: then cut through them after you have scraped away everything outside the delicate sac, which is over the testicles.</start_of_turn
Et iste modus castrationis est melior eo qui fit per attritonem: quoniam attritio fortasse relinquit aliquid ex testiculis, quare desiderat animal coitum.	And thus is the best method of castration by attrition: for attrition often leaves something from the testicles, which the beast desires for coition.
Deinde cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	Then care for the wound until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
¶ De cura Hermafroditae duorum modorum.	There are two methods of care for hermaphrodites.</start_of_turn>
Caput LXX.	Chapter 70.</start_of_turn
Hermafrodita ex uiris est secundum duos modos.	A hermaphrodite is one of two kinds, from the urine.</start_of_turn
Vnus eorum est, quia apparet in eo quod sequitur spacium, aut in cute testiculorum, in eo quod est inter duos testiculos, figura quasi uulua mulieris, in qua sunt pili: et quandoque currit urina ex eo quod est in cute testiculorum.	One of them appears because it follows the space, or in the belly between the testicles, like a female dog, in which are hairs, and sometimes urine comes from the belly between the testicles.</start_of_turn
In mulieribus autem est species una, et est uulua mulieris super pectinem sicut testiculi uiri parui omnino, eminentes ad exteriora: quorum unus est sicut priapus uiri, et duo sicut duo testiculi.	In women, however, there is one kind, which is like a female dog over the belly just like small testicles of a man, projecting outwards: one is like the penis of a man, and two like two testicles.</start_of_turn
Et curatio trium specierum, duarum ex uiris, et speciei unius ex mulieribus, est: quia oportet ut incidas carnes additas, donec effugiat impressio earum.	And the care of the three kinds, of the two from the urine and the one from the woman, is that you must cut away the meats added, until the impression of them is gone.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura eas curatione reliquorum uulnerum.	Then care for the rest of the wounds.</start_of_turn
In specie autem secunda uirorum, ex qua egreditur urina, quae est in cute testiculorum, non est operatio, neque est eius curatio omnino.	As for the second kind, which is that from which urine comes out, which is in the belly of the testicles, there is no operation, nor any care for it.</start_of_turn
¶ De incisione Tentiginis, et carnis eminentis in uuluis mulierum.	Of the incision of the hair, and the meat which projects outwards in the bodies of women.</start_of_turn
Caput LXXI.	Chapter 71.</start_of_turn
Tentigo fortasse additur super rem naturalem, donec foedatur et turpis fit aspectus eius: et quandoque magnificatur in quibusdam mulieribus adeo, donec expanditur sicut in uiris, et peruenit usque ad coitum.	The hair perhaps adds to the natural thing, until it is fed and becomes ugly: and sometimes it becomes big in some women so that it expands like in the urine, and continues until coition.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo ut teneas superfluitatem Tentiginis manu, aut cum uncino, et incidas: et non ultimes in incisione, praecipue in profundo radicis: ut non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	It is necessary therefore that you should take hold of the superabundance of the Tentiginis mane, either alone or with one finger, and cut: and do not delay in the incision, especially at the root: lest there should occur a flow of blood.
Deinde cura ipsam curatione uulnerum, donec sanetur.	Then care for the wound itself until it has healed.</start_of_turn>
Caro autem orta, est caro quae nascitur in orificio matricis, donec impleat ipsum: et fortasse egreditur ad exteriora secundum similitudinem caudae: et propter illud quidam primi nominant aegritudinem caudatam.	However, the flesh which is born in the belly orifice, until it has filled itself up: and perhaps it comes out to the outside according to the shape of a tail: and for this reason it is called a tail-like wound.</start_of_turn>
Oportet ergo ut incidamus eam sicut incidimus Tentiginem, et curemus eam, donec sanetur.	It is necessary therefore that we should cut in the same way as we cut the Tentiginis, and care for it, until it has healed.</start_of_turn>
¶ De cura Alratica, quae est uulua mulieris non perforata.	As for the care of the Alratica, which is the unpierced woman's wound.</start_of_turn
Caput LXXII.	Chapter 72.</start_of_turn>
Alratica est, ut sit uulua mulieris non perforata, aut sit foramen paruum.	The Alratica is, as it is the unpierced woman's wound, or as it is a small hole.</start_of_turn
Et est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	It is either natural or accidental.</start_of_turn
Accidentalis est ex aegritudine quae praecessit: et ipsa quidem fit aut ex carne nata addita, aut sifach subtili, aut spisso: et fit aut in profundo matricis, aut in lateribus eius, aut in superiore ipsius, aut inferiori eius: et prohibet a coitu et impregnatione, et partu, et fortasse prohibet menstrua.	Accidental is from a wound which preceded it: and it is either from a piece of meat which has become added, or from fine sand, or from fat: and it may be either in the belly, or in the flanks, or in the upper part of it, or in the lower part of it: and it hinders coition and conception, and delivery, and perhaps hinders menstruation.</start_of_turn
Et cognitio illius fit per aspectum obstetricis, si opilatio est apparens propinqua.	And the knowledge of it is by the aspect of the obstetrician, if the visible swelling is close at hand.</start_of_turn
Si autem non est apparens, tunc quaere eam digitis tuis, aut cum radio.	If however it is not apparent, then inquire about it with your fingers, or with an instrument.</start_of_turn
Si autem opilatio est ex sifach subtili, et est propinqua duobus labiis: tunc propera, et disrumpe ipsam.	If, however, the swelling is from a soft discharge close to the bone, then it is necessary to drain it, and break it.
Et est, ut ponas super duo labia puluillos.	And it is necessary to place two fingers over the lips [of the wound].
Deinde pone indices tuos duarum manuum simul, et mulier sit super dorsum suum expansis cruribus suis.	Then place your two fingers of both hands together, and a woman should be placed above his back with her knees spread wide.
Deinde extende duo labia cum fortitudine, donec disrumpatur sifach subtile, et aperiatur opilatio.	Then stretch out the two lips with force, until the soft discharge is broken and the swelling is opened.
Deinde accipe lanam, et imbibe eam in oleo, et pone ipsam super locum: et coeat mulier omni die, ut non consolidetur locus uice alia.	Then take a piece of wool and soak it in oil, and put it on the place: and the woman should keep it moist every day, so that it does not harden in another place.
Si autem sifach est grossum, spissum: tunc oportet ut seces ipsum cum spatumili lato simili folio myrti.	If, however, the discharge is thick and large: then it is necessary to cut it out with a sponge-like bandage similar to the bark of myrtus
Si autem opilatio est ex carne nata, tunc suspende eam cum uncinis, et incide eam: et sint tecum medicinae quae fluxum sedant sanguinis absque mordicatione, sicut acacia, et sanguis draconis, et thus aggregatum cum albugine oui.	If, however, the swelling is from natural tissue, then suspend the discharge with hooks, and cut it out: and there should be with you physicians who stop the flow of blood without biting, such as acacia, and the blood of a dragon, and thus gathered with alum or something like that.
Deinde administra cannulam ex plumbo amplam, ut non consolidetur uulnus uelociter, teneat eam diebus aliquot: et administra licinium ex lino sicco, deinde curetur reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then give a wide lead from lead, so that the wound does not harden too quickly, keep it for a few days: and give an ointment of dry linen, and then care for the rest of the cure, until it is healed.
Et quandoque nasciur in matrice natiuitas carnium aliarum: oportet ergo ut incidantur secundum hunc modum: dum non est apostema cancerosum apostemati enim canceroso quod est in matrice, non fiat contrarietas cum ferro omnino.	And when there is birth in the matrix of other tissues: it is necessary to do this in this way: while not there is a cancerous tumor in the matrix, do not do anything contrary to iron in any way
¶ De cura hemorroidarum, Athehelil, et Bothor rubeae in uuluis mulierum.	Concerning the care of hemorrhoids, Athehelil, and Bothor of the red in women's ulcers.
Caput LXXIII.	Chapter 73.
Hemorroides quidem sunt apertio orificiorum uenarum, donec currit ex eis sanguis multus assidue.	Hemorrhoids are open ulcers of the veins, until blood flows excessively from them.
Cum ergo antiquantur hemorroides, fiunt thelil: et iam dixi in diuisione species earum, et signa ipsarum: et dicam hic quae ex eis recipiunt curationem, et quae non.	When they are thus diminished, hemorrhoids become small: and I have already spoken of the signs of these, and of the things which aid their treatment and those which do not
Dico ergo, quod hemorroides quae sunt in orificio matricis, et non apparent sensui: tunc non est ei curatio cum ferro.	I say, therefore, that hemorrhoids which are in the belly-button and are not visible to the eye: in such cases there is no cure with iron
Quae autem ex eis sunt in orificio matricis super quas cadit sensus, sunt quae curantur.	Those which are in the belly-button above which sense has fallen are those which are cured
Oportet ergo ut intromittas mulierem in domum frigidam.	It is necessary therefore to put the woman in a cold house.
Deinde extende athehelil cum forficibus, aut cum panno aspero, et incide eas ex radicibus suis.	Then extend the little things with forceps, or with rough cloth, and cut away their roots.
Deinde pulueriza super eas apud fluxum sanguinis ex uno puluerum incisiuorum absque mordificatione: sicut acacia, et sanguis draconis, et thus, et similia eis.	Then powder over the wounds with powder from one of the incisions without causing pain: as acacia, and dragon's blood, and thus, and similar things.
Deinde impellat pedes eius ad parietem hora una.	Then put her feet against the wall for an hour.
Postea depone eam in aquam frigidam.	Then put her in cold water afterwards
Quod si perseuerat fluxus sanguinis: tunc fac eam sedere in decoctione sumach, et corticum granatorum, et gallarum, et similium.	If the bleeding persists: then make her sit in a decoction of rue, and nutmeg seeds, and barley, and similar things.
Deinde accipe farinam hordei, et confice eam cum melle et aceto, et fac emplastrum cum eo super dorsum eius.	Then take barley flour, and mix it with honey and vinegar, and make a plaster with it on her back
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis cum eo, bonum est: et si non, fac adhaerere dorso uentosas, et mammillis, absque scarificatione.	If blood is thus separated with it, that is good: and if not, make the swelling adhere to the back, and swellings, without cutting
Deinde accipe lanam, et submerge in succo tarathit, aut succo arnoglossae, aut succo ramorum alaulat, id est, aglanter, uino pontico, et fac adhaerere loeo.	Then take wool, and soak it in pitch juice, or in rue juice, or in pomegranate juice, that is, aloe, port wine, and make it adhere to the wound
Cum ergo quiescit apostema, tunc cura locum cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	When the limb is quiet, then care for the place with unguents until it is healed.
Albarth uero rubeum est simile capitibus alhaasse, et est asperi aspectus.	When the limb is quiet, then care for the place with unguents until it is healed.
Oportet ergo ut incidas quod apparet ex eo, secundum quod dixi in thelil aequaliter: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	It is necessary therefore that you cut away whatever appears from it, as I have said before, and care for it, until it is healed.
¶ De perforatione Exiturae quae accidit in matrice.	Concerning the perforation which occurs in the matrix.
Caput LXXIIII.	Chapter 74.
Accidunt in matrice species multae apostematum, sicut cancer, et apostema lapideum, et ulcera, et adubelati, et alekilati, id est, herpes, aestiomemus, et fistulae, et hemorroides, et ragadiae, et thelil, et apostema calidum.	Many kinds of swellings occur in the matrix, such as cancer, and a stone abscess, and ulcer, and foreign bodies, and carbuncles, and herpes, and tumours, and fistulas, and haemorrhoids, and thread-like swellings, and cold abscesses
Et ego quidem iam dixi omnes has aegritudines et species earum, et signa ipsarum, et earum curationes in diuisione: necesse est ut dicam in hoc tractatu apostema calidum quod accidit in matrice, quando est ex apostematibus quae colligunt saniem, et uis scire qualiter fit eius apertio cum ferro.	And I will say concerning all these ailments and their species, their signs and their cures in general: it is necessary to say in this treatise the cold abscess which occurs in the matrix, when it is caused by other swellings which unite health, and to write how its opening is made with an iron
Oportet ergo ut consideres.	It is necessary therefore to consider it
Tunc si dolor apostematis in incaeptione sua est acutus cum percussione sua, et flamma, et febre: et uides ipsum rubere: si cadit super ipsum sensus, tunc non properes cum perforatione eius: et cura ipsum cum eo eo quod iuuat super maturationem, donec quando quiescat acuitas accidentium.	When the pain of the swelling in its beginning is acute with percussion, and inflammation, and fever: and you see it turning red: if it falls beyond the sensation of it, then do not attempt to perforate it: care for it with that which will promote its healing, until the acute pain of the accident has ceased
Tunc oportet ut facias sedere mulierem super sedem quae labeat duo sedilia, et reclinetur, uel appodietur super dorsum suum, et aggreget pedes suos ad partem inferiorem uentris: et sint coxae eius expansae, et ponat brachia sua sub genibus suis, et liget utraque ligamento conueniente ad illud.	When it is necessary to sit a woman over two chairs, and she recline, or she is put upon her back, and her feet are put at the lower part of her belly: and her hips are spread out, and she puts her arms under her hips, and ties both ligaments conveniently to this
Deinde sedeat obstetrix a latere dextro, et administra instrumentum quo aperitur orificium matricis.	Then let the obstetrix sit at the right side, and manage the instrument which opens the maternal orifice.
Cuius forma uenit in eis quae sunt post.	And whose form comes into being in the things which are after.
Et oportet quando uis administrare hoc instrumentum, ut figas cum Radio profundum matricis mulieris: ut non sit illud quod ingreditur ex instrumento plus, quam profundum matricis, et laedat infirmam.	And it is necessary when you are about to administer this instrument, that the figs be placed as far as the Radio of the deep matrix of the woman: that there may not be that which enters from the instrument more than from the depth of the matrix, and harms the lower part.
Si autem fuerit instrumentum magis quam profundum, tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos super tecturam profundi matricis: ut prohibeatur introitus instrumenti totius in profundum matricis: et oportet ut ponat uertiginem, quae currit in instrumento, ex latere superiore: et ut teneat instrumentum, et ut reuoluat minister uertiginem, donec aperiatur profundum matricis.	If, however, the instrument be thicker than the depth, then you must place sponges upon the covering of the deep matrix: in order to prevent the entrance of the whole instrument into the depth of the matrix: and you must place a bandage, which runs in the instrument, from the upper side: and must hold the instrument, and must turn the minister of the bandage, until the depth of the matrix is opened
Cum ergo apparet Exitura, et tangitur manu, et est lenis et mollis: tunc oportet ut seces ipsam apud caput suum cum spatumili lato.	When therefore the Exitura appears, and the hand is grasped, and is soft and yielding: then it is necessary to cut it off at its head with a broad knife
Cum ergo euacuatur sanies, tunc oportet ut ponas in uulnus licinium submersum in oleo rosaceo: aut oleo uiridi, in quo sit quaedam stipticitas: et pone licinium, et extrahe sectionem in profundo matricis.	When therefore the healthy parts have been evacuated, then it is necessary to place in the wound a soaked piece of lint dipped in saffron: or in olive oil, in which there is some astringency: and place the lint, and withdraw the section from the depth of the matrix.
Et pone exterius super matricem, et super pectinem lanam mundam submersam in aqua, in qua bullitae sunt maluae.	And place externally upon the matrix, and upon the belly wool soaked in water, in which there are small bubbles.
Deinde curetur post duos dies cum unguento quod conuenit ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then care for two days with an unguent that is suitable for this, until it is healed
Et quandoque abluitur matrix et uulnus, ita quod clisterizatur cum aqua et melle: deinde cum aqua in qua bullita est radix lilii, aut aristolochia longa: deinde redeat ad unguentum.	And when the matrix and the wound are washed, it is to be cleansed with water and honey: then with water in which the radix of lily, or long-stalked iris, is boiled: then return to the unguent.
Quod si uulnus absconditum fuerit interius in matrice, tunc oportet ut prohibearis ex curatione eius cum ferro, imo cura ipsum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione.	If a vein has been concealed within the matrix, then it is necessary to exclude its treatment with iron, and indeed to treat it with that which we mentioned in the discussion.
¶ Doctrinae Obstetricum, qualiter medicentur embriones uiui, secundum figuram non naturalem egressi.	How obstetrics should handle unborn creatures, according to their unnatural position of emergence.
Caput Lxxu.	Chapter Lxx.</start_of_turn>
Necesse est Obstetrici, ut cognoscat in primis figuram partus naturalis.	It is necessary for the Obstetrician to know at first the natural position of birth of a creature.</start_of_turn>
Ex signis ergo eius est, quod quando uides mulierem comprimi ad inferiora, et desiderat odorare aerem, et alleuiatur super eam quod super ipsam est de partu, et festinat exitus embrionis: tunc scias quod iste partus est secundum figuram naturalem, et est exitus eius super caput suum, et secundina cum eo: aut suspensa, uel pendens ex umbilico.	Therefore, when a woman is pressed downwards by the attendants and wishes to smell the air, and she feels that something is pressing upon her from below which is different from the birth process, and if she is hastening the birth, then you know that this is a natural birth, and the head comes out first, and afterwards the tail: or the tail is suspended or hanging from the navel.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo uides haec signa, tunc oportet ut comprimatur uenter eius, ut descendat embrio uelociter.	When you see these signs, then it is necessary to press the belly of the woman, so that the fetus comes down more quickly.</start_of_turn
Nam quando descendit super caput suum, descendit secundina cum eo, et mundatur ex illis superfluitatibus mundificatione bona.	For when it descends upon the head, it also descends with the tail, and they move out together with ease.</start_of_turn
Qui autem est praeter hunc partum, est innaturalis, illaudabilis.	Whoever does not follow this part is unnatural and harmful.</start_of_turn
Quoniam quandoque egreditur foetus super pedes suos, et egreditur corpus eius ante caput ipsius, et pedes eius, et manus eius una, aut pes eius unus: aut egreditur caput eius et manus eius: aut egreditur uentrinus: et fortasse conuertitur super collum suum, et similia ex figuris illaudabilibus.	For indeed, when the fetus comes out through its feet, and its body comes out before its head, and its feet and hands together, or one foot alone: or the head comes out alone, or the belly comes out: and perhaps it turns upon its neck, and similar things happen which are not natural.</start_of_turn
Necesse est ergo Obstetrici, ut sit prudens, subtilis in istis rebus omnibus, et caueat sibi ab errore et decaeptione: et ego sum ostendens omnem figuram ex eis, et qualiter est ingenium in ea, et significetur per illud, et stetur super ipsum.	Therefore, it is necessary for the Obstetrician to be prudent and cautious in all these matters, and to fear mistakes and negligence: and I will show you all the figures and their meanings, and I will explain them to you so that you will be able to understand them.</start_of_turn>
Quando egreditur foetus super caput suum egressione sua naturali, et uehemens fit illud super mulierem, et difficilis fit ei partus, et uides uirtutem eius iam debilitatam: tunc fac eam sedere super sedem, aut mulieres teneant eam: et uapora uuluam eius cum foenugraeco decocto, et cum oleis humidis.	When the fetus emerges from the head by its natural egress, and it mounts upon the woman, and its delivery becomes difficult, and the aid of its virtue is hindered: then let the woman sit down, or let the women hold her: and let steam rise from the bath of vinegar and decocted fenugreek with oily substances.
Deinde intromittat Obstetrix inter digitos suos Spatumile paruum, et findat cum eo secundinam, et secet eam ungue suo, donec currat quod est in ea ex humiditate: et preme uentrem mulieris, donec descendat foetus.	Then let the obstetrician introduce his fingers between the toes of the parous woman, and find the second finger, and cut it off with his nail, until he has run off what is in her from moisture: and press the woman's belly, until the fetus descends.
Si autem non descendit, tunc oportet ut clisterizetur mulier ex mucillagine foenugraeci, cum oleo sisamino.	If it does not descend, then it is necessary that the woman be stimulated with a sponge of fenugreek with oil of sesame seed
Deinde praecipe ei post clistere, ut comprimatur: et fac eam sternutare cum condisi, et tene os eius et nasum ipsius hora una.	Then command her to strain: and make her wipe with a towel, and hold her hand and nose for an hour together
Foetus enim egredietur statim.	The fetus will immediately issue forth.
Quod si egrediantur duae manus foetus in primis, iunc oportet ut reducas eas cum facilitate paulatim.	If two hands of the fetus come out at first, it is necessary to reduce them gradually.
Si autem non obedit in introitu, tunc pone mulierem super sedem, et eleua pedes eius sursum: deinde concute sedem super terram: et mulier teneatur, ut non cadat apud concussionem.	If it does not obey in delivery, then let the woman sit down, and elevate her feet above the level: then strike the seat upon the ground: and the woman shall be held, lest she should fall by the concussion.
Si ergo non egrediuntur manus, et moritur foetus: tunc incide eas, et extrahe residuum foetus: et liga manum eius cum panno, et extrahe ipsum cum aequalitate: nam ipse egredietur.	If, however, the hands do not issue forth, and the fetus dies: then cut off the hands, and draw out the remainder of the fetus: and bind up the hand with cloth, and draw it out with equality: for it will issue forth itself
¶ Exitus embrionis super pedes suo.	The exit of the embryo from its feet.
Quando egreditur foetus super pedes suos, tunc oportet ut impellat eos sursum: deinde conuertat foetum paulatim: postea aequet ipsum.	When the fetus comes out from its feet, then it is necessary to push it upwards: then slowly turn the fetus: afterwards equalize it.
Deinde accipiat unum pedum eius, et extendat eum paulatim.	Then he shall take one foot of his and extend it gradually.
Cum ergo egrediuntur usque ad coxas, tunc praecipe ei, ut comprimatur, et fac eam sternutare cum condisi: egredietur enim, si Deus uoluerit.	When they have gone as far as the hips, then command him to bend his knee, and let him rest: he will go out of himself, if God wills it.
Et si non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc reduc foetum paulatim, donec ponas eum secundum figuram naturalem.	If he does not go out of himself as we have said, then reduce his foot gradually, until you have set it according to its natural form.
Nam ipse egredietur tunc egressu facili.	For he will go out of himself when he wishes to go out.
Quod si prohibeatur cum eo toto quod narrauimus: tunc accipe ex mucillagine alteae, et oleo sisamino, et gummi soluto: et percute totum in mortario percussione bona: deinde line cum eo uuluam mulieris, et inferius uentris eius.	If it is hindered that he should go out of himself as we have said: then take from the thick slime of the armpits, and smear it with oil, and gum dissolved: and pierce all this with a good needle: then draw out with the thumb of a woman, and downwards into his belly
Deinde fac eam sedere in aqua tepida, donec consequatur hypocundria.	Then make him sit in warm water, until his pulse subsides.
Cum ergo uides quod iam calefacta sunt inferiora eius, tunc fac ei sief de myrrha: et suppone ipsum.	When his lower parts are warmed by the water, then make for him a plaster of myrrh: and leave it on him
Quando ergo tenet sief hora una, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem.	When an hour has passed since you put on the plaster, then make him sit on a chair.
Deinde fac eam sternutare: et stringe ipsius os et nasum: et preme inferiorem partem uentris compressione facili.	Then make him cough: and bind his jaw and nose: and press down the lower part of his belly with ease
Nam foeus egredietur statim.	For the urine will come out immediately.
¶ Exitus foetus super genua et manus.	The urine comes out over the knee and hand
Quando egreditur secundum hanc formam, tunc ingeniet in intromittendo manus suas paulatim.	When he has gone out in this manner, then insert your hand inside gradually.
Deinde resupinetur mulier super collum suum, et pendeant pedes eius ad inferiora: et ipsa sit iacens super lectum, et complicet manus suas.	Then the woman lies down on his neck, and leans his feet downwards: and she herself lies down on a bed, and joins her hands together
Deinde preme supra uentrem eius paulatim.	Then first above the belly of it gradually.
Deinde extrahe quod est sub pedibus eius ex puluinaribus, donec sit praeparata in inferiori parte.	Then extract what is under its feet from the heel, until it is prepared in the lower part.
Quod si non egreditur foetus, tunc accipe pedes eius, et moue eos motu uehementi.	If it does not come out, then grasp its feet and move them with force.</start_of_turn>
Deinde preme quod est supra hypocundria paulatim, donec ascendat foetus ad superiora.	Then first above the hip gradually, until the fetus ascends to the upper parts.</start_of_turn
Deinde intromittat manus suas, et aequet foetum paulatim: et praecipe mulieri, ut comprimatur, donec egrediatur foetus.	Then introduce your hands, and equalize the fetus gradually: and command the woman, that she may compress, until the fetus comes out.</start_of_turn
¶ Exitus foetus latitudinaliter pendens ex manibus.	The fetus comes out laterally hanging from the hands.</start_of_turn>
Ingenietur in reductione manus eius.	Beware in the reduction of its hand.</start_of_turn
Si autem non potest reducere eam, tunc eleua mulierem, et fac eam ambulare.	If however you are unable to reduce it, then elevate the woman, and make her walk.</start_of_turn
Si uero ambulare non potest, tunc fac eam iacere super lectum: et concute crura eius concussione uehementi.	If she is unable to walk, then make her lie upon a stretcher: and strike her thighs with a blow of force.</start_of_turn
Deinde administra linimentum quod praeparasti ex mucillaginibus.	Then administer the liniment which you prepared from mucilages.</start_of_turn
Quod si accipit eam partus, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem.	If she bears a part, then make her sit upon a seat.</start_of_turn
Deinde stude in reductione manus, et aequa foetum secundum figuram naturalem: et fac sternutare mulierem, et praecipe ei, ut comprimat se, donec egrediatur.	Then study in the reduction of the hand, and equalize the fetus according to its natural figure: and command the woman to press, and tell her to compress herself, until she comes out.</start_of_turn
¶ Exitus foetus super collum suum, expansis manibus, et est facies eius ad dorsum matris suae.	The fetus comes out upon its collar, with expanded hands, and its face is towards the mother's back.</start_of_turn
Oportet ut teneat Obstetrix manum foetus, deinde reuoluat eum paulatim, et aequet eum cum facilitate.	It is necessary that the Obstetrician grasp the hand of the fetus, then gradually turn it back, and equalize it with ease.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo aequatur, tunc pone super uuluam eius quod narrauimus ex oleo et mucillaginibus.	When the edges are equal, then place over its belly what we have mentioned from fat and mucus.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut moueatur paulatim.	Then command him to move slowly.
Cum ergo feceris illud, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem, et praecipe ei ut inclinetur ad latus dextrum.	When you have done this, then make him sit on his seat, and command him to lean to his right side.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut comprimatur: et fac eam sternutare cum condisi.	Then command him to compress: and make him snort with pain
¶ Exitus foetus praeparati super latus.	The fetus is prepared to come out on the right side
Quando descendit ad orificium matricis secundum hunc modum cum secundina, tunc scinde secundinam cum ungue tuo, donec euacuetur ex humiditate.	When it has descended to the birth opening in this way with the second [finger], then split the second with your nail until it is evacuated from the moisture.
Si ergo suspenditur super faciem foetus, et collum eius, tunc incide eam ex umbilico: ut non retineatur, et moriatur.	If it is suspended on the face of the fetus, and its neck, then cut it from the navel: so that it does not remain and does not die
Deinde impelle foetum ad interiora, donec ponas eam secundum quod oportet: et praecipe mulieri, ut comprimat se aliquotiens: ipse enim egredietur exitu leui.	Then drive the fetus inwards until you place it according to what is required: and command the woman to compress herself a little: for he himself will go out through the easy exit.
¶ Exitus Geminorum, aut foetuum multorum.	The exit of twins, or many fetuses.
Scias, quod Gemini multotiens nascuntur: et quandoque nascuntur tres, et quatuor.	You know that twins are often born together: and sometimes three, and four are born together.
Verumtamen illud extraneum est, et raro contingit.	However, this is an unusual thing, and rarely happens
Quinque uero est res extra naturam, et non uiuunt penitus: et continet eos, quamuis multiplicentur, secundina una: et separantur per sifach, distinguens inter eos ligatum in umbilico cuiusque eorum.	Five or more is a thing beyond nature, and does not often happen: and it contains those which, although multiplied, are one: and they are separated by the navel, distinguishing between each of them that which is connected to each of them
Et quandoque egrediuntur sicut egreditur foetus unus exitu naturali, facili: et egrediuntur exitu illaudabili, sicut narrauimus.	And sometimes they come out like a single fetus through the natural opening, easily: and they come out through the difficult opening, as we have mentioned
Quod si difficiles fuerint quidam eorum apud partum, et perueniunt ad illud quod diximus ex figuris innaturalibus, tunc cura eos sicut narrauimus: et sit ob stetrix subtilis, et faciat quod facit cum facilitate et tarditate, et ingenietur secundum omnem figuram cum eo quod praeparatur ei ex ingenio ducente ad salutem.	If any of them are difficult at the part, and they reach that which we have mentioned from unnatural figures, then care for them as we have said: and let the obstetrix be gentle, and let her do what she does with ease and tardiness, and she shall succeed in every figure as she is accustomed to with that which is prepared for her from the leading mind for safety.
¶ Rememoratio eius quod formatur in matrice ex embrionibus, et abortiuntur.	Remember that which is formed in the womb from embryos, and aborts.
Quandoque formatur in matrice unus, et duo, et tres, et quatuor, et quinque, et sex, et septem, et plures decem: et iam uerificatum est apud me, quod mulier abortiendo emisit septem, et alia quindecim, omnes formatos.	When one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, and more than ten are formed in the womb: and I have seen that a woman has aborted seven, and another fifteen, all of whom were formed.
Quod factum est mensuratione gloriosi sapientis.	Which is done by the measurement of the glorious wise man.
Hoc ergo totum oportet ut sit in scientia Obstetricis.	Therefore all this is necessary that it should be in the science of Midwifery
Fortasse enim perueniet ad eam simile illius: opponat ergo ei cum illo quod oportet	Perhaps also it will reach like that: oppose it with that which is necessary.
¶ De extractione foetus mortui.	On the extraction of a dead fetus.
Caput LXXVI.	Chapter 76.
Quando curas foetum mortuum cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex medicatione, et non egreditur, et cogeris uti operatione cum manu, tunc oportet ut consideres.	When you care for a dead fetus with that which I said in the discourse from medicine, and it does not go out, and you must do so by operation with the hand, then you must consider it.
Si ergo mulier est sanae uirtutis, et non est cum aliquo ex accidentibus, ex quibus timetur super eam perditio: tunc oportet ut resupinetur mulier super lectum, super dorsum suum, et sit caput eius inclinatum inferius, et crura eius eleuata: et ministra teneat eam a duabus partibus, aut ligetur ad lectum, ut non extrahatur corpus eius apud extractionem foetus.	If a woman is healthy and of good virtue, and is not with any of the things from which she is afraid that she will lose her life: then it must be that she rests over her bed, over her back, and that her head is inclined downwards, and her legs are elevated: and the minister shall hold her fast by two parts, or she shall be bound to the bed, so that her body is not pulled out during the extraction of the fetus
Deinde humecta os matricis ex oleis humidis cum mucillagine alteae, et foenugraeci, et seminis lini.	Then moisten the os matricis with oily things with high mucus, and chaff of aloes, and linseed seed.
Deinde inungat Obstetrix manum suam cum istis oleis et mucillaginibus: deinde intromittat eam in matricem cum facilitate.	Then the Obstetrix shall wet his hand with these oils and mucilages: then he shall insert it into the matrix with ease.
Deinde quaerat cum ea locum in quo figat uncinos ex foetu, et loca conuenientia ad illud.	Then he seeks the place where the ribs rest upon the fetus, and the convenient location for it
Considera ergo tunc, si foetus est praeparatus ut descendat super caput suum: tunc fige uncinos in oculos eius, aut in collo eius, aut in ore eius, aut in palato ipsius, aut sub barba eius, aut in furcula ipsius, aut in locis propinquis costis, et sub hypocundriis.	Consider therefore at that time, if the fetus is ready to descend over its head: then fix the ribs to its eyes, or to its neck, or to its mouth, or to its palate, or under its beard, or under its ribs, or in nearby places to the ribs, and under the hyoid bone
Si autem descensus est super pedes eius, tunc in pectine, et costis eius mediis.	If however the descent is over its feet, then in the chest, and the middle ribs.
Et oportet, ut teneat uncinum cum manu dextra: et ponat curuitatem eius in eo quod est inter digitos sinistrae manus: et intromittat cum manu cum facilitate, et figat uncinum in aliquo illorum locorum quae diximus, donec perueniat ad rem uacuam.	And it is necessary that he grasp the hook with his right hand: and he shall place his thumb in that place which is between the left thumb and little finger: and he shall insert it with the hand with ease, and he shall fix the hook in some one of those places which we mentioned, until it reaches the desired thing.
Deinde figat in oppositione eius uncinum alium, aut tertium, si indiges: ut sit contractio aequalis, et non declinet ad partem.	Then he shall fix the other hook, or the third one, if necessary: so that there is an equal tension, and it does not lean towards one side.
Deinde extendatur extensione aequali, et non sit extensio secundum rectitudinem tantum, imo moueatur ad omnem partem, ut alleuietur exitus eius: sicut fit cum dente apud eradicationem eius.	Then the extension shall be equal, and it shall not be extended only in a straight line, but it shall be moved to all parts, so that it may relieve the exit: thus it is done with a tooth in extracting it
Et oportet in eo quod est inter illud, ut mollificetur extensio.	And it is necessary at that place where the extension is, to soften the extension.
Quod si retineatur ex eo pars, tunc oportet ut inungat Obstetrix quosdam digitos cum oleo, et intromittat eos ex parte, ut reuoluat cum eis quod retinetur.	Which if it is retained from that side, then it is necessary that the Obstetrix grasp some fingers with oil, and insert them from the side, so that it will recoil with that which is retained
Si ergo egreditur pars foetus, tunc permutentur uncini ad locum alium qui sit altior: fac hoc donec egrediatur foetus totus.	If therefore the part of the fetus comes out, then change the nails to another place which is higher: do this until the fetus comes out entirely
Si ergo egreditur manus ante alia, et non est possibile reducere eam, propter coartationem eius: tunc oportet, ut inuoluatur super eam pannus.	If the hand goes out before the other, and it is not possible to reduce it, because of its compression: then it is necessary that the hand be bound above the palm.
Deinde extrahe eam donec quando egreditur tota, incide eam aut in iunctura plantae, aut in cubito: et ita oportet ut facias in manu altera, et in duobus pedibus.	Then draw out the hand until when it goes out entirely, it hangs by the edge either at the wrist or at the elbow: and thus it is necessary that you make in the other hand, and in two feet
Si autem caput foetus est magnum, aut accidit ei coartatio in exitu, aut est in capite eius aqua aggregata: tunc oportet ut intromittat inter digitos Spatumile spinosum, et findat cum eo caput, et extrahat aquam: aut disrumpat ipsum cum instrumento quod nominatur Almisdac: cuius forma uenit cum formis reliquorum instrumentorum in capitulo quod est post hoc.	If however the head of the fetus is great, or if it has received compression on its exit, or there is water in its head: then it is necessary that you introduce between the fingers a thorned sponge, and find with it the head, and extract the water: or break it with an instrument which is called Almisdac: whose form comes with the forms of the other instruments in the following chapter.
Similiter faciat si foetus est magni capitis natura, tunc oportet ut seces algengematu: aut extrahas ipsum cum misdach, sicut diximus.	Likewise do thus if the fetus is of great head-size: then it is necessary that you cut through the membrane: or extract it with force, as we have said.
Deinde attrahas ossa cum forcipibus.	Then draw out the bones with forceps.
Quod si egrediatur caput, et coartetur apud furculam: tunc findatur, donec effundatur humiditas quae est in pectore.	When the head comes out, and is compressed at the furculum: then it is found, until the humidity which is in the chest is drained out.
Si autem non complicatur, neque obedit ad exitum: tunc incide caput frustatim, secundum quod possibile est tibi.	If however it does not become complicated, neither will it agree to go out: then cut off the head roughly, as much as is possible to you
Quod si inferius uentris est apostematum, aut est in eo hydropisis: tunc oportet ut perfores ipsum, donec currat humiditas ex eo.	If indeed the lower belly is swollen with fluid, or there is water in it: then it is necessary that you perforate it, until the humidity from it comes out
Si uero foetus est super pedes suos, tunc attractio eius est facilis, et directio eius ad os matricis est leuis.	If indeed the fetus is above his feet: then its traction is easy, and its direction towards the maternal bones is smooth
Si autem coartatur apud uentrem, aut pectus: tunc oportet ut extrahas ipsum cum panno quem inuoluisti super manum tuam: et findat uentrem, aut pectus, donec currat quod est in eis.	If however it is compressed at the belly, or the chest: then it is necessary that you extract it with the bandage which you bound above your hand: and find the belly, or the chest, until it comes out by itself.
Si autem auferuntur reliqua membra, et redit caput: tunc intromittat Obstetrix manum sinistram.	If, however, the remaining limbs are removed and the head remains: then the Obstetrix inserts his left hand into the head.
Si ergo os matricis est apertum, tunc intromittat manum in profundum matricis, et quaerat cum ea caput, et attrahat ipsum cum digitis usque ad os matricis: deinde intromittat in eo uncinum unum, aut uncinos duos, et attrahat ipsum cum eo.	If the mouth of the matrix is opened: then he inserts his hand deep into the matrix and grasps the head, and pulls it until it reaches the mouth of the matrix: then he inserts one or two fingers into it and pulls it out with them.</start_of_turn>
Quod si os matricis coartatur, propter apostema calidum quod accidit ei: tunc non oportet ut laboretur super ipsum, imo oportet tunc administrare effusionem rerum humidarum, pinguium: et administra emplastra: et sedeat in aquis quae mollificant et humectant.	If the mouth of the matrix is closed, because of a thick clot that has happened to it: then it is not necessary to work above it, rather it is necessary to administer an effusion of soft things: and to apply plasters: and to sit in water which softens and moistens.</start_of_turn>
Quod si foetus est super latus suum, tunc possibile est ut aequetur: tunc administretur quod diximus in foetu uiuo.	If the fetus is above its side: then it is possible to make it even: then the following is administered for the fetus itself.</start_of_turn>
Quod si non est possibile illud, tunc incidatur frustatim, et extrahatur.	If it is not possible to do this, then it is done hastily, and it is extracted.</start_of_turn>
Et oportet ut non dimittas aliquid ex secundina intus omnino.	And it is necessary that you do not leave anything remaining inside at all.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo compleueris operationem tuam, tunc administra quod diximus in apostematibus calidis quae accidunt in matricibus.	When you have completed your operation, then administer what we have said concerning the clots which happen in the matrix.</start_of_turn
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc descendat in aquis stipticis, et administra reliquam curationem.	If there is a flow of blood: then descend into the waters of styptics, and administer the remaining treatment.</start_of_turn
Et ego quidem iam uidi mulierem, in cuius uentre mortuus erat foetus: deinde impregnata est super ipsum uice alia, postea mortuus est foetus alius etiam.	And I myself have seen a woman in whose womb there was a dead fetus: then she was impregnated over her with another, afterwards the other fetus also died.</start_of_turn
Accidit ergo ei post tempus longum apostema in umbilico suo, et inflatum est, donec apertum est: et coepit emittere pus.	This happened to her after a long time there was a clot in her navel, and it became swollen, until it opened: and pus began to flow from it.</start_of_turn
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius, et medicatus sum ei tempore longo: et non consolidatum est uulnus.	I have been called to his aid and have treated him for a long time: and the wound has not healed.
Posui ergo super ipsum ex quibusdam emplastris fortis attractionis: et exiuit ex loco os.	I have placed above it some strong adhesive plaster: and it has come out of its place at the bone's location.
Deinde praeterierunt ei dies aliquot, et exiuit os aliud.	Then some days passed by, and the bone came loose again from another side
Miratus sum ergo inde, cum in uentre non sit os.	I am doubtful that it will recover, since there is no bone in the middle
Cogitaui ergo, quia erant ex ossibus foetus mortui.	I think that the bone is dead from its roots
Inquisiui ergo uulnus, et extraxi ossa multa, muliere existente in melioribus dispositionibus suis: et iam uixit taliter tempore longo, et mittit ex loco pus parum.	I asked about the wound, and I extracted many bones from her, a woman who is in better health than usual: and I have treated her for a long time, and she sends out a little pus from the place
Et ego non firmaui hic hoc extraneum, nisi quoniam in eo est scientia, et adiutorium ad illud, quod administrat medicus artifex cum manu ex curatione.	I do not know for certain what is the cause of this, except that it is a knowledge and an art that a physician who is an artificer has with his hand in the treatment.
¶ De formis Instrumentorum necessariorum in extractione foetus.	Of the forms of the necessary instruments for extracting bones from the fetus.
Caput LXXVII.	Chapter 77.
Hic inferius est forma Strictorii, quo aequantur libri, cui aequaliter sunt duae uertigines in duabus extremitatibus duorum lignorum.	Here below is the form of the Strictor, with which books are equaled, to which are equal two strings at the extremities of two sticks.
Verumtamen haec Vertigo oportet ut sit subtilior strictorio: et ut fiat, aut ex ebano, aut ex ligno bussi.	True, this vertigo must be smaller than the strictor: and it must be made either of ebony or of seasoned wood
Et sit latitudo omnis ligni quasi duo digiti: et margo cuiusque amborum est quasi digitus unus, et longitudo cuiusque eorum est palmus et medietas: et in medio duorum lignorum sunt duo additamenta ex genere eiusdem ligni, quae iam firmata sunt in utrisque, quorum longitudo est medietas palmi et plus parum: et latitudo utriusque est quasi duo digiti, aut plus parum.	And the width of each stick is like two fingers: and the margin of each of them is like one finger, and the length of each of them is palm and a middle: and in the middle of the two sticks are two additions of the same kind of wood, which are firmly fixed in both of them, whose length is half of the palm and a little less: and the width of each of them is like two fingers, or less
Et ista duo additamenta intromittuntur in os matricis, ut aperiatur cum eis quando tu reuoluis duas Vertigines.	And these two additional things are introduced into the matrix bone, so that it opens when you rotate two Vertigines.
Forma Vertiginis qua aperitur matrix.	When two Vertigines are rotated, these two additional things are introduced into the matrix bone so that it opens
Forma alia ad simile illius, subtilior, et leuior.	The like of that, but smaller and smoother.
Fiat ex ligno ebani, aut bussi, secundum similitudinem forcipum.	They are made from the wood of the bone or from horn, according to the likeness of pincers
Verumtamen in extremitate eius sint duo additamenta, sicut uides hic supra: et longitudo omnis additamenti ex eis est quasi palmus: et latitudo utriusque est, duo digiti.	There are indeed two additional things at its extremity here: as above: and their length from the heel to the tip is like a palm, and their width is like two fingers.
Cum ergo uis aperire matricem cum eo, tunc fac sedere mulierem super lectum, pendentibus pedibus eius, aperto quod est inter crura eius.	When you wish to open the matrix with this, then make a woman sit over a bench, with her feet hanging down, and open that which is between her thighs.
Deinde intromitte ista duo additamenta coniuncta in matricem: et tu es tenens extremitatem instrumenti inferius inter coxas eius.	And then introduce these two additional things together into the matrix: and you hold the lower extremity of the instrument between her thighs.
Deinde aperi manum tuam cum instrumento, sicut facis cum forficibus, aequaliter secundum quantitatem quam uis ex apertione oris matricis, donec faciat Obstetrix quod uult.	Then open your hand with the instrument, like making with pincers, equally according to the quantity that you wish to open the opening of the matrix, until the Obstetrician wishes to stop it.
Forma Vertiginis alterius quam dixerunt antiqui Forma Impellentis quo impellitur foetus.	The like of that, as the ancients said, is the form of the Impelling Force which drives out the fetus.
Forma Almisdac, qua conteritur caput magnum: et assimilatur forcipi, cui sunt dentes in extremitate, sicut uides.	The shape of the Alma, which counteracts the large head: and it is assimilated to the pincers, which have teeth at the extremity, like these things.
Et quandoque fit oblungum, sicut forcipes secundum hanc formam, sicut uides, cui sunt dentes sicut dentes serrae, quo inciditur et conteritur.	And when it is bent, like the pincers according to this shape, like these things, which have teeth like saw teeth, with which it incides and counteracts
Forma Almisdac quo conteritur caput paruum.	The shape of the Alma which counteracts the small head
Forma Vncini habentis spinam unam.	The shape of the neighbor having a single spine.
Forma Vncini habentis spinas duas.	The form of the neighbour who has spines two.
Forma forcipis cui sunt dentes serrae, cum quo conteritur caput foetus.	The shape of the forceps which have teeth like a saw, with which the head of the foetus is held.
Forma Spatumilis habentis duas extremitates ad abscindendum caput.	The shape of the spatula which has two extremities to bind the head
Forma duorum Spatumilium etiam latorum.	The shape of two spatulas also of the hands
Ista instrumenta omnia exercentur, et quanto plus multiplicantur species eorum, et praeparata sunt apud artificem, est uelocior ad operationem suam, et altior apud homines, propter quantitatem suam.	These instruments are used for this purpose, and the more numerous the species of these, and the more are prepared by the artificer, the faster is the operation and the greater for the men, on account of their quantity
Non ergo despicies ex eis instrumentum, quin sit apud te praeparatum.	It does not behove you to despise the things of the instruments which are prepared for you.
Inexcusabilis est enim necessitas eorum.	It is not unreasonable that you should have them.
¶ De extractione Secundinae.	About the extraction of the second one.
Caput LXXVIII.	Head seventy-eighth.
Quando retinetur Secundina apud partum, tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmae, ut retineat anhelitum suum.	When the second one is retained at the delivery, then it is necessary to grasp the lower parts, so that it retains its breath.
Deinde fac eam sternutare cum condisi: et stringe manum tuam super os eius, et nares ipsius.	Then make the grasp with the thumb and the index finger: and stretch out your hand over its bone, and take hold of its breath.
Si ergo egreditur per hoc, bonum est.	If it comes out by this means, that is good
Si non: tunc accipe ollam, et perfora in coopertorio foramen: et pone in ea herbas aperientes os matricis, sicut calamentum, rutam, et anetum, et camomillam, et sseham, et cassiam ligneam, et centauream: accipe omnes istas herbas, aut quasdam earum, et submerge eas cum aqua, et pone eas super ignem.	If not: then grasp the head firmly, and pierce through the skull in the suture: and put in it herbs which are applied to the bone, such as calamus, rue, and mugwort, and chamomile, and hyssop, and saffron, and pitch: grasp all these herbs, or some of them, and immerse them in water, and put them over fire.
Deinde pone embulam arundinis super foramen coopertorii ollae, et extremitatem aliam in os matricis: et teneat eam donec perueniat uapor ad concauitatem matricis.	Then put a bundle of reeds over the hole in the skull of the jar, and the other extremity in the bone of the matrix: and keep it there until the steam reaches the cavity of the matrix.
Deinde fac eam sternutare, sicut diximus.	Then make the incision, as we have said.
Secundina enim egredietur cum facilitate.	Then indeed it will flow out easily.
Si autem remaneat post hanc curationem, et non egrediatur: tunc praecipe Obstetrici, ut submergat manum suam in oleo sisamino, aut mucillagine alteae.	But if it remains after this treatment, and does not flow out: then command the Obstetrician, that he plunge his hand into the belly of the patient, or sprinkle it with alum.
Deinde intromittat in uuluam, et quaerat cum ea Secundinam.	Then insert the hand into the belly, and search with it for the Secundina
Cum ergo inuenerit eam, tunc accipiat eam, et extendat ipsam paulatim.	When you find it, then seize it, and draw it out slowly
Si autem fuerit annexa in profundo matricis, tunc intromittat manum, secundum quod narrauimus, donec quando inuenerit Secundinam, et extrahat eam paulatim secundum rectitudinem, ut non cadat matrix apud attractionem uehementem: imo oportet, ut permutetur cum facilitate ad latera dextra et sinistra: deinde addatur in quantitatem attractionis.	If it is an appendix which lies deep in the belly, then insert the hand as we have said, until you find the Secundina. Then draw it out slowly according to the rule, so that the belly does not tear at the time of traction: it is better to move it to the right and left sides: and then add in the quantity of traction
Ipsa enim obedit tunc, et seruatur, et euadit ab adhaerentia.	Then indeed it will obey, and will be cured, and will go away from adhesion
Quod si os matricis est coartatum, sicut nos iam narrauimus: cura eam cum sternutatione, et ex medicatione ollae cum herbis.	If the belly is closed, as we have said: treat it with an incision, and with medication from an oil jar with herbs
Si autem non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc caue ne fatigeris super eam in iteratione extractionis.	If it does not flow out with all that we have said: then be careful that you do not tire yourself in the process of extraction.
Verum oportet, ut quod egreditur ad os matricis ex ea, liges ad coxam mulieris.	It is indeed necessary that what flows out to the belly-opening should be bound to the woman's hip.
Deinde clisteriza eam cum unguento tetrapharmacon.	Then close the incision with four herbs.
Ipsum enim putrefaciet eam post dies, et dissoluetur, et egredietur.	It will itself decay the incision after a few days, and will be dissolved, and will flow out.
Verumtamen quando putrefit, eleuatur ex ea odor malus ad stomachum et caput, et laedit illud infirmam.	Indeed when it decays, it will emit a bad odor from the belly and the head, and will make that worse the illness.
Oportet ergo ut administrentur suffumigationes conuenientes ad illud.	It is necessary that suitable fumigations be administered thereupon.
Quidam autem antiquorum iam experti sunt suffumigationem nasturtii, et ficuum siccarum.	Some of the ancients are experts in fumigation with naphtha and dried figs.
Forma instrumenti quo suffumigatur mulier apud retentionem Secundinae et menstruorum.	The manner in which a woman is fumigated with respect to the retention of the second [menstrual] and the menses
Fiat ex uitro simile alcama, aut ex zere: et ponatur extremitas ampla super ignem: et suffumigatio sit posita super prunas: teneat eam, donec consumatur illa suffumigatio: et itera aliam.	Let it be like the smoke of an incense burner, or from a cone: and put the broad end over the fire: and let the fumigation be placed over the berries: hold it there until the fumigation is consumed: and do it again for the other side
¶ De curatione Ani non perforati.	About the treatment of an unpierced animal
Caput LXXIX.	Chapter 79.
Nascuntur multi puerorum, et Ani eorum sunt non perforati, quos iam opilauit sifac subtile.	Many boys are born with unpierced noses, and their animals also have unpierced noses, which I have treated with subtle sponges
Oportet ergo, ut obstetrix perforet illud sifac digito suo: et si non, perforet ipsum cum Spatumili acuto: et caueat lacertum, ne tangat eum.	It is necessary that the midwife pierce that sponge with her finger: and if not, pierce it with a sharp spatula: and beware of tears, lest they touch it
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam infusam in uino et oleo.	Then put upon it infused wool in wine and oil.
Deinde cura ipsum cum ungentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with nails until it heals
Si autem times quod opiletur, tunc pone in foramine cannulam de plumbo diebus multis, et auferatur quando puer uult egerere.	If, however, it is to be opened, then put in the cavity a lead cannula for many days, and remove it when the boy wishes to fart
Et iam accidit opilatio Ani etiam ex consolidatione uulneris, aut apostematis.	And sometimes the piercing of an animal is done even from the swelling or from the pus
Oportet ergo ut secetur illa consolidatio, deinde curetur cum eo quod diximus ex curatione et plumbo.	It is necessary that the swelling be drained, and then care for it as we have said concerning treatment and lead
¶ De curatione Fistularum quae accidunt in inferiori parte.	About the treatment of fistulas which occur in the lower part
Caput LXXX.	Chapter 80
Fistulae quae accidunt in inferiori, sunt Nodatio, et Grossitudo quae accidunt prope anum deforis: aut in spacio unius partium: et est Fistula una, aut plures.	The fistulas which happen in the lower parts are Nodatio and Grossitudo, which happen close to any deformity: or in the space of one part. And there is one fistula, or more.
Cum ergo antiquatur illa Nodatio, aperitur, et currit ex ea humiditas aquosa alba, aut pus subtile.	When the Nodatio is old, it opens, and there runs from it a white watery moisture, or subtle pus
Et quandoque sunt ex istis Fistulis penetrantes.	And sometimes these fistulas are penetrating
Ergo penetrantes cognoscuntur per illud quod egreditur ex egestione, et uentositate, quando utitur infirmus egestione: et fortasse egreditur ex eis uermis.	Therefore they are recognized as penetrating by the thing which comes out with the discharge, and by the swelling, when the patient uses the bowels: and sometimes it comes out with worms.
Et sunt ex eis Fistulae quando sunt in spacio penetrantes usque ad uesicam, et usque ad meatum uirgae.	And there are fistulas from these things when they are penetrating from the space until the bladder, and until the membrane of the intestines
Et sunt ex eis penetrantes usque ad iuncturam coxae, et usque ad nodum caudae.	And they are penetrating from these things until the hip joint, and until the node of the buttocks
Ex eo autem quo cognoscitur Fistula penetrans usque ad anum, etiam a non penetrante, est, ut intromittas digitum tuum indicem in anum: et intromittas tentam subtilem in Fistulam ex aere, aut ferro: quando non est tortuositas.	From this it is known that a penetrating fistula until the limb, even if it is not penetrating, is when you insert your finger indicating towards the limb: and you insert a subtle attempt into the fistula from the air, or from iron, when there is no distortion
Quod si in ea est tortuositas, tunc intromitte in eam tentam ex plumbo subtilem, aut pilum ex pilis equarum, donec sentias tentam, aut pilum in digito tuo.	When there is distortion in this, then insert into the fistula a subtle lead weight, or a hair from a horse's tail, until you feel the attempt, or a hair in your finger
Quod si non sentis ipsam penitus, neque procedit ex foramine aliquid ex egestione, neque uentositas, neque uermis sicut dixi: tunc scias, quia est non penetrans: propera ergo ad curationem.	If you do not feel the attempt, neither does anything come out of the discharge, neither swelling, nor worms as I have said: then you know that it is not penetrating: depart therefore for treatment.
Et quando Fistula est penetrans usque ad uesicam, aut ad meatum urinae: tunc significatio eius est exitus urinae ex ea, et prohibitio eius ab hoc ut consolidetur locus cum medicinis.	And when the fistula is penetrating until the bladder, or until the membrane of the urine: then the meaning of this is the escape of urine from it, and the prohibition of this from happening again so that the place is consolidated with the doctors.
Si uero est penetrans usque ad iuncturam coxae, aut ad os coxae: tunc signum eius est, quod perueniat tenta usque illuc, si non est in ea tortuositas usque ad os: et inuentio doloris in circumitu partis, et quod egreditur pus ex ea semper: et quod non ualeat in ea medicatio, neque consolidatur cum unguento.	If the wound extends up to the hip joint or the hip bone: then its sign is that the limb hangs limp until that point, if there is no curvature of the limb up to the bone. And there is pain around the part, and discharge of pus from it always. And it does not heal in it, neither is it consolidated with oil.
Et in istis Fistulis omnibus penetrantibus non est curatio omnino: et curatio earum est labor et uanitas ei, ex stultis medicis, super quem formatur.	In all such penetrating wounds there is no cure; the cure for them is toil and perseverance, from the stupid doctors who cause them.</start_of_turn>
In illa autem quae non est penetrans, et non antiqua, speratur sanatio cum serro: secundum quod ego narro tibi, et ego iam probaui: et est, ut iaceat infirmus inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et eleua crura eius usque supra coxas ipsius, et coxae eius sint inclinatae ad uentrem ipsius.	But in those which are neither penetrating nor old, healing is expected with rest: as I have said before, and as I have shown: that the patient should lie between your hands on his back, and raise his legs up to above his hips, and that his knees should be bent towards his belly.</start_of_turn>
Deinde intromittetentam plumbi, aut aeris, si est in Fistula tortuositas, donec scias ubi peruenit tenta.	Then introduce lead or air, if there is curvature of the wound, until you know where the limb hangs limp.</start_of_turn>
Si autem sentit eam infirmus circa anum, tunc oportet ut intromittas digitum tuum indicem in anum.	If, however, the patient feels pain around the part, then you must insert your finger into the part.</start_of_turn>
