Then apply ligatures with sharp instruments: and introduce these until you have reached the depth of the fistula which you recognized with the iron: do this as many times as necessary, until the acute medicine has eaten away everything that remains in the depth of the fistula from corruption
Deinde restaura ipsam cum unguentis quae generant carnem sanam, donec sanetur.	Then restore the part with the bandages which generate healthy flesh, until it is healed.
Si uero non sanatur per illud, tunc cauteriza ipsam secundum quod narrauimus.	If, however, it does not heal by this, then cauterize it as we have narrated.
Si ergo caussa Fistulae est os, et certificatur apud te illud: tunc inquire ipsum, et seca ipsum secundum quod narraui tibi: si non prohibet te aliquid ex uena, aut neruo, aut membro principali, sicut diximus.	If, however, the cause of the fistula is bone, and you suspect this: then inquire about it, and dissect it as we have narrated: if it does not prevent you anything from the bone, or the nerve, or the principal limb, as we have said
Si ergo detegitur tibi os, et est in eo quiddam corruptionis, et nigredinis: tunc rade ipsum, donec auferatur corruptio eius tota.	If, however, in it you discover bone, and there is something of corruption and blackness: then burn it out, until the corruption of it is entirely removed
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with that which nourishes it, until it is healed
Quod si non sanatur, et emittat pus sicut faciebat: tunc scias, quod tu non peruenisti ad totam eradicationem corruptionis.	Which if it does not heal, and emits pus like before: then you know that you have not reached the entire eradication of the corruption.
Detege ergo super illud secundo, et exquisite fac rasionem eius, et mundificationem ipsius cum ultima fortitudine tua.	Discover further on this, and make an investigation of it, and dissect it with the greatest skill you can muster.
Deinde restaura ipsum.	Then restore it.
Si ergo sanatur, bonum est: et si non, tunc scias quod illa corruptio est in profunditate longinqua corporis, quam non es consecutus.	If, however, it heals, it is good: and if not, then you know that this corruption is in great depth of the body, which you have not been able to overcome
Non est ergo tibi in ea ingenium, nisi dimittere ipsam naturae.	No force is there in that thing in the body, except that which it itself sends out.
Quod si corruptum est os paruum, et est possibile tibi, attrahe ipsum cum forficibus subtilibus quae conueniunt ad illud.	If the bone of the limb is corrupted, and you can reach it, draw it out with fine forceps which fit to it
Si autem sunt ossa multa, tunc exquisite fac attractionem eorum omnium, neque dimittas ex eis aliquid cum tua fortitudine.	If there are many bones, then you must make an incision of all of them, and do not send anything out with your hand.
Si uero contrarietatem facit tibi aliquid ex humiditatibus, et non est in incisione eorum timor, uel error: tunc incide illas humiditates et carnes, si sunt illic, et libera ossa.	If anything opposes you from making an incision, and there is no fear of error in the incision, then you must make an incision of the humors and the flesh there, and free the bones.
Si uero non est tibi praeparatio auferendi ossa ex hora tua, tunc pone super uulnus quod putrefaciat ipsum: et dimitte ipsum, donec putrefiat quod est in circumitu illorum ossium ex carnibus et humiditatibus.	If indeed you are not prepared to extract the bone at this hour, then put over it something which will putrefy it: and send it away, until it is putrefied from the flesh and humors surrounding the bones.
Et custodi uulnus ut non consolidetur.	And keep the wound closed so that it does not swell up.
Et constringatur sectio quam tu secuisti in operatione tua.	And let the incision be as small as you made it in your operation
Imo pone super ipsum, si times, cotum submersum sulfure trito cum oleo: aut cotum submersum in unguento aegyptio, aut aliquo unguentorum uiridium.	And put over it, if you wish, sulfur pounded with oil: or immerse it in Egyptian unguent or in some other unguent of your choice
Nam quando putrefient illae scilicet humiditates, et separantur ex eis ossa, alleuiatur ablatio eorum, et ipsorum attractio.	For when the humors are putrefied and separated from the bones, the pain will cease, and their attraction will cease also
Si autem est os unum magnum, sicut os cruris, aut os coxae, et similia illis, et quod ex eo corruptum est, est pars magna: tunc rade ipsum rasione ultima, donec auferatur illa nigredo et corruptio.	If indeed there is a great bone, such as the shin or the thigh, and the like of them, which is corrupted, it is a great part: then cut away that part finally, until the blackness and corruption are gone from it.
Deinde restaura uulnus.	Then close the wound.
Si uero quod est in eo corruptum, est pars magna, et corruptio iam consecuta est medullam ossis, tunc necesse est serrare ipsum, et incidere ipsum totum usque ad locum, ubi peruenit corruptio: tunc cura ipsum, donec consolidetur.	If indeed that which is in it is corrupted, is a great part, and the corruption has already penetrated the marrow of the bone, then it is necessary to amputate it, and cut through it entirely until the corruption has ceased: then care for it, until it is healed
Et ego narro tibi zuken, quae accidit uiro in crure suo: ut ponas ipsam exemplum et adiutorium super operationem tuam.	And I shall tell you about the swelling which happens in the leg: in order that you may take it as an example and an aid in your operation.
Fuit uir iuuenis aetate circiter triginta annos, cui accidit dolor in crure suo, a caussa quae mota est super ipsum intra corpus, id est, ab interioribus, donec peruenerunt materiae ad crus, et apostematum est apostemate magno: et non fuit ei caussa extrinseca.	A youth of about thirty years of age suffered pain in his leg, due to something that had moved within his body, that is, from the inside outwards, until it reached the leg, and there remained a large swelling: there was no external cause for it.
Extensum est ergo cum eo tempus cum errore medicorum, donec apertum est apostema, et concurrerunt cum eo materiae multae.	It has been prolonged for a long time with the error of the doctors, until the swelling was opened, and many materials came out with it
Et postposita est curatio eius, donec fistulatum est crus, et facta sunt in eo orificia multa: quae omnia emittebant pus, et humiditates corporis.	And after that, his cure was completed, until the limb was bandaged, and many holes were made in it: from which all sorts of pus and moisture came out of the body
Curauit ergo ipsum multitudo medicorum circiter duos annos, et non fuit in eo sapiens in arte manus, donec uocatus sum, et uidi crus eius, et materias quae currebant ex illis orificiis cursu magno: etiam omne uiri corpus iam tabuerat, et color eius citrinus erat.	He was treated by many doctors for about two years, and there was no skill in their art of hand, until I came, and I washed the leg and the materials which came out of the holes were great: even all the flesh of the limb had been wasted, and its color was yellow
Intromisi ergo tentam in uno locorum orificiorum, et peruenit tenta ad os.	They introduced it into one of the holes, and the attempt reached the bone.
Deinde perscrutatus sum orificia omnia: et inueni ea peruenire ad se inuicem ex omnibus partibus cruris.	Then I examined all the holes: and I found that they all went deep into the leg from all parts of the limb
Properaui ergo, et secui super unum illorum orificiorum, donec detexi partem ossis: et inueni ipsum corruptum: quod iam corrosum erat, et denigratum, et putruerat, et perforatum erat, donec penetrauerat usque ad medullam.	I proceeded accordingly, and I closed one of the holes, until I reached a part of the bone: and I found it corrupted: it was rotten, discolored, and putrefying, and had a hole in it, until it had penetrated as far as the marrow
Serraui ergo quod detectum est mihi, et praeparatum ex osse corrupto.	I saw what had been detected by me, and prepared from the corrupted bone
Et deputaui, quod non esset in osse nisi illa corruptio, quam abscidi, et serraui.	And I concluded that there was no soundness in the bone except for that corruption, which I cut off and removed
Et ego iam eradicaueram eam.	I have eradicated it.
Deinde posui restaurationem uulneris cum medicinis consolidatiuis spacio longo.	Then I shall institute the restoration of the wound with the physicians consolidated in a wide space.
Et non est consolidatum.	It is not consolidated
Deinde tentaui, et detexi super os secundo supra detectionem primam: et inueni corruptionem continuam cum osse: et serraui quod apparuit mihi etiam ex illa corruptione.	Then I tried, and I found above the first detection: and I found a continuous corruption with the bone: and I saw that it had also appeared from that corruption
Deinde conatus sum restaurationem eius.	Then I attempted to restore it
Et non est restauratum.	It is not restored
Detexi ergo super ipsum iterum, et non cessaui incidere os particulatim, et conari restaurationem eius: et non est restauratum, donec incidi ex osse circiter palmum unum, et extraxi illud cum medulla sua.	I found it again above that: and I did not cease to cut the bone piecemeal, and to try to restore it: and it is not restored, until I cut from the bone almost a palm's breadth, and I extracted that with the marrow itself
Deinde restauraui ipsum cum medicinis, et consolidatum est uelociter, et sanatum: et non fuit necessaria haec iteratio in operatione eius, et sectione ipsius, nisi propter dispositionem debilitatis infirmi, et paucitatem tolerantiae eius, et timorem meum super ipsum de morte: quoniam accidebat ei in omnibus horis ex superfluitate euacuationis syncopis mala.	Then I restored it with the physicians, and it was consolidated quickly, and healed: and it was not necessary for this repetition in the operation of this, and the section of itself, except for the disposition of the infirmity of the patient, and his small tolerance, and my fear of death for him: because it was happening to him in every hour from the excessive evacuation of the bad humors
Sanatus est ergo sanatione integra: et nata est in loco ossis caro dura, et bona facta est dispositio in corpore suo, et rediit uirtus eius: et conuersatus est in dispositionibus suis: et non fecit ei contrarietatem in ambulatione nocumentum omnino.	He is healed thus by complete healing: and it has become in the place of the hard bone, and a good disposition has been made in his body, and the strength has returned to him: and he has recovered his former state: and he has not suffered any discomfort in walking or sleeping ever since
Si autem os eminens in loco corporis iam fractum est: tunc oportet ut serres ipsum, secundum hunc modum: et est: ut accipias ligamentum, et stringe ipsum in extremitate ossis eminentis: et praecipe alicui, qui extendat ipsum ad sursum: et pone ligamentum aliud ex lana grossius ligamento primo.	If however the prominent bone in the body is fractured: then it is necessary to bind it up according to this method: and it is that you take a ligament, and bind the bone at the extremity of the prominent bone: and command someone to extend it upwards: and put another ligament of a greater thickness than the first ligament.
Deinde liga ipsum super carne, quae est suh osse: et extende extremitatem eius, ut trahas carnem ad inferiora: et tu detegis carnem super locum quem uis serrare, ut non laedat Serra carnem.	Then bind up the limb above the flesh which is upon the bone: and stretch out its extremity, so that you may draw the flesh downwards: and you will see the flesh above the place which you wish to cut, so that it does not damage the flesh.
Pone lignum, aut tabulam sub osse inferius decenter: quoniam quando facis illud, non prohibetur quin secet carnem corruptam.	Place a stick, or a board under the lower bone in the center: because when you make this, it does not hinder that the flesh is cut through which is spoiled
Et oportet ut sit Serratura super locum corruptum parumper, ut non sit in concauitate ossis corruptio: et non appareat in apparitione sua sensui, et cogat ad Serraturam sui uice alia.	It is necessary that the suture be above the spoiled place rather than in the concavity of the broken bone: and that it should not appear in its vision to the patient, and should cause no pain to him concerning the suture of his wound
Quod si os est corruptum, et non est eminens, imo continuatur pars eius cum parte: et corruptio est in medio eius, aut in parte ipsius: tunc detege carnem ab omnibus partibus totam.	If the bone is spoiled and is not prominent, continue its part with its part: and the corruption is in the middle of it, or in the part itself: then draw out the flesh from all parts of it whole
Deinde pone lignum inferius.	Then place a stick below.
Postea serra illud ex parte prima, ubi est corruptio, donec continuetur Serratura ex parte altera: et sit Serratura secundum longitudinem a corruptione parumper, secundum quod diximus.	Then cut it from the first part where the corruption is, until the suture is completed from the other side: and let the suture be according to the length of the corruption, as we have said
Quod si corruptio est in iunctura, incide ipsam iuncturam corruptam, et serra os ubi continuatur ex parte altera.	If the corruption is in the joint, cut through the spoiled joint, and cut the bone where the other side continues.
Si uero corruptio est in continuatione duarum iuncturarum, tunc non est in ea ingenium nisi abrasio.	If indeed the corruption is in the continuation of two joints, then it is not in this place except for abrasion.
Quod si corruptio est in pectine manus, aut in pectine pedis: tunc res in eo est difficilis ualde.	If the corruption is in the palm of the hand, or in the palm of the foot: then the matter is difficult to deal with.
Verum oportet, ut inquiras corruptionem qualiter appareat tibi.	It is necessary to inquire concerning the nature of the corruption.
Et abradas eam, et mundes ipsam secundum quamcunque dispositionem tibi possibile est, et cum quocunque ingenio rectificatur tibi: quando non facit tibi contrarietatem Vena, aut Neruus.	And scrape the wound, and cleanse it according to whatever method you are able, and with whatever skill you can: when it does not cause you to be in contradiction to the Vein, or the Nerve.
Et scias quod incisoria, et Serrae ad incidendum ista ossa sunt multa, secundum situm ossium, et praparationem eorum, et ipsorum grossitudinem, et subtilitatem eorum, et magnitudinem, et paruitatem ipsorum, et duriciem ipsorum, et eorum raritatem.	And you know that the incisors and the molars for cutting down these bones are many, according to the position of the bones, their preparation, their size, their flexibility, their magnitude, and their quantity.
Quapropter oportet, ut praepares omni speciei operationis instrumentum conueniens ad illam operationem.	Therefore it is necessary to prepare an instrument suitable for each kind of operation for that operation.
Et scias, quod operationes istae significant tibi super speciem instrumenti quo indiges, quando tecum est studium longum.	And you know that these operations are significant to you above the kind of instrument which you do not know when you have studied for a long time.
Et cognitio modorum huius artis, testimonium modorum aegritudinum: tunc enim iam inuenies per teipsum illud quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis ad omnem infirmitatem.	And the knowledge of the ways of this art is a testimony to the ways of knowledge: for then you will find for yourself that which is suitable for it from the instruments for all diseases.
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	I am firm in the last of this chapter concerning the number of instruments which I place as examples of those which you will encounter, and the test which you will experience with others.
Forma Serrae.	The form of the molars.
Forma alterius Serrae.	The form of the other molars
Forma Serrae alterius.	The shape of the other molars
Forma Serrae alterius.	The shape of the molars is like that of the incisors, but it is broader and more flexible.
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	This shape of the molars is made with the edge facing downwards.
Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	Its arch is towards the upper part, its edge is of iron: and its handle is of boxwood, and it is made in the shape of a pyramid with the edge facing downwards
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	The shape of the cutting instruments
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	The head of this instrument is like the head of a star-shaped key: and its points are like the points of a nail.
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	It does not fit unless it is rubbed against it with the head of the cutting instruments when it is broken, or when the bone is large and great
Forma maioris Rasorii.	Greatness of the wound.
Forma medii Rasorii.	Middling greatness of the wound
Forma Rasorii lati.	Small greatness of the wound.
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	Wound of slight concavity
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	Wound of great concavity
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	Wound of extreme concavity at the margins
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	Wound of very small greatness, slight tension
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	Wound involving a bone fragment.
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	Wound of great greatness also
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	This is like a wound caused by a knife, and the edges are like a saw: it appears in many places because of the cause of the fractured bones.
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	The greatness of the wound is in accordance with the extent of the perforation caused by the bones
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	The edges are triangular, the extremities are acute
Fit ex Indi.	Like that from India
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	And in the same way, it is necessary to consider all the wounds, cuts, and saw-like injuries
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	Regarding the incision of the extremities and the stitching of bones
Caput LXXXIX.	Chapter 89.
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	The extremities putrefy, either by an external cause or an internal one.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	When you have treated the cause of the putrefaction with medicines and it does not heal: and if the putrefaction has spread to the limb without causing any effect, you must then cut off the limb until the point at which the putrefaction stops. Thus the patient is saved from death or from the greater defect of the limb
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	And the sign of this is that the limb becomes pale, until it turns black: for fire burns it, or it becomes putrified after it has become black. Until such putrefaction has spread throughout the body
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	Properly therefore when the incision is made, and similarly if the cause of the corruption is from a blow which has struck some of the veins: such as a scorpion's sting, and spiders, and worms, and things of that kind.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	If there is corruption, or the blow has struck at the extremity of the finger, then incise the finger and not the space of the corruption, so that it reaches until the remaining hand
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	And similarly if it happens in the hand, then incise from the root of the bone, and not the space of the corruption, until it reaches the wrist bone
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	And if it comes to that, then incise the arm at the elbow in its joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	But if the corruption has passed, and you see it around the elbow: then that is the mark of the disease.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And as for treatment beyond this, it is the quantity of the remedy.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	And do the same with the foot, when the corruption comes to the finger, then incise it at one of the joints: and if it reaches the heel bone, then incise the whole foot.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	If it comes to the knee, then incise the thigh at the knee joint
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	When the corruption has gone beyond the knee, then it is not in it, except for amputation, and leave the diseased limb to die.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	And as for the mode of incising the limb, or leaving it, it is like this, that you string the ligaments below, which you wish to incides: and string the other ligament above the place.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	And stretch out one ligament downwards: and stretch out the other ligament upwards
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	And you separate the flesh which is between the two ligaments, with a broad spatula, until the whole flesh is separated
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then it either advances or retreats.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	Therefore, one must take from all parts of the wound the amount of linen that does not touch the healthy area: and when it has advanced, the wound becomes more inflamed and the swelling becomes greater.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	If, however, blood flows inwards during the operation, then cauterize the place quickly: or put over it some powder that absorbs blood
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Then return to your medicine until it is complete.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bandage the wounded limb with the bandage that is suitable for it, and care for it until it heals
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I tell you what happened in my foot, that is what I tell you
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	That is, because it happened in my foot during a journey, with a burning sensation that assimilated with the fire: and the corruption first occurred in my finger, until the whole foot was affected
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	He therefore went away from it by himself after he had cut away the corruption from the limb because of the pain and the burning sensation: and he put it at the juncture and it healed
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	And when a long time had passed, the same corruption occurred in the thumb of his hand.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	He came to me and I attempted to recover the swelling with the methods which I use on the other patients after I had treated his body: and the swelling did not disappear, but it began to advance to another finger. And the corruption spread to the hand
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	He called me to amputate his hand: and I did not do it, hoping that the swelling would subside: and I feared that if I made an incision in his hand he would die
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	Because the force of the man was great over the case.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	When he had given up hope of me, he returned to his land: and he came to me again because he had heard that I had been cured. And he threw himself upon my hand whole: and he was healed.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	And do not heed this narration except as an aid concerning that which has fallen from the kind of this ailment: and as a signification which signifies, and according to how it is done.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	Of the care of joints, and the quality of blistering with the physicians.
Caput XC.	Chapter 90.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	When swelling happens in some limb with pain, and the space of the swelling is prolonged, until it makes collection of the healing: then it is broken, or pierced, and what is in it is removed from the healing, and the place which was swelling is left as though it were a hollow space: and the skin which is over it is like a thin membrane which has been stretched: and it does not reach the end in its corruption, neither does it reach the bone, nor the nerve, nor the ligament: it deserves to be called a Sinus: and it is not called a Fistula, until its space is prolonged, until corruption is made in some part of the limb, then it is called a Fistula, or swelling
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	And its care is that you cut the whole skin as it is twisted: and especially when it is stretched thin, like a membrane: and trust that it will not adhere to the place because of its corruption
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	If, however, you hope that the skin will adhere, and this does not result from this corruption: and if there is thickening in the skin from the flesh, then cure it with blistering: and it is like considering the Sinus
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	Then if it is great, and the pus which comes out of it has a foul smell: then blister it with Egyptian medicine, which is vinegar, and oil, and resin, equal parts, mixed together: and boil them over a fire, until the medicine boils: and bring in the spissitude of honey
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	Then take from this what is necessary: dissolve it with water and honey, and instill it with vinegar: and tighten its orifice, and send the medicine into it for two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	Then extract it with pressure: do this for several days until the sinus is healed, and the stench is gone.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	And when it is instilled with vinegar and water, when it is not in the presence of this medicine: take vinegar of wood ashes, or vinegar from the wood of ilic: and sprinkle it over the water
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	Then rest it, and instill it with this, until you are confident that the sinus has been evacuated
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	If the patient does not tolerate the Egyptian medicine, neither vinegar or water, then instill it with water and honey, to which something of ground cinnamon has been added
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	Or instill it with honey and wine mixed together, for honey has the property of healing and softening: and the wine makes the sinus adhere, especially when there is an excess of astringency and dryness in it
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	When you have done this several times, and are confident that the corruption of the sinus has passed away: then instill it with something that makes new flesh grow in it.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	And it is good to take from alum of Daphne: and dissolve it with rose water and wine: or instill it with some medicine, and anoint with others, of whose properties are written in the treatise on unguents.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	If the orifice of the sinus is narrow, in which the cannula of the syringe will not pass: then widen it with a small iron: or put in the cavity something softened in Egyptian unguent, or in aloes, until it is widened.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	If the orifice is wide, join its lips together with suture and discharge the amount which enters the fistula without adding.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	If pus flows from the orifice, elevate it to the upper parts: then dry it in the recess where it is, so that it flows downwards: for pus, when contained in depth, hinders the generation of flesh in it
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	If it is not possible to dry the fistula below, try to prepare the limb with a preparation which will allow the pus to flow out easily as it is prepared
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	Try that nothing of the pus remains in it: and take solidifying medicines which are placed over the sign, suitable for this purpose.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	And spread them over a layer of linen.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	And let the linen be of such quantity as to cover the whole fistula.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	Then cut through in the middle of the orifice of the fistula with scissors, widening the orifice of the fistula somewhat.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then spread out fine sponges over the other linen, according to the size of the hole: and put it over the fistula in a long position away from the orifice of the fistula, so as to relieve the discharge of pus from it: and do not make the linen too large, except after a few days or so once
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	But he who is over the orifice of the fistula should move in every hour, so that what accumulates in it from the pus may go out: and you will know whether it is much or little, digested or indigested
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And thus consider again the place of the fistula itself, whether the master of the house feels pain there, or whether there is pain there, or whether there is swelling there, or not
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	When the remedy has been applied in this way, and you see that the material which exudes from the orifice of the Sinus has ceased, then you know that the Sinus is adhered, or is close to adhesion: then you must solve it in the palm of your hand, or on the third day. And when you have solved it, then change the bandage and renew the unguentum.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	But if it continues to exude from the Sinus for a long space of time with a fine discharge, then do not despair of adhesion, for its healing approaches, because there are men who are slow to generate flesh in their wounds, and there are those who act contrariwise to this.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	But if it continues to exude from the Sinus for many days, pus which is indigested, then you know that the Sinus is not adhered
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	If, however, the adhesion of the Sinus is delayed and its condition is prolonged: then add to the medication, truly the physicians will make the medicine moist in its substance and dry in its nature: like unguentum dyafinicon, when added to it makes the excess moist.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And from the last thing which is to be done, that is to take unguentum dyafinicon and dissolve it with rosewater, and return over the old liquid equal in quantity to its substance.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Then mix it with this and use it thus.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	It does the same thing as this, when it is not present there, honey, when you boil it until it thickens, until it is consumed, and you use it with this
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Or take myrrh, aloes, and olibanum: mix them all together, and grind that up over honey while it is over the fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Then smear upon the bandage, and bind it over the Sinus: and smear with the honey which you have boiled until it is consumed: and grind over it the spices, and put upon the bandage, and bind it.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	When such aristolochia, long roots of lilies of the heavens, lilies, herb seeds, and centaurea are administered together,
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	When these simples are used together, either simple or combined, and there is bleeding, let there be pounded salt on the wound, and use it on the pulse.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	If the condition of the sinus persists and does not heal with this treatment: then you know that there is corruption in its depth: either that it makes an imprint on the bones, or on the tough parts of the limb, or the ligaments: then treat it by fistula, as mentioned before.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	Concerning the care of panaritium and nails that have become detached, and the incision of the digit added, and the section of it.
Caput XCI.	Chapter 101.
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	Panaritium is a swelling that occurs under the nail of the thumb or finger, or perhaps in the other digits.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	When it persists, and is neglected, it becomes inflamed and pus is emitted, until the root of the nail is corroded: and perhaps the whole nail is broken, and perhaps the corruption reaches the bone, and there is a foul odor: and the digit becomes swollen and its color becomes dark.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	When you treat it as we have said, and it does not improve: then it is necessary to cut off the entire superabundance that remains from the nail with a knife
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	Then burn the nail afterwards
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	A cautery is useful for these things when the iron is cold.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	If indeed the bone is sound, and the nail is also sound, and the nails have become loose and penetrate the flesh: then you must place radium under the nail at an angle so that it will touch the flesh, and push it up: and cut the flesh easily, and put on what remains of the flesh from the physicians who have burned and corroded it until it is gone
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	If, however, corruption has already set in the bone, then it is necessary to cut away the bone and extract it: for it will not heal as long as the corrupt part remains in it.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	If you see corrosion and corruption advancing in a finger, then cut through it at one joint, as has been mentioned previously concerning its reminder.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	If, however, an attrition or percussion should happen to the nail, and there is pain in this, then it is necessary to bleed the diseased part at first.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	Then dry the nail with a sharp spatula from above downwards to the edge.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	And take care, lest the cutting should reach the flesh under the nail, for thereby you will cause the addition of pain to the diseased part, and that is the cause of the rotting of the flesh in that place
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	Then care for the place with that which sits upon the pain.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	The finger which is born among the hands of men, perhaps is entirely fleshy: perhaps there is in some of them a bone, and perhaps in that is the nail: and some of them are born in the root of the joint, or that is the origin of them in some part of the finger
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	He who is born in some part of the finger does not move: and he who is born near the joint of the finger, perhaps does move
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	He who is born of flesh is easily cut away
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	That is, as you would cut away the nail with a wide spatula
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	The treatment of the condition whose origin is in the root of the junction is difficult.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	Avoid therefore incision of the same.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	In that case where it originates in the finger at the end of the bones, then it is necessary to cut through the flesh in a circular fashion from the beginning of the bone down to the bone itself
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	And then cut the bone with one saw that fits to it
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then treat the wound until it heals
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	Consolidation however which happens to the finger at the joint, often happens either by natural cause of the man, that is, it is born with it, or from the consolidation of the wound, or from burning of fire, and the like.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	It is necessary therefore to separate that consolidation, until the finger returns to its natural shape
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	Then put between the bones ligatures, or soaked sponges in boiled oil: so that they do not solidify too quickly, and separate the bones: or put between the bones a thin sheet of lead, until the place is consolidated according to what is necessary
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	And in the same way if consolidation happens to any finger with the palm, then dry up that consolidation, according to what is prepared and convenient for the figure of the limb.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	¶ On the Incision of Wounds.
Caput XCII.	Chapter XCII.
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	There are veins which are involved, large, full of melancholic superfluities which happen in various parts of the body: and most of the time their event is in the legs, especially in the legs of those who are engaged in travel and work, and those who carry burdens.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	It is necessary therefore to manage the swelling of the body from black bile somewhat by evacuation.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	Then the physician shall take the patient's pulse with ease.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	Treatment of these with iron is in two ways.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	One of these is to cauterize and draw out black blood.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	The other is to raise the vein and draw out all of it.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	The cutting of these is in this way.
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	The patient should be bathed with warm water, and the thick blood should be resolved until it becomes like mud
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	Then bind the limb of the patient from the upper part of the thigh down to the lower part of the knee with oil
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	Then cut the vein in one place, or two, or three wide sections
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	Then raise up, that is, draw out blood from the lower part of the leg up to the top, and from the top pour it out so that the patient receives the phlebotomy at the beginning
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	Then dry the blood until there remains just as much as is needed for the treatment, and as the patient can tolerate the pain of the wound
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	Then bind the limb: and command him to abstain from food that generates black bile: and repeat the evacuation and phlebotomy when the veins are filled, and this will be good for the patient
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	The elevation of these is in this way
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	If there are many hairs in the limb, shave them off
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	Then immerse the limb in a bath: or cauterize the limb in the leg with warm water, until it turns red, and swell the veins: or perform an exercise of force, if there is no bath present, until the limb is warmed up
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	Then dry the skin in the direct vicinity of the area to be cut: either at the end of it near the knee, or at the lower part of it near the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	Then open the skin with scissors, and scrape the area thoroughly, until sensation is restored: and it is when sensation returns that you know that you have rubbed away the redness to the blackness
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	When the blood has drained from the wound, you know that the wound has bled as much as it will.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	Then introduce beneath it radium, until it rises and comes out of the skin: suspend it with a cautery needle, fine hair
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	Then dry the other area nearby for three fingers.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	Then scrape the skin from the upper part of the area, until sensation returns.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	Then raise the area with the radium as you did before, and suspend it with another needle as you did before.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	Then dry another area, or several areas, if you wish
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	Then lift up, and make the final incision at the heel
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	Then remove the wound from the area which is above the wound
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	Do all this, until you have removed the wound from the upper section, or from all the higher sections, until when they are all gone: then make the incision.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	But if you do not manage to remove it by lifting and pulling: then introduce a needle with a strong thread, and tie the wound, and pull it out: or introduce radium under it: and move your hand over the whole area, until it comes out
Et caue, ne incidatur.	Take care not to make any further incisions
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	If it happens, it is difficult for thee to lift him up again, and it enters over the patient from this document.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	When you have pulled out all of it: then put over the place of the wound a soaked bandage of wool in wine and rose oil, or oil: and care for him, until he is healed.</start_of_turn>
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	If the vein is contracted, having a twist to which the parts are twisted, and is not as we have said according to the rule: then it is necessary to find over the vein on all parts the twist of the twist itself.</start_of_turn
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	Then suspend the vein with hooks, until you have lifted up all of it: and beware at your incision on the vein above that you do not cut the vein, or wound it: for it is difficult to lift up or extract it.</start_of_turn>
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	Be prudent in this matter.</start_of_turn>
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	The form of the wound which heals the vein.</start_of_turn
Forma Vncini caeci.	The form of the closed wound.</start_of_turn
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	It has no curvature like other veins, neither is it acute at the extremities, as it does not wound the vein: and it is of great flexibility, gentle: for if it were slight, it would wound the vein by its flexibility: or if it were of great thickness, as we have said.</start_of_turn
De extractione Venae cruris.	On the extraction of the thigh vein.</start_of_turn
Caput XCIII.	Chapter XCIII.</start_of_turn>
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	This vein is generated in the thighs in warm lands, like Alizegi, and the land of Arabs, and in dry and warm lands, few in number, that is, in which no herb or tree grows.</start_of_turn
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	And perhaps it is generated in other parts of the body besides the limbs.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	And indeed its generation is from putrefaction which occurs under the skin, as for example worms and serpents within the body, and worms generated between the skin and the flesh.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	And a sign of the commencement of this event is swelling in the limb with heat
Deinde uesicatur locus.	Then the site becomes wet
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	Then the vein begins to depart from that wet place, as if from the root of a plant, or an animal
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	When therefore it appears from that extremity, then it is necessary to cover over the lead with the thumb, which weighs a drachma, up to two drachmas and a node: and let the suspended lead go from the limb.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	Every time therefore that anything comes out from that, cover it with lead and tie it
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	If it is prolonged for a long time, then cut off a part of it, and cover the remainder
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	And do not cut through the root before all of it has gone out
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	For if you cut through it, it contracts, and enters the flesh: and it makes the swelling worse, and generates putrefaction in the place, and a bad ulcer
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	Therefore it is necessary to extract it gently, and gradually, until all of it has gone out of the body: and from this vein comes out in some people which is as long as five palms and ten fingers long
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	And indeed it has come to me, because it has gone out of the body for twenty palms.
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	If, however, it happens that you are seized in the hour of your medication: then introduce radium into the cavity of its body, and perforate it through a long opening, with the body, until all that is in it from the material is evacuated: and administer putrefaction of the place with physicians for a few days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	Then care for the aftercare of the wound.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	And thus the vein often has many branches, especially when it appears in the junction of the foot, or in the foot itself: and it has many outlets, and branches go out from every outlet.</start_of_turn>
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	Care for it accordingly, as we said before, and as is usual.</start_of_turn>
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	With regard to the section above the worms generated under the skin, and it is called bovine disease.</start_of_turn
Caput XCIIII.	Chapter XCIV.</start_of_turn>
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	This disease is called in this land among us bovine disease: because it frequently happens to cattle, and it is a small worm which is born between the skin and the flesh.</start_of_turn
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	It goes through the whole body, ascending and descending: and is perceptible to the sense during its walking from limb to limb, until it ruptures wherever it ruptures in the skin at the place, and comes out.</start_of_turn
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	And its generation is from the putrefaction of some humors.</start_of_turn
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	Just as worms and serpents appear, that is to say, roundworms and tapeworms in the belly.</start_of_turn
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	And they are harmful.</start_of_turn
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	Because when it itself goes into the body, and ascends to the head, and comes to the place: then perhaps it opens there, and comes out, and destroys the eye: and this happens frequently.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	When the will to care for him and extract him exists, it is not done except alongside his walking and the perception of his sense.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	It is necessary therefore that strings be passed both above and below him with strong ligation
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry over him and extract him.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	If it is found deep in the flesh and you do not find it: then place over the place a cautery with fire until it dies
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	And more than that which is feared is the corruption of his eye, as we have said
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	If indeed you see him going toward the head near the eye, then string under it with a strong suture above the eyebrow.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry over him and extract him
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	It is necessary that the patient be treated with the purification of his body, with physicians resolving the harmful humors.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	And beware of foods that generate putrefaction.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	Regarding the incision above the navel of Nakir
Caput XCV.	Chapter XCVI.
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	This ailment is called Nakir in our land: and it is a pain that occurs in some parts of the body: then it changes from limb to limb.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	I myself have seen it, as I have told you
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	I was called to a woman who was sick in some corner of the house
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	And I found her arm swollen and saw a swelling of the marrow in the bone of the arm
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	And after an hour had passed, I saw another swelling grow with a worm, like a worm, ascending to his shoulder more quickly than is possible: so that it was like silver going from place to place
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	The pain has receded from that place and is fixed in the arm.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	Then remain one hour, and it runs through the rest of the body until it reaches the other arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	Then he told me that it was returning throughout its whole body, as I saw.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	I marvel at the swiftness of its change from limb to limb
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	And indeed I did not believe that such an illness could be seen in this way until now
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	But I have seen many who have found the pain change from limb to limb, and I have not seen it with my eyes in a woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	I do not believe this, except that it is because of the moisture of the women of this district: hence hence appears the swelling to be moved about
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	It is necessary that it should not appear in delicate persons and humid bodies, hidden by their secret parts.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	When you see it with your eyes that the pain has returned: then if it appears to you like this, then grasp above and below with more force: and dry above until the swelling has gone away: and cauterize the place.</start_of_turn>
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	If you do not see it with your eyes: then take care of it with the evacuation of the body and with the application of fomentatives with poultices of rue and sage, and similar things.</start_of_turn>
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	(The text continues with a description of treating another medical condition.)</start_of_turn>
Caput XCVI.	(The page number is omitted.)</start_of_turn>
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	Arrows are varied according to their kinds and according to the locations from which they fall from the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	Their variety is indeed great: for some have large teeth, others have small, some are concave and others are convex
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	And some have three angles.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	And those which have tongues
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	And those which have stars
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	These are varied according to the members from which they fall, in two ways.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	Or else the members are from those which are concave in principle, such as the brain, the heart, the spleen, the lung, the kidneys, the intestines, the bladder, and similar parts
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	When therefore it falls into any one of these members, and you see signs of death, which I shall tell you afterwards, then it is necessary to extract that arrow from the body, for death follows its trajectory in many positions.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	And when you do not see these bad signs, and the arrow is not hidden in the depth of the member, then extract it and care for the wound
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	From the signs of the brain, when it falls in that arrow, and pierces the bone, and comes out at the surface of the brain, it is: because from that arise soda that causes vomiting, swelling, vertigo, redness of the eyes, inflation, redness of the tongue, spasm, and mixture of the intellect, and vomiting of bile.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	And perhaps blood comes out of the nostrils or ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	And perhaps the voice is lost, and the will is destroyed.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	And comes out from the wound a white moisture like pus
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	And it comes out like the moisture of meat.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	If, however, this sign appears, then abstain from treatment and draw out the arrow if it does not come out by itself.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	The signs of an arrow lodged in the gut are: when it is close to the left breast: and it feels as though it is fixed in something hard, not in something soft.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	And perhaps the arrow is moved like the beating of a pulse: and it runs out with black blood from the wound
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	And following this there is cold extremity, cold sweat, and fainting
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	You know, therefore, that death approaches with doubt.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	The sign of an arrow when it wounds the lung, is the escape of bloody foam from the wound: and the swelling which follows the chest, subsides and changes the colour of the patient.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	And the great and high spirit expires: and it seeks the attraction of cold air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	If an arrow falls into the diaphragm, which is in the chest: then it is near the lower ribs: and it causes a great sigh with pain, with breathing difficulty, with gasping: and all the arms hang down
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	And if an arrow falls into the stomach: then perhaps it comes out of the wound with some undigested food
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	And if an arrow falls into the belly and is fixed in it: something of stool, or urine, or intestine which has been ruptured comes out of the wound
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	There is no hope in the treatment of this, neither in the extraction of the arrow
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	If an arrow falls into the bladder, and urine comes out: and something goes out from it to the outside, and the pain is more severe over the patient: then you know that this is deadly
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	The remaining members, as the face, neck, belly, spatula, assistant, dorsal spines, fork, hip, thigh, and those similar to them, are treated according to various arrangements: when neither an arrow nor a nerve is found.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	I also say concerning these arrows that you must understand by that your care.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	That is, because I believe that the arrow is hidden by the swelling of the eye or the root of the nose.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	Therefore I extract it from the other side under the fatty substance of his ear: and he was healed, and no wound remained in his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	And I extracted another arrow from a Jew who had it in the fat of his eye under the lower eyelid: and the arrow was hidden, and I did not find its tip until I had broken its bow: it was a large arrow of the Turks, with lead, in which there were no ears.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	He was healed therefore, and no evil happened to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	And I extracted another arrow from the belly of a Christian.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	It was an Arabian arrow, and these are those which have ears
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	And I found it between two ribs: and it was buried deep in his belly
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	I was careful with it until I had extracted it: and the Christian was healed.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	And I extracted another which had been buried in his bowels: and we thought that he would die from it.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	After these things happened to him for thirty days, and there was no change in his condition concerning the arrow, we believed that he would recover: and we treated him, and extracted the arrow: and he was healed, and no evil happened to him
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	And immediately he who was struck by the arrow in his back, and the bone was consolidated above it.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	And after seven years, the arrow came out from the root of his thigh bone.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	And immediately she who was struck by the arrow in her belly, and the bone was consolidated above it, and the arrow remained inside her: and no change appeared in her condition from her former habits, and the woman did not suffer from any aftereffects of her natural operations.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	And immediately another man who was struck by an arrow on his face, and the bone was consolidated, and the arrow remained, without causing him much pain: and similar things happened to many others
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	And I extracted an arrow from the king's face, which had struck him in the middle of his nose, and which had inclined towards the right side below: and the arrow was completely hidden
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	I was called to his care after the arrow wound for three days.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	I found the arrow wound quite tight above the bone
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	I asked him [the patient] whether he felt any pain under the skin, and he himself confirmed that he felt pain and swelling from the right side around the wound
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	I hoped that this was the mark of the arrow's exit wound.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	I plastered the place with absorbent and adhesive plaster, trusting that the wound would heal, and that the sign of the arrow would disappear on the surface: and it did not happen in the place of the wound as if the arrow had followed its course.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	I continued to pack the wound with plaster for many days: and it did not happen that the accident occurred, and the bone consolidated in the meantime: and he remained unable to extract the arrow until one day he felt the arrow within his nose
Et narrauit mihi illud.	He told me that.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	And he related to me that.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	Moreover, in the opening of the wound by means of that acute medicine, until it became visible to us the extremity of the arrow: and we passed over that period of time about four months.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	When the wound had healed, and we were able to insert forceps into it, and move it, and it did not emerge: then we did not desist from boring under the nail, and devised ways to manage above it like skilled people, until we put an end to it on a certain day with forceps which had been made crooked, as it happened in the end of the chapter, until we extracted the arrow from it.
