Deinde restauraui uulnus.	The wound was restored.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And the physicians say that the cartilage of the nose is not restored
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	We restored it, and the wound became firm and healed completely: and nothing remained of the illness.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I tell you the kind of extraction of arrows which I have seen: so that you may know the rule and the signification of it concerning this matter which I have not mentioned
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	For the parts of this art and their distinctions are not comprehended by the narration: neither does this book comprehend them, nor does the skillful craftsman compare them with little to much: and with regard to that which is present, there is little of it, while that which is absent is much; and he has found a new operation and an instrument among the descent of these things in this art when they arise
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I say, therefore, that arrows do not emerge from the members in which they are fixed, except according to two methods.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Or by attraction from the place from whence it came in.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or otherwise from the opposite side.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And that which goes out from whence it came in, or that is a bow proceeding in a fleshy place: and it is attracted and goes out.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	If it does not obey the exit at the hour when it fell: then it is necessary that you omit it for some days, until the carrion that is around it is putrefied: and the attraction of it will be diminished, and its egress will cease
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And in like manner if it is fixed in bone, and does not obey you at the exit, then omit it also for some days: and do it again every day with the attraction and motion until it comes out
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	If it does not obey you at the exit after days: then it is necessary that you perforate around the bow in the very bone from all sides with a fine thread, until the bow be increased
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then draw it out, and draw out the thing itself.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	If however the bow is fixed in the head of the bone, and is proceeding in one of the ventricles of the brain, and appears from the diseased parts some of those things which I have mentioned: then abstain from the attraction of the bow and draw it out, until it be equal to its former state after days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if the bow persists to the soft parts, then its decay will not be prolonged.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the bow is not fixed except in the body of the bone, and does not penetrate as far as the soft parts: and remains diseased for some days, and nothing happens to it from those things: then think of the attraction of the bow and its extraction
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	If however it is fixed above, and does not obey you in the attraction: then manage the surrounding of the bow as I have said: then care for the place, until it be healed
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	If, however, the arrow is hidden in a body part and is concealed and hidden from sight: then inquire concerning it with a hook.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	If you suspect that it is there, then draw it out with some instrument that is suitable for its attraction.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	If, however, you are unable to see beyond it because of the constriction of the wound and because of the length of the arrow in its depth: and there is no bone, no nerve, or blood vessel there: then find above it until the wound is widened, and only then can the arrow be extracted.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	If there are veins which are held by it, then loosen the flesh fixed in the wound from all sides, by all means which you can think of, and contort them, if it is not possible to remove the flesh from the fracture of the ears, and the twisting of the ears, until it escapes
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	And when you are administering the extraction of the arrow from whatever place it is in, then use the twisting of your hand with forceps to all parts, until you make the arrow escape: and with the last little force, so that the arrow does not break, and so that its extraction is easier for you
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	If you are unable to remove it at one time, then leave it for a few days, until the surrounding parts have become putrid
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then repeat the process: for it will be useful to you that it does not cause the flow of blood. Then administer what we have said about the care in its chapter: and guard your virtue from the incision of the vein, or nerve, or cord.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	And administer skill in every way that you can in order to extract the arrow: and do it with ease, and tranquility, or slowly, and firmly, as I have told you
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	And it is necessary that you do this while you are pulling out the arrow, so that the patient is like the image of the arrow as it is in the case of the arrow in itself.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	How great is the blessing.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	If this is not possible, then do what you can from the things that are possible to you.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	An arrow which proceeds from the opposite side, or which proceeds from that to the exterior, either makes a swelling at the end of the arrow which is near the skin, and brings up pus: dry therefore over the pus, and cut according to the quantity which they take in that force-ps
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then draw out the arrow: for itself becomes easy to come out.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	If indeed it is retained in the bone, then twist your hand according to the circumference, until you press the arrow into the bone, and expand it: then draw it out
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	And if not: leave it for a few days: then try it again, until it comes out.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	If the arrow-wood is in that, then push it out with that.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	If the wood breaks, and you wish to administer a push: then introduce an instrument with a concave edge, so that the concavity of the instrument may enter into the head of the arrow: then push out the arrow with the instrument itself
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	If the arrow is concave, then push out the arrow with an instrument entering into itself
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	The arrow will be relieved by that.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	If the arrow is poisonous, then it is necessary to cut away the entire flesh in which the poison is: if this is possible
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	Then take care of the arrow as it pleases you which will agree with this
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	If the arrow is falling in the chest, or in the belly, or in the gut, or on the side: and it is close to that which you touch with your finger, and it is possible to cut over the wound: then cut over the wound, and burn from the navel, or nerve, and draw out the arrow.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	Then, if necessary, apply the poultice to the wound, and care for it until it heals.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	This is the form of forceps with which arrows are extracted.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	The extremities are like the beak of a bird, made of iron: when they grasp the arrow, they do not recoil
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	There are many kinds of forceps, large, small, medium, according to the quantity of the arrow, the size of the wound, and the constriction of the wound
Forma Impellentis concaui.	The shape of the bent handle
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	The shape of the blunt handle
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is the shape of the extremities like a radius, so that the entrance of the wound is protected into the bent arrow, and is driven in with it.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	The handle of this forceps is concave like the beak of a bird: so as to protect the entrance of the arrow into itself and the driving force of it
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	On the Phlebotomy of Veins
Caput XCVII.	Chapter 127
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	The veins which are usually bled in the body are thirty in number.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	Of these, there are six in the head: two palpapable veins which are behind the ears, called the two Herbas: and two arteries which appear in two temporal regions: and two veins which are in the two tear ducts of the two eyes, which are called Aspicientes: and the vein prepared in the middle of the forehead: and the vein which is at the end of the nose
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	And two Guidegis which are in the neck
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	And two veins which are in the upper lip of the mouth
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	And two veins which are in the lower lip.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	And these are the veins which are called Algecherich
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	And two veins which are under the tongue
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	For the veins which are cut in the arms, there are five veins in every arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	One of them is the Cephalic, and it comes from the side of the collar: and it names the great vein of the head
Et Fusca.	And the other is the Femoral.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	And it is the Middle vein, and it is composed of the branches of the Basilic and the Cephalic: and it names the great vein of the body
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	And the Basilic, and it is placed on the domestic side: and it is also called the Titillicaris.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	And it names the great vein of the belly
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	And the Brachial vein, and it is placed over the elbow: and it is that in which phlebotomy is performed, and that which appears above the thumb in a visible wound
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	And the Palateal: and it is the vein which is between the ankle and the wrist: and there are two branches to it.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	And in the leg and in the foot there are three veins
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	One of them is which is under the curvature of the thumb from the lateral side
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	And the second is the Saphenous: and its place is beside the calcaneus from the domestic side
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	And the Popliteal: and its place is beside the calcaneus from the lateral side
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	And in the other leg there are three veins similar to these.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	After the Aures, from the two veins.
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	After the Aures, from the two veins which are post Aures, is the treatment for old cataracts, and migraine, and haemorrhoids, and head-ulcers.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	And the quality of the phlebotomy is as it is said to be.
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	And it is that the head of the patient is to be reduced: and the scalp is to be abraded in the place of the two veins with rough cloth.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	And then let the patient grasp his neck with his hand, until two veins appear.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	And their places are post Aures in two depressed places of the head
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	Seek therefore where your finger is easy, and where you feel their pulse under your finger, there are the signs with the cautery
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	And then make the phlebotomy with a lancet, and that is called Incidens.
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	And then insert it under the vein into the skin, until the phlebotomist has reached the bone.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	And then raise your hand with the vein and the skin towards the upper parts, and cut the vein with the incision which is incidental
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	And the length of the incision is as much as the distance of two joined fingers, or thereabouts: and let there issue from the blood as much as you wish
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	And then bind up the patient with bandages, and let go of the vein, until it is healed.
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	And thus it is before in the beginning of the book, the incision of the veins, and their cautery
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	Paragraph not included in the request.
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	If, however, the veins which are in two positions during phlebotomy are injured, it is to the ancient migraine: and the proud sweat, and the persistent vomiting: and the running forth of sharp excoriated matters to the eyes.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	The quality of the phlebotomy is easy according to what I have said to you.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	The patient should tighten his neck very much, until two veins appear to the sense of sight: and it is shown that their pulse is under your finger
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	Then indeed the signs are with incisions.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	Then raise the skin above the vein with your index finger, and make the phlebotomy incision below, and raise the vein above.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And make the incision like that which you made in the two other veins: and make the blood flow out according to the quantity which you need
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	Then loosen the patient's compression, and place your finger on the vein for an hour
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then place above the limb and the nails, and tighten it above the constriction: and let it go, until it is healed
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	And now remember the incisions and their extraction at the beginning of the book
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	On the phlebotomy of the front vein after cephalic phlebotomy.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	The after-effect of the phlebotomy of the front vein is after cephalic phlebotomy for ancient facial ailments: and for migraine, and redness: and ulcers.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	The quality of this phlebotomy is, according to what I have said to you.
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	The patient should tighten his neck with the thumb and index finger, until the vein appears to the sense of sight
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	Then take the instrument which is called Fossorium.
Cuius haec est forma.	Its shape is as follows.
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	Place the prominent point which is at the head of the Fossorium over the opening, and pierce through it with a hook or in some other way: and let the blood flow out according to the quantity you desire.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	Then close the perforation of the patient, and tie it off until it is healed.
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	And when it is opened with a wide lancet.</start_of_turn>
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	It is not necessary that the lancet should be acute at the extremity, like the other lancets, but rather that it should be wide at the extremity.</start_of_turn>
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	And the lancet should be passed according to the course of the veins: because the bone is close by: and perhaps in that it will break the lancet if it is slender.</start_of_turn>
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	As for the phlebotomy of the veins in the two lacrimal bones.</start_of_turn
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	The purpose of the two veins which are in the two lacrimal bones of the two eyes is for the eye from itching and redness: and for swelling in the eye, and for the ailments of the face.</start_of_turn
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	And the quality of the phlebotomy of these is that it tightens the neck of the patient with a loop.</start_of_turn
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	Then the phlebotomy is easy: and you stand over his head.</start_of_turn
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	And do the phlebotomy according to the course of the vein to a small length, with a small lancet, wide at the edge, for in that place there is no bone.</start_of_turn
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	If the lancet is slender at the extremity, perhaps it will break.</start_of_turn
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	Then let him run from the blood as much as is necessary.
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	Then put on above the wound a bandage once, and bind it tight. Then loosen it
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	About the cutting of the veins of the nose.</start_of_turn>
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	The veins of the nose are to be bled in case of acute fever, excessive sweating, facial pain, such as a headache, and redness which occurs in the face: especially when it is old.</start_of_turn>
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	And the quality of the bleeding of these veins is that it tightens the patient's neck.</start_of_turn
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	Then take the left hand of the patient and make the incision slightly under the tip of the nose, long: and hold it in the middle of the nose itself, between that which distinguishes the nose from the second part.</start_of_turn
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	For the vein does not appear to the sense there, and because the blood begins to flow immediately.</start_of_turn
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	And it is necessary, after having performed the bleeding, to take the last hand with the bleeding: and let the blood run from the blood as much as is necessary.</start_of_turn
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	Then bind it tight once at night.</start_of_turn>
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	The wound itself will soon restore itself.</start_of_turn>
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	About the cutting of the veins of the guide.</start_of_turn
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	These veins of the guide are to be bled in case of constriction of the breath, excessive weeping, leprosy, melancholic diseases, bad ulcers and wounds, and corrosive diseases, that is, herpes of the piles.</start_of_turn
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	The quality of the bleeding of these veins is that it tightens the patient under the chin with the ligature: and let the artist sit above the patient's head, and the patient sit down on a seat.</start_of_turn
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	Then the phlebotomy shall be performed to a length equal to that of the wide phlebotomy.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	Then draw from the blood an amount appropriate, or according to what is needed for the purpose
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	Then do likewise with the other vein.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	Then suture the ligament and bind the two veins with a middle knot: so that the patient is not harmed
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	And keep it bound until morning.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	The wound will then heal naturally
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	Of the phlebotomy of veins according to Algeberich
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	The veins of Algeberich are phlebotomized because they cause swelling in the mouth, corruption of the gums, bad ulcers, cracks in the lips, bad ulcers also in the nose and in the surrounding area
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	And the quality of the phlebotomy of these veins is that you must make the patient sit before you: and bind their neck with a collar.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	Then pull down their lip and look at two veins: one is on the right side of the lip, and the other on the left side: and the sign of both is by their blackness around them
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	And this is true: because around them are small veins, black ones
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	Incise therefore each of them at the place where they join.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	If, however, you are doubtful and do not know which of them is which: then you must proceed to the incision of the greater of the two, and their manifestation will be evident to you
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	And do likewise with the two veins which are in the upper lip: and most of them run together with it: and incisions must be made of the two veins which are in the lower lip
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	From the phlebotomy of the Cephalic vein below the tongue after the phlebotomy of the vein above the tongue.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	From the phlebotomy of the vein below the tongue after the phlebotomy of the cephalic vein
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	And the quality of the phlebotomy is such that the patient sits between your hands facing the sun: and lift up his tongue, and look under the tongue from one side of the tongue to the other side of the tongue: and the colour of both is to be dark red.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	The phlebotomy must be done on both sides: and take hold, lest you should put your last hand in phlebotomy.</start_of_turn>
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	For under the tongue are arteries, and perhaps blood will flow out from those arteries.</start_of_turn>
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	Of the three veins in the elbow.</start_of_turn>
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	For indeed three veins are phlebotomized in the elbow, and it is customary in all men to perform phlebotomy on them.</start_of_turn
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	And their phlebotomy is done in two ways.</start_of_turn
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	Either by grasping with the thumb as with a phlebotome of Myrtle: or by olive oil to the point of thinness: or by cutting with a knife, which is Alnesil.</start_of_turn
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its form.</start_of_turn
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	Thus Alnesil is suitable for cutting.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	And there are broad and narrow species according to the width of the veins and the tension of their form. The phlebotomy of the Myrtle is broad like water.</start_of_turn
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	And it is suitable for opening wide veins that are contracted, full, engorged, visible, large, and those which contain thick blood.</start_of_turn
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	And this phlebotomus is of smaller width and has a finer extremity.
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	And it is suitable for the puncture of slender veins which contain thin yellow blood.
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	Concerning the puncture of veins according to Albucasis
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	Basilicae, however, which is one of the three main veins for phlebotomy, is deemed an instrument.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	Because it draws blood from the swellings which are under the jaw and the throat, from the chest following the belly, and the groin: and it is suitable for the phlebotomist because it is above the risk of causing damage to an artery
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	If, therefore, he is mistaken and adds to the puncture of the phlebotomy, he will damage the artery, and there will be a flow of blood.
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	Therefore it is necessary not to puncture the phlebotomist with the phlebotome: rather let him be dry like Alnesil.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	If it does not appear visibly, then one must seek it out elsewhere, or ask about it, or take one of its branches: or perform the phlebotomy in another place, such as the elbow pit
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	For it is itself visible, and let the phlebotome be dry like that of Anesil, as we have said.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	If you wish to perform phlebotomy upon it itself, then you must beforehand grasp the arm tightly, so that you may know the place, until you recognize the place of the pulse
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	Then mark upon the place with a scar, afterwards the arm, and dry the vein with a concave section of the phlebotome like that of Alnesil, as we have said
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	And beware lest the puncture should slip from the place of the artery.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	And when you go, with your strings of the ligature, the inflation in the place which you marked with the cautery, then that inflation is an inflation of the artery: you must therefore do so.
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	When you go [i.e., perform surgery], with your strings of the ligature, the inflation in the place which you marked with the cautery, then that inflation is an inflation of the artery: you must therefore do so.
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	Therefore do so, and place your finger over the said long space, then withdraw your finger.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	If blood is therefore separated (for it is much more severed), then string the arm, and let it go: and let the patient beware of its movement: and be over its fear.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	And do not move it for a few days, until it is healed.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	If however blood is not severed, and it increases to you: and it does not appear to you in your moment of need, then cut the artery if you see it
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	For its extremities recoil, and blood is severed.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	Or take the edge of the flesh, and find the vein: take the middle one, and string it over the place of the narrowest constriction, with the ligature and the threads until another day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	Then if blood is severed, that is good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	And if not: then care for it as for that from which the recollection of the bleeding powder flows: and the cutting of blood in that is not difficult in many positions, because of the smallness of the wound, and the possibility of ligating from the arm.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	Of phlebotomy of the vein of the Fuscus
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	The vein of the Fuscus is suitable for phlebotomy, because it carries blood from the upper part of the head and the lower part of the body: because it is composed of the branch of the Basilica and the branch of the Cephalic, as we have said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	It is fitting for the phlebotomist to be above the fear of phlebotomy, for under it lies a nerve.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	If, therefore, the phlebotomist adds in the puncture of the phlebotomy, and finds a nerve, it happens in this that he falls into a trance, and the healing of his case becomes difficult, and perhaps does not heal at all
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	And this nerve appears to be connected with the sense of touch.
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	If, however, it is hidden in some people, and is slight, and is not seen: then it is necessary that you should perform phlebotomy with caution, sectioning with Alnesil, and take the nerve with your strength.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	If there are two nerves between which there is a space, then find the space in its length.
¶ De uena Cephalica.	Of the nerve of the head.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	Phlebotomies of the nerve of the head are useful, because they draw blood from the head, and confer to eye diseases.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	And it is necessary in this vein alone, if you will, that you should perform phlebotomy with the olive oil needle, or with the myrtle needle: because it is safer for the veins of all, because there is no artery, nor nerve under it
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	But it is fitting to you to know concerning phlebotomy that you should take hold of the head only with the first puncture, and seek a softer place: and it does not harm if it is not found with the first blow, as it will return with subsequent phlebotomies.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	Perhaps sometimes in some people the swelling subsides when it is not phlebotomized in the first blow, but it does not harm that swelling in anything.
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	Of the usefulness of phlebotomy, and the precautions to be observed in its practice.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	The quality of Phlebotomy and its associated accidents are such that you must consider their rectification.
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	Firstly, you must know that Phlebotomy is not to be used except in the conservation of health, and the preservation of life, and the avoidance of diseases.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	And as for the veins which are in the elbow, namely the Cephalica, and the Fusca, and the Basilica, these are suitable for Phlebotomy
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	And as for the time of the year when Phlebotomy should be performed, it is best in the beginning of spring after the feast, in summer, and in autumn, and in winter after the completion of the harvest, when there are signs of fullness.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	It should be performed on the first or third day after the three hours have passed
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	Phlebotomy for diseases does not have a fixed time: but when there is convenience and necessity for it, at night or day, at any hour, and at any time.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	It is not permitted to perform Phlebotomy on children until they are at least fourteen years of age.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	Neither should Phlebotomy be performed on a pregnant woman except from the fourth month until the seventh month.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	Nor on the elderly who have passed their sixtieth year
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	When anyone wishes to undergo Phlebotomy for any reason: it is necessary to empty the intestines beforehand with a mild laxative, if there is much stool retained: so that they do not draw out harmful matter from the intestines towards the principal parts during Phlebotomy.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	Phlebotomy should not be performed on a patient who is suffering from nausea, or who is intoxicated, or who has consumed alcohol: until these symptoms have passed from the body.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	Neither the infirm nor the healthy are unaffected by hydropisis.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	Neither the infirm nor the healthy are unaffected by hydropisis.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	Neither the infirm nor the healthy are unaffected by hydropisis. Consider carefully the condition of the humors before attempting treatment; if blood is thick with food and drink, and if the physicians are present: in such a case it is possible for them to do it.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	Consider carefully the condition of the humors before attempting treatment; if blood is thick with food and drink, and if the physicians are present: in such a case it is possible for them to do it.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	Consider carefully the condition of the humors before attempting treatment; if blood is thick with food and drink, and if the physicians are present: in such a case it is possible for them to do it. And perform phlebotomy in the chest, around the third day, as we have said: and endeavor to evacuate the belly of all harmful things: such as envy, anger, and fear: and from all bodily things, such as labor, pain, and excess, and such like these.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	And make your food fragrant with things which are customary among men, such as spices, perfumes, and delights, and like these in quantity as is possible
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	And let the phlebotomist sit above the ankle, which is higher than the ankle of the phlebotomist: then draw out his arm and wipe it with the hand of the phlebotomist twice, or thrice
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	Then bind the ligament with a bandage, and hold it twice.
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	And let the restraint be moderate, for when the restraint is too tight, or through excess in the restraint, then it hinders the course of the blood: or in softening, then it hinders the course of the blood also
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	Then after the stricture it is necessary that the phlebotomist should move his hand towards the inside together with the thumb, until the veins become full, and their filling is perceived by sense.
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	Then the phlebotomist should withdraw the vein with a slight pull, as before.</start_of_turn>
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	Then he places his index finger of his left hand over the vein at the place where the phlebotomy is to be made, slightly: so that the vein does not slip away, and the percussion should be set.</start_of_turn
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	For from the veins is more like a fleeing cord at the phlebotomy: and from the inside is what is filled with air: and when you place the phlebotomy over the vein, it contracts under the phlebotomy, and the phlebotomist is thrown back, and the vein is not opened by the phlebotomy: and if it is opened, it is a stricture: because of this, therefore, it is necessary that the phlebotomist should be firm, and be solicitous in all these matters.</start_of_turn>
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	Then he lays down the phlebotomy.</start_of_turn
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	If thus the vein is opened from the inside, then it is good.</start_of_turn
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	And if not, then repeat it with another vein slightly under or over that one: if the place does not yield.</start_of_turn
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	And if it yields, or if the patient is weak, then let it go on the first or second day: and do not tie the ligament.</start_of_turn
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	Perhaps indeed it will draw out the clot.</start_of_turn
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	Neither should you introduce a sponge.</start_of_turn>
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	Then repeat the phlebotomy if necessary.</start_of_turn
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	If the opening is small, or blood runs slowly: then take care that the amount of blood which escapes does not exceed what is desired. Then repeat the bloodletting in the same place according to the rule, and add a little more to the operation.
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	Do it with speed, before the place is closed. For the closed place is in many men at the time of the operation itself
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	If therefore you see that the thing is already closed, do not go over it any more, for that will not excuse you before the lord.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	And put something of the fat of oil upon it: because it will soothe the running of the blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	It is better in this place than pure oil, and than any other oil.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	And do the same with the fat of oil in all your bloodlettings, which you do against the running of the blood: and make it become like tyriaca alfarach and sage, when you put some of it upon the place
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	The blood becomes thin and dissolves when it is thick
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	If it happens at the time of bloodletting that the clot is great, for it often happens to those who are not skilled in bloodletting except for a small opening, then take care and put upon the place a sponge wet with water and salt, warmed up slightly: and keep it for an hour: for it will dissolve
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	And it is necessary that you do this after the blood has gone out of the vein, with the complement of the hand, or from another vein.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	If anything black or yellow remains in the place after a few days, it does not harm: and if you wish, put upon it something of aloe or myrrh of resolvers, or something of the juice of mint, that is, camomile or something like that.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	Many wounds occur at the ankles and knees among the phlebotomists of the Basilica.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	Place your hand over the area being compressed; if you find softness there, the swelling is bad
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	Therefore, put something over it as we have said.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	For perhaps blood flows from the artery.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	But make a compress with something that has styptic properties to stop the bleeding at the source
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for the rest with the other treatment until it heals
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	And it is necessary to draw out every man from blood in proportion to his virtue.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	And what appears from the color of the blood on the wound
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	For blood that is black, then let it go out until it turns red: and in like manner if you see it thick: then let it go until it becomes thin: and in like manner if it is acute: then let the sharpness pass away from it
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	And it is necessary for him who is full, strong, and indigent in bloodletting to use one at a time, so that he increases the phlebotomy of one and is wide in that one: and in him who is weak, the contrary is true
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	And it is necessary to extract it in small amounts, and that the puncture be strict: and it is better that it be administered in phlebotomy of one than by puncture.
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	And this method of phlebotomy is safe from the flow of blood and from the cutting of nerves: and is more praiseworthy and safer than phlebotomy by breadth and length.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	And whoever has been accustomed to persist with phlebotomy during fainting spells should before phlebotomy give the patient a spoonful of honey mixed with water of pomegranate: or vinegar, if he is feverish: and draw from him in three or four amounts
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	If the complexion is frozen, then before performing a phlebotomy, take bread infused in myrrh syrup, or in scented honey syrup with spices, or in scented oil.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	If during a phlebotomy syncope should occur, due to the excessive flow of blood: then it is necessary to take in the vessel water of meat and a mild scented syrup: and let it be flavored with caraway and linseed, and cover the chest with these. And do all that we have said in the chapter on syncope concerning evacuation.
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	Whoever wishes to remove his arm and restore his blood slowly: must take that from which the phlebotomy has been performed because of the great evacuation, and that is because of its weakness, so that it slowly restores the blood in quantity equal to the degree of weakness in continuous days.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	Whoever wishes to remove his arm and restore his blood slowly, and his body is strong: then let him do so after seven or nine hours of the first phlebotomy.
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from his body in the opposite direction of its decline: must do so on the second or third day
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	In whose body there is much hot and acute blood, and which causes fever: must be driven out of it with one vessel, and a great quantity of blood should be drawn from it: and the opening should be prolonged until syncope occurs: after which time you must maintain all the conditions of the phlebotomy, and put your hand over the pulse of the blood-vessel, so that no further syncope should occur.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	Many times this happens when the phlebotomist is ignorant and neglectful.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	And it is not proper when one wishes to restore the arm and restore the blood, when the orifice of the vessel is closed, and there is difficulty in the flow of blood, as it may happen too soon because of excessive speed, and the wound is extended too quickly.
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	It is bad that it should be delayed, nay rather let it go, until the phlebotomy be done the second time.
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	When the blood has coagulated in the opening of the vein, remove it with the greatest attention, and pour upon it some salt dissolved in water.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	And pour upon it some aloes of aloes, or alum, and compress it gently, until the blood has drained out
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	If indeed the vein has been opened, then let it go, and do not press it, until the swelling has subsided
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	When necessity demands to evacuate the blood a second time, and this is not forbidden, then either perform the phlebotomy above the location, or in the arm or in another vein altogether
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	The veins of the arm are to be phlebotomized at the cubital fossa and the elbow, when they cannot be found, because they are hidden, for they are composed of bones.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	And the quality of the phlebotomy is that the patient dips his hand into warm water, until the hand becomes red and the vein becomes visible again.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	Then bind it above with a ligature of moderate tension
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	Then perform the phlebotomy in a transverse direction gradually, not laterally, and not too deeply: and let the opening be wide, and your phlebotomy should be as near to the edge of the wound as possible
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	If the discharge of blood is forbidden, then dip the hand once more into warm water, and let the blood flow into the water, until you have accomplished your purpose
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	If indeed you are in the summer days, then you are excused from the dipping of the hand into the warm water
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	Much of the blood course is placed in warm water in winter.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	Phlebotomy of this vein is more beneficial than all the others, because there is neither a pulsatile vein nor a nerve under it
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	Phlebotomy of the right hand is useful for treating liver ailments.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	The quality of the phlebotomy is that you tie the vein with a thread or your finger, after you have introduced the vein into the warm water, until the vein swells and you can feel the cold sensation
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	Then the phlebotomy is completed by cutting across the vein.
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	And if you cut the vein completely, it will not cause it any harm in any way.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	And let us preserve, that you do not cut off your hand with the phlebotomy
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	Under this are the nerves of the fingers stripped of flesh.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	Then return the hand to the warm water, and let the blood flow out of it
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	For if you do not return the hand to the warm water, the blood clots in the opening of the vein and prevents its course.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	When you have taken out the amount of blood necessary, then put on the vein oil and salt: so that it does not clot too quickly.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	And in the same way you must do with every strict limb
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	The remedy for the phlebotomy of the left hand is: because it is useful for treating spleen ailments: and in the phlebotomy of this, do as you did in the second equally
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	The saphenous veins are useful for treating ailments that are in the lower part of the body, such as stomach ailments, retention of menstrual blood, kidney weakness, ulcers of the buttocks and thighs of old age, and similar ailments.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	And the quality of the phlebotomy is such that it introduces the diseased limb into hot water: and makes above it friction, until the veins bubble forth: and binds above the junction of the limb with a bandage.
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	The veins are located at the heel, appearing under the thumb: and are extracted from that on the face of the foot of many limbs.
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	The phlebotomy is therefore done in the greater branch of the limb, or at the heel in its collection: because that is better and safer
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	If the phlebotomy is done on the face of the foot, then it causes damage from the nerves that are under it over the face of the foot.
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	And place your phlebotomy above that from which the phlebotomy is made, as if you wish to cut through it: and let the phlebotomy be of Nile
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	But if the discharge of blood is prohibited, then repeat the limb in hot water: and let the blood flow out in the limb until it is evacuated.
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	But if the vein is mistaken in the first attempt, then repeat with the phlebotomy to the upper parts, for the place is safe, and does not often cause harm, when you cut from the nerves, as we have said.
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	And in the same way as the other vein of the foot is equal.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	The veins of the sciatica are located at the heel from the side of the heel bone
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	The purpose of the phlebotomy is for the relief of the pain of the ankle, when it is because of the hot blood.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	And the quality of the phlebotomy is such that it introduces the diseased limb into a bath, and makes haste: and ties the limb from the side of the ankle up to the heel for four fingers, with a fine long bandage: for it does not appear except for that.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	When the patient appears, then the phlebotomy is performed according to whatever is possible for the patient, or according to the passage of blood: and it is better either to make the incision or to perform the section.
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	The place of the vein is more beneficial, and it is hidden in many men.
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	If you do not find it and it does not appear to the senses in any way: then the phlebotomy is performed on some branch of it, and that which appears at the back of the foot and is adjacent to the heel: and you should prick from nerves, and cause blood to flow out in the quantity that you desire
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	Then loosen the tight dressing, and place over the site of the phlebotomy the skin, and bind the place
Uelociter enim sanatur.	It will heal quickly.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	On Windings, and the quality of the bandage.
Caput XCVIII.	Chapter XCIII.
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	Wounds are caused by horns, and by air, and by pus.
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	And the dressing is done in two ways
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	One is with scarification and extraction of blood: and the other is dressing without scarification
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	And this dressing which is without scarification is done in two ways
Aut enim est cum igne.	Or it is with fire
Aut est absque igne.	Or it is without fire
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	And the dressings which are administered with scarification and extraction of blood are fourteen in number for the body
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	Of these, one is the dressing of Aloe, and it is the most recent for the head: and Alkhel, and it is middle of the neck: and the dressings of Aloes of the Gardens, and they are two layers of the neck from two parts together: and the dressing of Mint, and it is under the mandible in the lower part of the mouth: and the dressing of the Two Spines, and they are two layers of the cheek: and the dressing of Alachosos over the end of the tail: and the dressing of the Two Grooves, and they are middle of the two arms: and the dressing of the Two Ribs, and they are under the two elbows: and the dressing of the Two Heels
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	Neither does external application of powder exert blood from small wounds scattered through the flesh; for that reason it does not cause the loss of vital force from the body, as is the case with phlebotomy.
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	Neither does it suffice to apply powder with fire, or without fire, to any ailment that arises from excessive filling of the body until the whole body is evacuated
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	When need compels us to apply powder in an ailment, whether due to custom or for the benefit of the patient, we shall administer it at the beginning, at the end, and in the middle of the month, and at any other time as required
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	For indeed, when men are multiplied in their blood, until they crave its extraction through powder, they find in their head a burden.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	And from the body comes the filling and redness of the face, head, and neck
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	And from the body comes the itching of the face, the forehead, the temples, and the dimming of the eyes.
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	The body itself is the seat of powder application.
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	The body's laughter is multiplied
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	And from the body comes the taste of blood in the mouth: either the tongue swells up and expels blood.
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	The body's sleep is multiplied.
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	And from the body comes sweating in sleep, blood, redness, boils, and similar things
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	When we see any of these things, or at least in the middle of the month: we order powder to be applied immediately, after two or three hours have passed
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	The application of the Ventosation of the Neck is as follows: since it itself contributes to the gravity in the head, and what flows down to the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	It should be administered after the evacuation of the entire body.
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	And this is indeed the Ventosation of the Cephalic Vein.
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	It is not permitted to use it on those who are of a cold complexion, or in whom there is a discharge from the eyes
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	For it brings about a great heat.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	It is not suitable to use it in the elderly, or in those whose heads suffer from cold ailments
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	Whoever uses it excessively will cause great pain in the head
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	Therefore it is necessary to support the hand with the open palm downwards, away from the face, fearing the generation of a headache
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	The Ventosation or Alkehel is the place of the phlebotomy of the Vein of the Fuscus, and of the vein of the Basilica, and because of this it contributes to asthenia, and constriction of the chest, and pain in the instruments of the chest, and cough, and swelling.
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	It is necessary to apply the Ventosation of the Alkehel downwards, because if it is placed downwards, it will cause stiffness of the heart and the stomach
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	The application of the Ventosation is useful for headaches, dizziness, migraine, perforation and toothache: it is the place of the phlebotomy of the Basilica.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	It is necessary to hold the hand firmly without grasping it during the procedure: so as not to damage the artery and cause the flow of blood to be obstructed
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	The windward side of the face, when it is wet, brings moisture to the mouth, corrupts the gums, and brings about similar ailments which are in the mouth: and it stands in the place of a bloodletting which is in two veins.
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	The windward side of the face, when it is wet, brings moisture to the lips, which is caused by reflection and heat.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	The windward side of the face, when it is wet, brings moisture to the three angles of the mouth, Basilica, Fez, and Cephalic: because it attracts blood from all these small veins which are in the flesh: and it attracts these small veins from other greater veins until the attraction reaches the three veins.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	And it is necessary, in order to prevent the effects of the wind, not to make too great an incision: because the place is naked of flesh, and under it are nerves and blood vessels.
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	The wind which comes upon the cheeks brings about haemorrhoids of the anus and lower ulcers.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	And it is necessary, in order to prevent the effects of the wind, that it should be great and dry: because the place requires strong suction, and the fine veins may be broken by strong suction: and a great incision is made.
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.
