Et est instrumentum quod fit ex ferro, cuius longitudo est quantitas septem digitorum, aut octo: et eius latitudo est secundum quantitatem uulneris.	And the instrument is made of iron, whose length is the quantity of seven fingers, or eight: and its width is according to the quantity of the wound.
Et propter illud necesse est medico, ut accipiat ex eis tria, aut quatuor secundum quantitatem qua indiget ad illud ex curatione in omni specie fracturae.	And because of this it is necessary for the physician, that he take from these three, or four according to the quantity that he needs for the care of every kind of fracture.
Et sit rotundum: et sit in eo grossitudo parua, ut non duplicetur apud compressionem super ipsum in hora operationis: et sit acutae extremitatis, cui sit margo in extremitatibus suis.	And be rounded: and be in such a small size, that it does not double under compression over it in the hour of operation: and be acute at the extremities, which have a margin at their extremities
Et sit superius eius ad grossitudinem ex medietate eius usque ad inferiora.	And be above it to the height from the middle to the lower parts.
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its form.</start_of_turn>
Oportet in Hac Operatione, ut ponatur extremitas eius acuta curuata super extremitatem ossis eminentis: et impelle ipsum cum eo uice una, donec quando redit os et aequatur quadam aequatione.	It is necessary in this operation that you place the acute curvature of the limb at the extremity of the prominent bone: and push it in with the same, until the bone returns and is equal in height to the surrounding parts.</start_of_turn>
Conare ergo aequare extremitates fracturae adinuicem.	So do you make the extremities of the fracture equal to each other.</start_of_turn
Quod si extremitates eius fracta est subtilis, et non accipit eam instrumentum accaeptione bona, tunc opotet, ut incidas extremitatem illius ossis, donec instrumentum potestatem habeat eius.	If its extremities are fractured slightly, and do not grasp well with the instruments, then you must cut off the extremity of that bone, until the instrument has sufficient power.</start_of_turn
Si uero non potes reducere eos cum eo quod narrauimus omnino, tunc incide ipsum cum eo quod conuenit ei ex Incisoriis quae diximus: aut serra ipsum cum una serrarum quocunque modo possibile est tibi.	If indeed we are unable to reduce them as we have said, then cut through it with the instrument which we mentioned before: or grasp it with a clamp in any convenient way.</start_of_turn
Deinde rade illud quod remanet in osse ex asperitate et corticibus minutis.	Then remain only the rough parts of the bone and the small pieces of cortex.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo reducitur os, et inuenit infirmus post reductionem eius dolorem uehementem laedentem, tunc scias, quod os non rediit ad locum suum naturalem.	When the bone has been reduced and has been found to be loose after reduction, then you know that the bone has not returned to its natural place.</start_of_turn
Fac ergo illud.	Do this.</start_of_turn>
Nam tu confers infirmo iuuamentum magnum, cum completur restauratio tua quam facis ossi.	For you confer great pain on the sick man when you complete your restoration of the bone.</start_of_turn
Tunc submerge pannum in uino stiptico, nigro.	Then soak the bandage in lukewarm black wine.</start_of_turn
Et proprie si est in aestate.	And in summer it is proper.</start_of_turn
Et non ponas super uulnus caerotum, neque aliquid in quo sit oleum: ut non faciat accidere in ipso putredinem et corruptionem.	And do not place upon the wound a greasy ointment, or anything containing oil: so that it does not cause it to become infected and corrupted.</start_of_turn
Deinde administra astellas in hora complementi tui a restauratione ossis.	Then administer the stars at the hour of completion of your restoration of the bone.
Et dimitte uulnus detectum: ita, ut incidas cum forficibus foramen in inuolutionibus secundum quantitatem uulneris.	And discharge the wound detected: thus, that you may cut with scissors the opening in the incisions according to the quantity of the wound.
Et caue omni cautela, ne stringas uulnus cum fractura.	And take care of all precautions, that you do not tighten the wound with the fracture.
Multotiens enim fecerunt istud stolidi medici: et fecerunt accidere super infirmos suos aut mortem, aut corrosionem, aut zuchem, id est, saniem.	Many have done this carelessly, and they have caused many patients to suffer either death or decay or corruption, that is, harm.
Et sit strictura tua mollis, lenis, diuersa stricturae fracturarum reliquarum.	And be your stricture soft, gentle, diverse from the strictures of the remaining fractures
Quod si uulnus est malum, aut est uulnus magnum, et times super ipsum quaedam accidentia mala quae narrauimus, et inuenis dolorem in loco suspensum: tunc non oportet, ut ponas super ipsum astellas.	If the wound is bad, or if it is large, and the times are great for some harmful events which we have mentioned, and if you find pain in the place of suspension: then it does not suffice to put on the stars over it
Et fac eis inuolutiones ex pannis duris in loco astellarum, et stringe ipsum cum eis.	And make for it incisions from hard papers in the place of the stars, and string it with them.
Cum autem est post diem unum, aut dies duos, et uides uulnus iam incipere, ut in eo generetur pus: tunc aufer desuper ipsum pannum quem posuisti super ipsum cum uino.	When, however, a day or two have passed, and the wound has begun to heal, so that pus is generated: then remove the paper which you put over it with wine
Deinde administra licinia, et unguenta cum quibus de consuetudine nostra est, ut medicemur uulnera: sicut unguentum tetrapharmacon, et similia illi.	Then administer balsam and unguents which are customary to us, to soothe the wound: such as the balsam of tetrapharmacon, and the like of it.
Et conuenit tibi, ut soluas ligamentum.	And it is convenient for you to dissolve the ligamentum
Et considera uulnus in omni die mane et uespere, donec consolidetur, et sanetur.	And consider the wound every day in the morning and evening, until it is consolidated and healed
Et oportet, ut praeparetur membrum taliter, ut currat ex eo pus ad inferiora cum facilitate.	And it is necessary that the limb be prepared in such a way that the pus may flow downwards with ease
Quod si praetereunt uulneri dies multi, et non consolidatur, neque abscinditur pus ab eo: tunc scias, quod illic sunt satagie ossis parua.	If the wound passes many days and does not consolidate, neither does the pus separate from it: then you know that there is a fracture of the bone there
Quare oportet, ut inquiras uulnus cum tenta.	Why should one inquire about a wound with a tentacle?
Quot uero ex illis alsatagie sunt separata, remoue ea, et extrahe ipsa.	How many of these tentacles are separated from the wound, remove them and extract them themselves.
Et quae ex eis sunt non separata, et pungunt membrum, et faciunt accidere dolorem, conare incidere ea, et auferre ea omni modo quo possibile est tibi illud.	And what remains of them which is not separated, and which pricks the limb, and causes them to swell, endeavor to cut them out, and remove them in every way possible for you
Quod si accidat uulneri zuchen, aut ekileten, id est, estiomenus, aut species alia corruptionis et putrefactionis: tunc oportet, ut opponas unicuique ex eis cum eo quod conuenit ei ex curatione, cuius praecessit narratio in capitulo suo.	If it happens that a wound is bitten by a dog, or has worms, that is, swelling, or some other corruption and decomposition: then it is necessary to oppose each of these with what is appropriate for it in its treatment, as is narrated in its chapter
Et ex eo in quo oportet ut stet sermo meus, et cui facias praesentem mentem tuam quando frangitur os, et eminet super membrum, sicut os coxae, et adiutorii, et similia eis ex membris magnis, est, ut non praesumas attractionem eius, multotiens enim accidit ex illo mors, imo dimitte ipsum, donec putrefiat.	And concerning this, as to what I have said before, and to which you must pay attention when a bone is fractured, and protrudes beyond the limb, such as the thigh bone, and joints, and similar parts of great limbs, do not presume its attraction, for much harm often happens from this moisture, indeed sometimes it is better to let it go rather than to retain it until it has decomposed
Fortasse enim cadet per se post uiginti dies, aut triginta.	Perhaps it will fall away by itself after eighty days, or a hundred.
Tunc ergo cura uulnus, si uidetur tibi: et sinon, dimitte ipsum.	Then indeed care for the wound, if you see it: and otherwise, let it go.
¶ De curatione Nodationis in uestigio fracturae.	Note: The provided text does not include the next section of the translation, so I am unable to provide the translation of that part.
Caput XXI.	Chapter XXI.</start_of_turn>
Multoties accidit haec Nodatio in uestigio sanationis fracturae.	Many times this swelling occurs in the process of healing a fracture.</start_of_turn>
Praecipue, quae est prope iuncturas: et foedatur ex ea figura membri.	Especially concerning those parts which are close to the sutures: and it is caused by that figure of the limb.</start_of_turn
Et fortasse prohibet membrum ab operatione sua naturali.	And perhaps it hinders the limb from its natural operation.</start_of_turn
Considera ergo tunc, si nodatio est recens: administra in ea medicinas quae stipticitatem habent, sicut aloe, et olibanum, et myrrha, et sarcocolla, et acacia, et similia eis.	Consider therefore, if the wound is still bleeding: administer in it medicines which have styptic properties, such as aloe, and olibanum, and myrrh, and sarcocolla, and acacia, and similar things.
Ita, ut accipias ex istis quasdam, aut omnes eas: et confice eas cum uino stiptico, aut cum albumine oui, aut cum aceto: et pone eas super nodationem in stuppa, et stringe eas super ipsam strictura bona.	Consider therefore, if the wound is still bleeding: administer some or all of these things: and mix them with a styptic liquid, or with albumin or vinegar: and apply them over the wound and bind them securely.</start_of_turn>
Et dimitte stricturam, nec soluas eam diebus multis.	And remove the dressing, and do not keep it on for many days.</start_of_turn>
Deinde solue eam, et itera aliam, donec remoueatur nodatio.	Then wash the wound, and repeat the process until the bleeding stops.</start_of_turn>
Aut stringe super ipsam laminam plumbi decenter.	Or bind over it a sheet of lead in the middle.</start_of_turn
Plumbo enim est proprietas remouendi omne quod timetur ex membris.	Lead has the property of removing all that is feared from the members.</start_of_turn
Si autem nodatio iam in lapidem conuersa est, et stricta est, et festine prouocat necessitas ad auferendum eam: tunc finde super eam ex superiori parte eius, et incide superfluitatem eminentem: aut rade eam cum quibusdam rasoriis, donec remoueatur: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	If however the wound is already covered with blood, and is tightly closed, and the bleeding persists: then find above the wound from the upper part of it, and cut off the excess: or scrape the wound with some instruments, until the bleeding stops: and care for the wound until it heals.</start_of_turn>
¶ De curatione quando restauratur, et remanet membrum post illud subtile, non secundum naturam suam.	And as for the care when the wound has healed, and the limb remains under its natural shape, not contrary to its nature.</start_of_turn
Caput XXII.	Chapter XXII.</start_of_turn>
Quando restauratur fractura ossis, et remanet membrum post illud subtile, debile: tunc non fit illud nisi propter caussas multas.	When the fracture of a bone has healed, and the limb remains under its natural shape, it is weak: then it is not done except for many causes.</start_of_turn
Quarum una est, multitudo solutionis ligamenti et ligationis eius non secundum quod oportet: aut propter superfluitatem stricturae ligamentorum, donec prohibeatur nutrimentum currere ad membrum: aut propter multitudinem embrocationis superfluae in non sua hora: aut propter paucitatem sanguinis in corpore infirmi, et debilitatem eius.	For one, there are many causes of loosening of the ligament and its ligation which are not according to what is necessary: either because of the excess tension of the ligaments, until it hinders the circulation of nourishment to the limb: or because of the excessive quantity of superfluous dressing: or because of the scarcity of blood in the body of the patient, and its weakness.</start_of_turn
Et curatio illius est, cibare infirmum, et tenerum facere corpus eius, donec multiplicetur sanguis in eo.	And its care is to feed the patient and keep his body firm until the blood multiplies in it.
Et administra balneum.	And administer a bath.
Et intromitte gaudium et laeticiam super eum.	And introduce joy and laughter upon him.
Deinde pone picem super membrum: ut attrahat pix ad ipsum nutrimentum multum.	Then apply oil to the limb: so that it attracts nourishment to itself much
Et assiduet embrocationem eius cum aqua tepida, donec currat nutrimentum, et redeat ad figuram suam naturalem.	And diligently anoint its embrocation with warm water, until nourishment runs and returns to its natural shape
¶ De curatione ossium fractorum quando restaurantur tortuose.	When restoring fractured bones to their natural position
Caput XXIII.	Chapter XXIII.
Quando accidit membro iam restaurato post sanationem eius tortuositas, et eminentia ossi fracto, aut nodatio: et foedatur per illud forma membri, uerumtamen membrum non prohibetur ab operatione sua naturali: tunc non oportet ut recipias sermonem eius, qui existimat, ut frangatur membrum denuo.	When a limb has been restored after healing from a fracture, and when the fractured bone or joint remains bent: and it is pained through that, but the limb is not prohibited from its natural action: then it is not necessary to break the limb again for that reason
Et iam fuerunt multi stolidorum medicorum et restauratorum, qui fecerunt illud in terra nostra.	And there are many proud doctors and restorers who have done this in our land.
Et haec quidem operatio est uituperabilis ualde, perducens ad mortem, uel timorem magnum, ut scilicet sit mortalis.	And this operation is very dangerous, often leading to death or great fear, as indeed it is mortal.
Verum si claudicatio et nodatio sunt recentes: tunc oportet, ut embrocetur cum aqua tepida, in qua decoctae sint herbae mollificantes, sicut folia alteae, et radix eius, et mellilotum, et illis similia.	But if the fracture and bending are recent: then it is necessary to anoint with warm water in which decoctions of emollient herbs are boiled, such as rue leaves, and the root of it, and honey, and similar things
Et fiat ei emplastrum cum emplastro mollificatiuo, sicut dyachilon decenter factum.	And make for him a plaster with a soothing plaster, such as gypsum made into a center
Aut sumatur mucilago radicis alteae, et concutiatur cum adipe gallinae, aut oleo sisamino: et emplastretur cum eo.	Or take the slime of the rue root, and mix it with chicken fat, or with beeswax: and plaster with that
Aut sumantur ficus pingues, et terantur cum fimo columbino, et similibus eis quae nominantur ex medicinis diminuentes consolidationem.	Or take figs of gum, and mix them with meal, and things of that kind which are named by doctors to decrease consolidation
Et quandoque soluitur nodatio cum fricatione assidua, antiqua, et leni, quae fit cum manibus humidis.	When the nodulation is resolved with persistent friction, ancient and gentle, which occurs with moist hands.
Et administretur motus membri ad omnem partem in horis omnibus.	The movement of the limb is administered to every part at all times of the day.
Si autem tortuositas iam antecessit, et fortis facta est, et conuersa est in lapidem, et prouocata est necessitas ad curatonem eius cum ferro: tunc oportet, ut secetur superius eius, et soluatur continuatio ossis, et incidatur quod superfluit ex nodatione aut osse cum Incisoriis subtilibus: et administretur facilitas in illo cum sollicitudine et studio.	If, however, stiffness has preceded it [the swelling], and has become strong, and has become congealed in stone, and has necessitated treatment with an instrument: then it is necessary to cut above it [the swelling], to resolve the continuation of the bone, and to remove what is superfluous from the nodulation or bone with fine scissors: and this should be administered with attention and care
¶ De sermone in Dislocatione.	Regarding the dislocation.</start_of_turn>
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter 24.</start_of_turn>
Dislocatio est exitus alicuius iuncturarum a loco suo.	Dislocation is the exit of any articulation from its place.</start_of_turn
Quare prohibetur a motu suo, et foedatur figura membri.	Therefore it is prohibited from its movement, and deforms the figure of the limb.</start_of_turn
Et facit accidere super infirmum dolores, et laesiones uehementes.	And causes the occurrence of excessive pain, and serious injuries.</start_of_turn
Quando ergo accidit alicui dislocatio, tunc oportet festinare ad restaurationem eius: neque tardet eam omnino.	When, therefore, such a dislocation has happened, then it is necessary to hasten to restore it: and do not delay at all.</start_of_turn
Nam si tardatur, apostematur locus, et fortasse cum eo reductio dislocationis.	For if it is delayed, the place is apt to become stiff, and perhaps with it the reduction of the dislocation.</start_of_turn
Propter illud ergo non oportet, ut moueatur, neque extendatur in hora apostemationis eius.	Therefore it is not necessary to move or extend it in the hour following its displacement.</start_of_turn
Quoniam multotiens facit accidere spasmum, et dolores laedentes.	For it causes many to suffer spasm and painful sensations.</start_of_turn
Verum quando accidit illud, tunc oportet, ut properes ad phlebotomiam infirmi.	But when it has happened, then it is necessary to order a bloodletting of the patient.</start_of_turn
Deinde dimittatur, donec quiescat apostema.	And afterwards let it be allowed to rest until the swelling subsides.</start_of_turn
Deinde embrocetur membrum cum aqua calida et oleo.	Then the limb is bound with warm water and oil.
Deinde reducatur cum facilitate.	Then it is reduced with ease
Et curetur omne membrum cum eo cuius rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	And all the limb is cared for so that its memory remains in its place
Ego quidem iam ordinaui capitula dislocationis, etiam secundum quod praecessit in fractura, a superiori parte corporis usque ad inferiorem eius.	I command that the head of the dislocation be reduced, even as has been said in the fracture, from the upper part of the body down to the lower part of it.
¶ De cura dislocationis Mandibulae inferioris.	Concerning the care of the dislocation of the lower jaw
Caput XXV.	Chapter XXV
Parum dislocantur duae Mandibulae nisi raro.	Rarely do two mandibles dislocate except for a little while.
Et dislocatio ambarum fit secundum unum duoru modorum.	And the dislocation of both is done according to one of two methods.
Aut enim remouentur a locis suis remotione parua, et mollificantur parumper.	Or they are moved from their places with a small removal, and are softened around
Aut dislocantur dislocatione integra, completa, donec mollificentur ad partem pectoris, donec currat saliua infirmi, et non possit tenere eam, neque possit claudere os suum, et inuoluatur lingua eius cum sermone.	Or they are dislocated completely, without any removal, until they are softened up to the breast, until the saliva of the infirm person softens them, and they are unable to hold it together, and are unable to close their own mouth, and their tongue is swollen with the saliva
Quando autem dislocatio eius est parua, tunc redit in pluribus dispositionibus per se cum paucitate.	When however the dislocation is slight, then it returns by itself in various positions with little effort
Si uero est dislocatio completa, integra: tunc oportet, ut administretur reductio eius uelociter, et non tardetur penitus: et est, ut teneat minister caput infirmi: et intromittat medicus pollicem manus suae unius in radicem Mandibulae dislocationis inter os eius, si dislocatio est a parte una.	If however the dislocation is complete, entire: then it must be immediately administered, and not delayed: and it is necessary that the minister of the infirm person should hold the hand of the hand which is near to the dislocation of the mandible between the bones of the dislocation, if the dislocation has occurred from one side only
Aut intromittat duos pollices suos simul, si dislocatio est a duabus partibus.	Or he may insert two fingers of his hand together if the dislocation has occurred from both sides
Et reliqui digiti manuum eius sint extra, quibus aequet.	And the rest of the fingers of his hand remain outside, which is equal
Et praecipe infirmo, ut mundificet Mandibulas suas, et absoluat eas ad manducandum ad omnem partem.	And command the patient to loosen their teeth and make them capable of biting throughout.
Et medicus aequet Mandibulam, et impellat Mandibulam, donec redeat ad locum suum.	And the physician must stabilize the jaw and press it until it returns to its place
Quod si difficilis sit reductio eius, praecipue si sunt ambae Mandibulae simul: tunc administra uaporationem cum aqua calida, et oleo, donec fiat facilis reductio ambarum: neque tardes reductionem ambarum omnino, sicut diximus.	If its reduction is difficult, especially if both jaws are simultaneously displaced: then apply heat with warm water and oil, until the reduction of both becomes easy: neither reduce them both at once, as we have said
Cum ergo redeunt et aequantur, et clauditur os infirmi, et non mollificantur: tunc pone super eas puluillos pannorum, cum ceroto quod sit factum ex cera: et oleo rosato.	When they have returned and are aligned, and the patient's bone is closed, and they are not softened: then place over the teeth pieces of wool felt, with wax that has been made from beeswax: and oiled with rose oil.
Deinde ligetur cum facilitate cum ligamentis mollibus.	And it is bound with soft bands.
Et sit somnus infirmi super dorsum suum: et caput eius sit stans inter duo puluinaria, ut non moueat ipsum ad dextram et sinistram: neque conetur, uel cogatur masticare aliquid: imo ponatur cibus eius sorbitio lenis, donec quando remouentur dolores, et nodatur Mandibula: tunc comedat quod uult, et administretur illud cum facilitate.	And the patient should rest on their back: and their head should be fixed between two cushions, so that it does not move to the right or left: neither should they be forced or commanded to bite: rather let them take a soft diet, until when they feel relief from the pain, and the jaw is relaxed: then they may eat what they wish, and this should be administered with ease
Non laboret super operationem oris sui apud comestionem et potum, et oscitationem, donec nodetur Mandibula, et sanetur.	They should not toil over their oral surgery with eating and drinking, and with biting, until the jaw is healed and restored
Quod si difficilis fiat reductio duarum Mandibuiarum, quando dislocantur in hora aliqua, et non conuertuntur ad loca sua: tunc multotiens accidunt inde febres, et soda assidua: et fortasse soluitur uenter infirmi, et fortasse uomit choleram puram.	If the reduction of both jaws is difficult, when they are displaced at some time and do not return to their place: then many times they cause fever, and bitter soda: and perhaps the patient's condition improves, and perhaps vomiting pure bile.
Cum ergo uides illud: tunc scias, quia est perditio, et multotiens moritur ille cui accidit illud in decem diebus.	When you have done this: then you know that it is lost, and many people die from it within a month
¶ De reducione dislocationis Furculae, et extremitatis humeri.	(The text continues with further instructions regarding the reduction of dislocation of the jaw and the extremity of the humerus.)
Caput XXVI.	Chapter XXVI.
Furcula quidem non dislocatur ex latere intrinseco, propter continuationem suam cum pectore.	The thyroid bone is not displaced from the inside outwards, because of its continuity with the sternum.
Et dislocatur quandoque ad exteriora: et declaratur illud sensui.	It is displaced sometimes towards the outside: and this is declared by sensation
Et restauratio eius est, ut iaceat infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat brachia sua.	Its restoration is that the patient should lie upon his back, and extend his arms.
Deinde coarta locum cum palma tua coartatione forti, nam ipsa redibit.	Then cover the place with the palm of your hand with a strong bandage, for it will itself return
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stringe eam.	Then put upon it a compress, and sponges, and bind it around it.
Extremitates uero eius quae sequuntur cubitum, et continuantur cum eo, non dislocantur, nisi raro.	The extremities of it which follow the elbow, and which continue with it, are not displaced, except rarely
Quod si dislocatur die aliquo: tunc oportet, ut reducatur et aequetur secundum quod diximus, et quod praeparatur tibi.	If it is displaced on some other day: then it is necessary to reduce it and make it equal according to what has been said, and to prepare the patient for it
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam.	Then put upon it a compress, and sponges, and bind it around it
Et praecipe infirmo, adhaerere tranquillitati et quieti, donec sanetur.	And command the patient to adhere to tranquility and quiet, until he is healed
Et cum hac eadem curatione reducitur extremitas Humeri, quando separatur etiam a loco suo.	And when the same cure has been made, the extremity of the humerus is separated even from its place.
¶ De reductione dislocationis Humeri.	¶ On the reduction of the dislocation of the humerus
Caput XXVII.	Chapter XXVII.
Scias, quod Humerus non dislocatur, nisi secundum tres modos.	You know that the humerus is not displaced except in three ways.
Quorum unus est, ut dislocetur ad partem titillici ad inferiora.	One of them is that it is displaced towards the elbow towards the lower parts.
Secundus est, ut dislocetur ad partem pectoris.	Secondly, it is necessary to displace the fragment to the part of the chest.
Et fortasse dislocatur ad superiorem partem Humeri: et illud fit raro.	It is also possible to displace it to the upper part of the arm: and that is done rarely.
Et non dislocatur ad posteriora, propter spatulam.	It does not go to the back because of the spleen
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora, propter neruos.	It does not go to the front because of the nerves
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur et egreditur ad inferiora uersus titillicum: praecipue in illis, quorum carnes sunt paucae.	Most frequently, however, it is displaced downwards towards the nipple: especially in those whose flesh is sparse.
Quoniam egrediur in eis uelociter, et ingreditur uelociter.	For it comes out quickly and goes in quickly.
In illis autem quorum carnes sunt multae, est econtrario illius, scilicet quia egreditur cum difficultate, et ingreditur cum difficultate.	In those, on the other hand, whose flesh is abundant, it is the opposite, for it comes out with difficulty and goes in with difficulty
Et fortasse accidit quibusdam hominibus percussio, aut casus, et apostematur Humerus apostemate calido, et putatur propter illud, quia iam dislocatus est.	And sometimes it happens to some people that they receive a blow or suffer a fall, and the arm is dislocated by the heat, and it is supposed that because of this the arm is dislocated
Oportet ergo, ut experiaris illud, donec stes super certitudinem eius, et tunc procedas in curatione eius.	Therefore it is necessary to experience this until you are certain that it is truly dislocated, and then you can proceed with its treatment.
Et cognoscitur dislocatio, quando est ad inferiora uersus titillicum: et distinguas inter Humerum dislocatum, et humerum sanum.	It is recognized as being dislocated when it is displaced downwards towards the nipple: and you must distinguish between a dislocated arm and a healthy arm.
Nam tu inuenis inter eos diuersitatem manifestam, et inuenis in capite Humeri concauitatem, et sub titillico apud tactum caput humeri quasi ipsum sit ouum: et non potest infirmus reducere manum ad aurem suam, neque mouere eam omnibus motibus.	For you will find among them a clear difference, and you will find in the head of the arm a depression and under the nipple at the touch of the hand almost like two bones joined together: and you will not be able to reduce the arm to its normal position, neither by pulling nor by any movement
Et similiter, si dislocatur uersus pectus, aut ad sursum: tunc inuenis manifestum tactum, neque occultatur.	And in the same way, if it is displaced towards the breast or upwards: then you will find a clear mark, and it will not be hidden
Et huius quidem dislocationis fit facilis reductio, quando est recens, aut infirmus est puer.	And in this case of dislocation, the reduction is easily accomplished when the limb is still firm or when the patient is a child.
Et reductio eius est, ut eleuet minister manum suam ad superiora.	And the reduction is to elevate the limb upwards by the hand of the minister
Deinde pone tu pollices tuos sub titillico eius, et eleua iuncturam cum fortitudine ad sursum ad locum suum: et minister eleuet manum suam, et extendat eam ad sursum.	Then put your thumbs under the joint, and elevate the limb with force upwards to its place: and the minister will elevate the hand and extend it upwards.
Deinde ponat eam inferius, ipse enim redit uelociter.	Then place the lower limb below, and immediately the limb will return to its place.
Si autem non redit per illud quod diximus, et sunt a principio quo accidit dislocatio dies multi: tunc oportet, ut balneetur infirmus in aqua calida, et administretur embrocatio quae mollificat et lenit, sicut si decoquantur radices alteae, et foenugraecum, et mellilotum in aqua, et administretur.	If however it does not return by this, and has been since the dislocation several days: then it is necessary to immerse the patient in warm water, and to apply a bandage which will soften and soothe, like decocting wild herbs, rue and melilot in water, and applying these things
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et ponatur sub titillico eius sphera et lana, quae sit aequalis inter lenitatem et stricturam.	Then the patient is placed on his back: and under the joint is placed a sphere and a bandage, which is equal between softness and tension
Deinde ponat medicus calcaneum suum super spheram, et eleuet caput humeri cum uirtute, et attrahat manum infirmi ad inferiora.	Then the physician places his heel on the sphere, and elevates the arm with force, and pulls the patient's hand downwards.
Et minister alius teneat caput infirmi, ut non moueatur ad inferiora: ipse namque redit statim.	And another minister holds the patient's head, so that it does not move downwards: and immediately it returns to its place
Et si uis, reduc eum secundum modum hunc: et est, ut facias esse praesentem uirum qui sit longior infirmo, et stet a parte lateris, et intromittat humerum suum sub titillico infirmi: et eleuet titillicum eius ad superiora, donec sit infirmus suspensus in aere.	And if necessary, reduce it in this way: make the stronger limb of the patient to be standing on the side, and let it intrude the arm under the patient's joint: and elevate the joint upwards until the patient is suspended in the air
Et minister alius trahat manum infirmi ad inferiora uentris eius.	And another minister pulls the patient's hand downwards into his body.
Si autem infirmus est leuis: tunc oportet, ut suspendatur cum eo aliquid aliud, ut grauet ipsum: nam redit dislocatio statim.	If however the patient is light: then it is necessary to suspend him with something else, in order to lighten him: for the dislocation will immediately return.
Et reducitur etiam secundum modum alium: et est, ut figatur in terra lignum longum, cuius caput sit rotundum figura: sicut manica mortarii: quod non sit grossum, neque subtile.	Also, it is reduced in another way: as when a long stick is placed in the ground, its head being rounded off like a glove of a corpse: neither thick nor thin.
Deinde ponatur sub infirmo postquam ponuntur super caput ligni panni lenes: et infirmus sit stans secundum longitudinem ligni.	Then it is placed under the patient after the stick's head has been covered with soft cloth: and the patient will be resting in accordance with the length of the stick.
Deinde extendatur manus eius ad inferiora a parte altera, et extendatur corpus eius ab altera parte cum fortitudine: nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	Then his hand is extended downwards from the other side, and his body is extended from the other side with force: for the suture returns to its place with speed.
Quod si difficilis sit eius reductio per omnia quae diximus, tunc utere hac cura: et est, ut accipias lignum cuius longitudo sit quantitas duorum brachiorum, et eius latitudo quantitas quatuor digitorum, et grossitudo eius quantitas duorum digitorum: cui sit caput rotundum, ut alleuietur introitus eius in profundum titillici, secundum hanc formam.	If its reduction is difficult by all that we have said, then take care of it thus: take a stick whose length is equal to the distance from the elbow to the wrist, and whose width is equal to the distance from the tip of the thumb to the tip of the little finger, and whose thickness is equal to the distance from the tip of the thumb to the tip of the index finger: and its head shall be rounded off, so as to facilitate its entrance into the depth of the wound, in this fashion
Deinde ligentur super caput rotundum panni lenes, ut non laedat lignum infirmum.	Then the soft cloth is placed over the rounded head of the stick, so that it does not irritate the patient's wound
Deinde ponatur sub titillico infirmi, ut extendatur manus, aut brachium super lignum usque ad inferiora: et ligetur lignum super adiutorium et brachium et extremitatem manus.	Then it is placed under the wound, so that the hand or arm is extended over the stick down to the lower parts: and the stick is bound to the aid and the arm and the extremity of the hand.
Deinde ponatur brachium super gradum scalae per latitudinem, et extendatur manus ad inferiora, et dimittatur reliquum corpus suspensum a parte altera.	Then the arm is placed over the edge of the step for the width of the hand, and the hand is extended downwards, and the rest of the body is suspended from the other side
Iunctura enim ingreditur statim.	The suture will enter immediately.
Cum ergo completur introitus eius secundum quemcunque modum possibile est: tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico spheram aequalis quantitatis ex lana.	When it has been completed as much as possible according to any method: then it is necessary to place under the wound a sphere equal in quantity to the wool.
Deinde pone emplastrum praeparatum ex puluere molendini cum olibano, et albumine oui super humerum totum, sicut reuoluitur desuper.	Then place a prepared plaster made from pounded wool with oil and white of egg over the whole arm, as is usual above
Deinde stringe sub titillico strictura decenti: et reuoluatur ligamentum super emplastrum desuper: et annectatur manus eius ad collum ipsius, et dimittatur, neque moueatur manus eius septem diebus.	Then tighten the string under the nail: and the ligament will be returned over the cartilage above: and its hand will be connected to its column and let go, neither hand moving for seven days.
Et oportet, ut ponatur cibus infirmipaucus, donec confortetur membrum: quoniam est uelocius ad sanationem eius.	It is necessary to put nourishing food in the mouth of the patient until the limb is comfortable: because it is quicker for its healing.
Deinde ponatur amplior post septem dies, aut quinque, et ex ercitetur cum motu.	Then put on a wider dressing after seven days, or five, and it is taken away when there is movement.
Si ergo firmatur et non mollificatur, tunc iam sanatus est.	If it is firm and does not soften, then it is healed.
Si uero iunctura dislocatur multotiens, propter humiditatem quae accidit ei, aut propter caussam aliam: tunc oportet, ut administretur in ea cauterium cum tribus foraminibus, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo de cauterio.	If, however, the suture is torn away many times, because of the humidity which has happened to it, or for another cause: then it is necessary to administer cautery with three holes in it, as is prescribed in the chapter on cautery
Quod si fiat hoc totum, et soluatur ligamentum post septem dies, et non confirmetur iunctura, et reducatur emplastrum et strictura super ipsum aliquotiens, et non firmetur, et cadat, et non possit eleuare ipsum ad superiora: tunc scias, quod nerui eius qui sunt ad caput humeri, iam incisi sunt, aut extensi, aut mollificati: et scias, quod iunctura nunquam figetur in loco suo.	If one does all this, and the ligament is dissolved after seven days, and the suture is not confirmed, and the cartilage and the stricture above it are reduced, and it does not harden, and falls away, and cannot be raised up to the upper part: then you know that the nerves which are at the head of the humerus are either cut, or stretched, or softened: and you know that the suture will never take hold in its place again
Dislocationis autem quae fit uersus pectus et mammillam, aut ad posteriora reductio, fit cum impulsione et extensione cum manibus: donec redeat, et administretur in ea reliqua strictura et cura, donec sanetur.	As for a dislocation which happens at the shoulder and the armpit, or to the back: it is reduced with a push and an extension with the hands: until it returns, and cautery is administered in the remaining stricture and care, until it is healed.
Quod si accidat post sanationem grauitas in membro, et tarditas in motu eius, tunc utatur infirmus balneo multotiens, donec leniatur illa grauitas, et redeat ad naturam eius primam.	If after healing there is greatness in the limb, and slowness in its movement: then the patient is put into a great bath, until the greatness is softened, and it returns to its first nature.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Cubiti.	(The text provided does not include information regarding the curation of a dislocation of the cubit.)
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter XXVIII.
Scias, quod iunctura Cubiti dislocatur cum difficultate, et similiter redit cum difficultate etiam: et ipsa quidem dislocatur ad omnes partes, et praecipue ad anteriorem, aut ad posteriorem.	Know that the dislocation of the cubit is difficult, and returns with difficulty: and it is displaced to all parts, especially towards the front or the back.
Et eius dislocatio non occultatur tibi: quoniam est cadens sub uisu, et sub tactu, secundum quamcunque figuram dislocetur.	Its dislocation is not hidden from you: for it lies under the skin and under the touch, according to whatever form it is displaced
Et quando coniungis cubitum dislocatum cum sano, declaratur tibi illud manifeste.	And when you unite the displaced cubit with the healthy, you must declare that to be visible
Concauatur enim iunctura, et non potest duplicare brachium, neque tangere cum eo humerum suum.	It must be united again, and you must not double the arm, nor touch it with the other arm.
Et oportet, ut properes, et reducas dislocationem statim, antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	And it is necessary that you do this promptly, and reduce the dislocation immediately, before swelling sets in
Nam si accidit ei apostema calidum, difficilis fit eius reductio: et fortasse non sanatur omnino, praecipue quando est ad posteriora.	For if swelling sets in, its reduction becomes difficult: and perhaps it will not be healed at all, especially when it is towards the back
Est enim deterior omnibus speciebus dislocationis, et uehementioris doloris eis: et multotiens descendit cum ea mors.	It is harmful in all kinds of dislocations, and increases pain: and it descends very much with it.
Et restauratio eius quando est ex eis quae possibile est reducere, est, ut extendatur manus eius cum duabus manibus: et brachium eius sit expansum, et manus medici sint supra cubitum et sub eo, et ipse impellat iuncturam cum pollicibus manuum suarum simul, aut cum radice palmae suae, donec redeat ad locum suum.	And the restoration of it when it is possible to reduce it, is that you extend the limb with two hands: and the arm is expanded, and the hands of the physician are above the elbow and under it, and he pushes with the thumbs of both hands simultaneously, or with the root of the palm of his hand, until it returns to its place
Aut uero dislocatio est ad anteriora: tunc redit ita, ut duplicet manum cum manu sua, donec percutiat cum radice palmae suae cubitum qui est dislocatus.	Or else the dislocation is towards the front: then it returns in such a way that you double the hand with the hand of the patient, until it reaches the displaced cubit with the root of the palm of the hand
Quod si non obedit dislocatio ad reductionem, tunc administra extensionem uehementem, fortem ualde: et est, ut extendant brachium duo ministri: et teneant ipsum duo ministri etiam, ut non remoueatur apud extensionem.	Which if it does not yield to reduction, then administer violent extension, with force: and it is that two ministers extend the limb: and they hold it firmly also, so that it does not move during the extension
Deinde reuoluatur brachium ad omnem partem postquam inuoluitur super manum eius pannus duplicatus longus, aut ligamentum latum.	Then the arm is returned to its entirety after it has been folded over the hand, and a broad ligament is doubled in length, or a wide ligament is stretched.
Et quando tangit medicus manu sua iuncturam, inungat ipsam cum oleo: ut sit illud ex eis quae adiuuant in lubricitate iuncturae cum facilitate.	When the doctor grasps the hand with his grasp, let him smear it with oil: that it may be from that which will aid in the lubrication of the joint with ease
Deinde impellat iuncturam impulsione uehementi, donec redeat.	Then the grasp is driven forward with a violent push, until it returns.
Et post reductionem eius oportet, ut ponatur super ipsam emplastrum, in quo sit stipticitas, et exiccatio cum albugine oui: et stringatur strictura decenti.	And after its reduction, it is necessary to place upon it a dressing, in which there is stypticity, and drying with alum: and tighten the constriction slightly.
Et suspendatur brachium a collo infirmi: et dimitte diebus aliquot.	And the arm is suspended from the collar of the infirm person: and omit for a few days.
Deinde soluatur.	Then it is healed
Si ergo firmatur iunctura in loco suo, tunc solue ligamentum ab ea, et dimitte ipsam.	If, however, the joint remains fixed in its place, then solve the ligament from it, and omit it
Et si uides iuncturam non bene stringi, tunc itera emplastrum, et ligamentum, et dimitte ipsam diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	And if you do not bind the joint well, then repeat the dressing, and the ligament, and omit it for a few days, until it is bound
Deinde solue ipsam.	Then it is healed.
Si autem accidit ei grauitas post reductionem iuncturae, et dispositio sit in motu: tunc administra humectationem in balneatione, et fricationem subtilem, et compressionem, donec liniatur, aut pone super iuncturam iliati, id est, natem arietis pinguem.	If, however, there should happen to him greatness after the reduction of the joint, and the position is immobile: then manage moisture in the bath, and slight friction, and compression, until it is aligned, or place over the joint a cushion of wool, that is, fat of sheep.
Deinde ligetur, et dimitte ipsam super eam die et nocte.	Then it is bound, and omit it over night and day
Deinde aufer eam, et intromitte ipsum in balneum.	Then remove the bandage, and introduce it into the bath
Cum ergo sudat, tunc frica iuncturam fricatione temperata.	When it is wet, then gently friction the joint with temperate friction.
Deinde itera super ipsam aleliati uice una, et secunda, et tertia cum introitu balnei, donec leniatur.	And repeat over it again oil once, and twice, and thrice with the introduction of the bath, until it is softened
Et si uis, pone super ipsam stercus uaccinum, humidum, calefactum cum butyro, et stringe super ipsum.	If necessary, place upon the stool a cushion, wet, warmed with butter, and bind over it.
Fac illud aliquotiens.	Do it thus.
Ipsa namque lenitur, et redit ad dispositionem suam.	The swelling itself will soften, and will return to its normal state.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Almahassem.	From the treatment of dislocation of Almahassem
Caput XXIX.	Chapter XXIX
Mahassem manus multotiens dislocatur, id est, iunctura quae est inter brachium et manum.	The limb of Mahassem is much dislocated, that is, the junction between the arm and the hand
Et reductio dislocationis eius est facilis.	And the reduction of its dislocation is easy.
Econtrario reliquarum iuncturarum.	Except for the remaining joints
Verumtamen oportet, ut uelocitas sit in reductione dislocationis eius in hora in qua dislocatur, antequam apostemetur locus: aut accidat in eo apostema calidum.	However, it must be known that speed is in the reduction of its dislocation in the hour in which it is dislocated, before it is set in place: or else it will happen that in setting it will cause stiffness.
Et reductio dislocationis in eo est, ut ponas Mahassem manus infirmae super tabulam, et extendat minister manum eius: et ponat medicus palmam suam super eminentiam iuncturae, et impellat eam, donec redeat.	And the reduction of its dislocation is like this: place the lower limb of Mahassem upon a board, and extend the hand: and the doctor places his palm upon the prominence of the junction and urges it until it returns
Verumtamen oportet, ut consyderetur, si palma iam recessit ad uentrem manus: tunc ponat infirmus dorsum manus suae super tabulam apud extensionem et reductionem: et si dislocatio est procedens ad dorsum manus, tunc sit positio manus eius intrinsece super tabulam, id est, interior pars manus eius super tabulam ponatur, ut cadat manus medici super ipsam eminentiam iuncturae.	It must be known that the hand must not be forced backwards towards the belly: then the infirm person should place the back of his hand upon the board alongside the extension and reduction: and if the dislocation has arisen from the back of the hand, then let the position of the hand be inside the board, that is, let the inner part of the hand be placed upon the board, so that the hand of the doctor may rest upon the prominence of the junction
Si ergo redit statim, bonum est: et si non, tunc stringe eam cum emplastro sedante apostema: et dimitte ipsum, neque iteres illud.	If it returns immediately, that is good: and if not, then bind the limb with a bandage while it is being set: and let it go, do not do it again
Nam si non tolerat, neque potes super reductionem eius, postquam praetereunt ei dies, uerumtamen iunctura remanet secundum tortuositatem suam: et non nocet infirmo aliquid, nisi quod mollificatur manus, et non potest stringere aliquid: tunc scias, quod nerui sunt abscissi, aut attriti.	For if it does not tolerate it, neither can you force further reduction of it after a few days: indeed, the joint will remain bent according to its own crookedness: and it does not harm the infirm person anything, except that it makes the hand stiff, and you must not bind anything: know that it has slipped away, or that there is swelling
Non est ergo ingenium in ea, nisi ut stringatur cum cauterio prope casum eius.	There is no natural opening in it, except that it be bound with a cautery near the case.
Et fortasse non confert illud aliquid.	It may perhaps suffice without that.</start_of_turn>
Cum ergo non redit Almahassem, tunc pone super ipsum emplastrum, quod narrauimus.	When the soul does not return, then place above it a plaster as we have described.</start_of_turn>
Deinde stringatur, et dimittatur quinque diebus: postea soluatur et dimittatur, et exercitetur manus.	It is then bound and left for five days: afterwards it is dissolved and dismissed, and the hand is exercised.</start_of_turn
Si autem priuatur motus eius, et accidat in ea aliquid grauitatis: tunc leni eam cum aqua calefacta, et fricatione aliquotiens, donec leniatur.	If, however, its movement is withheld, and something heavy has happened in it: then soften it with warm water and friction until it is softened.</start_of_turn
¶ De curatione dislocationis Digitorum.	(Continuation of previous sentence)</start_of_turn>
Caput XXX.	Chapter 30.</start_of_turn>
Quando dislocatur ex eis Digitus ad omnem partem, uel ex eis Digitus ad dorsum palmae, aut uentrem eius: tunc extende Digitum, et impelle dislocationem pollicibus tuis, donec redeat.	When the Digit has been displaced from its place towards the whole of the limb, or from the back of the palm of the hand, or from the inside of the limb: then extend the Digit and drive out the displacement with your thumbs, until it returns.</start_of_turn
Deinde sustenta caput Digiti, et suspende ipsum uersus partem ad quam dislocatur, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	Then support the head of the Digit, and suspend it over the part from which it was displaced, and leave it for two days.</start_of_turn
Deinde suspende eum, et extende ipsum, donec aequetur rectus in illo die suo.	Then suspend it, and extend it, until it is straight on that day.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo fuerit nox, liga ipsum secundum narrationem ipsam: et non cesses soluere ipsum in die: et exerce eum cum motu: et liga ipsum in nocte.	When night comes, bind it according to what has been narrated: and do not stop dissolving it until the next day: and exercise it with movement: and bind it at night.</start_of_turn
Fac illud diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	Do this for a few days, until it is bound.</start_of_turn
Et similiter fac cum eo, si dislocatur ad uentrem manus: et liga eum ad partem ipsam, et fac cum eo operationem tuam primam, donec sanetur.	And do the same with the ulnar bone if it is displaced to the inside of the hand: and bind it to the part itself, and do the operation as before, until it heals.</start_of_turn
Et similiter fac cum eo quando dislocatur ad reliquas partes.	Likewise do as with it when it is displaced to the other parts.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Spondilium dorsi.	Likewise do as with it when it is displaced to the other parts.
Caput XXXI.	Likewise do as with it when it is displaced to the other parts.
Quando accidit alicui Spondilium dorsi, aut colli dislocatio completa, aut remouentur Spondiles multae a locis suis: tunc non est in ea curatio, quoniam mors properat infirmo.	When anything of the spine of the back, or the neck, is completely displaced, or when many spinal processes are displaced from their places: in such a case there is no cure for it, because the marrow is softened for the sick person.
Et signum illius est, quod egestio infirmi egreditur absque uoluntate, neque potest tenere eam: et multotiens mollificantur ex eo quaedam membra eius, aut duo crura eius, aut duo brachia ipsius, aut unum eorum: aut remouetur Spondilis una de loco suo.	And the sign of it is that the sickness departs without being willing, and cannot be held back: and many times it softens some limb of it, or two limbs of it, or two arms of it, or one of its bones: or it displaces one of its vertebrae from its place
Multotiens enim remouetur, quod multotiens fit remotio earum ad quatuor partes.	Many times it displaces, because many times it is displaced to four parts
Illa ergo quae remouetur ad posteriora, nominatur Gibbositas.	The one which is displaced to the back is called gibbousness.
Curatio uero eius est, ut consyderes tunc, si Gibbositas accidit a puericia: tunc non est in ea curatio, neque ex ea est sanatio omnino.	The cure for it is, if the gibbousness happened from infancy: then there is no cure for it, and no healing from it at all
In illa autem quae accidit a casu, aut percussione, aut similibus illis, iam dixerunt antiqui modos curationis sermone prolixo.	But in such a case as happens by blow, or by percussion, or in like manner, as the ancients said in a long discourse about the methods of treatment.
Cuius plurimum non redit cum proficuo.	Most of them do not return when the treatment is finished
Ego uero iam abbreuiaui ex illo, cuius parum excusat a multo eius ex propinquitate mea ad intentionem: et expositione mea qua exposui illud, et formaui instrumentum eius diuerso modo ab eo quo ostenderunt illud, et exposuerunt ipsum.	I myself, however, have abbreviated this, because of my proximity to the matter: and I have shown it in a different way from how it was shown by them, and I have made an instrument out of it in a different way from how they made it.
Dico ergo, quod in gibbositate quae accidit ab anteriori parte, non est ingenium, neque sanatio ex ea.	I say, therefore, that in the gibbousness which happens from the front part, there is neither wisdom, nor healing from it
Et similiter in illa quae fit ad duo latera etiam.	Likewise, in whatever is done to the two sides.
Et non curatur ex eis, nisi illa quae accidit in dorso proprie, cum eo quod ego narro: et est, ut extendatur infirmus super faciem suam super podium aequale prope parietem: et expandatur sub eo stramentum humidum, ut non laedatur pectus eius.	It does not matter from which side, except that which happens in its own place, as I have said: and that is, that the patient should be extended over his face towards the platform near the wall; and let the instrument be extended under him, so that it does not irritate his chest.
Deinde ponatur lignum rectum fixum in fouea in terra, in extremitate podii, circiter caput eius: et lignum aliud circiter pedes eius in extremitate altera podii: et minister teneat lignum, et sit non firmatum in fouea.	Then place a fixed stool of wood in the fire in the ground, at the foot of the bed, round about the head of him: and another stool of wood round about the feet at the other foot of the bed: and the minister shall hold the stool, and let it not be fixed in the fire.
Et minister alter teneat alterum.	And the other minister shall hold the other.
Deinde inuolue super caput infirmi, et sub titillicis eius ligamentum lene, firmum: et extende extremitatem ligamenti ad lignum quod est apud caput eius: et liga ipsum in eo.	Then draw over the head of the patient, and under his chin the ligament is to be made firm: and extend the extremity of the ligament to the limb which is at the head of him: and bind it in that place
Deinde stringe ligamentum aliud supra anchas eius, et supra genua ipsius, et apud cauillas eius.	And bind the other ligament above his shoulders, and above his knees of him, and at his buttocks.
Deinde aggrega ligamenta omnia, et liga ea in ligno altero quod est apud pedes eius.	And gather together all the ligaments, and bind them in the other limb which is at his feet.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem ligni ligamentum, et non remoueantur duo ligna ex locis suis in quibus sunt fixa: uerumtamen non sint firmata, sicut diximus.	And let all the ministers extend to the part of the limb of the ligament, and do not move the two limbs from their places where they are fixed: indeed they are not to be fixed, as we have said
Et medicus ponat palmas suas super Spondilem cum fortitudine, donec redeat: aut ponat super eam tabulam.	And the physician puts his palms on the spine with force, until he returns: or puts them on the chest board.
Deinde annectat super tabulam pedes suos, donec redeat.	And then he joins his feet on the board until he returns.
Si autem non redit per hanc curationem, tunc accipe tabulam cuius longitudo sit circiter tria brachia.	If however he does not return by this cure, then take the board whose length is about three arms
Et caua in pariete de quo diximus quod est prope infirmum, locum in quem ingrediatur extremitas tabulae.	And the cavity in the wall from which we said is close to the patient, is the place where the extremity of the board enters.
Deinde pone medium tabulae super Spondilem.	Then place the middle of the board over the spinous process
Et ponat pedes suos medicus super extremitatem alteram.	And let the physician place his feet on the other extremity
Et stringat bene, donec coartetur Spondilis, et redeat ad locum suum.	And tighten well, until the spinous process is firm, and then return to his place.
Deinde si uis, operare cum torno quod inuoluitur cum manu tua: et est, ut figas in terram apud caput infirmi in postremo podii duo ligna, quorum longitudo sit brachii unius: et apud caput eius in postremo podii duo ligna.	And if you wish, work with the ankle which is involved with your hand: and it is that two boards be placed beside the head of the patient at the end of the two feet, of which the length be the forearm of one hand: and beside the head of these two boards at the end of the two feet.
Et sit longitudo quae est inter omne lignum palmus unus: et iam factum est in omni loco foramen, in quo currit tornum: et firmetur lignum omne in terra multum, ne moueatur omnino.	And the length which is between every two boards is the palm of one hand: and it is finished in every place where there is a hole, in which the ankle runs: and the board is fixed firmly in the earth much, that it does not move at all
Et intromittatur lignum rotundum: et est tornum in quo reuoluitur ligamentum in duobus foraminibus duorum lignorum.	And introduce the round bone: and it is the ankle in which the ligament is rotated in two holes of the two boards
Et in extremitate eius est foramen, in quo firmatur lignum, cuius longitudo est palmus cum eo quod reuoluitur: et in duobus lignis aliis est similiter illius.	And at its extremity is a hole in which the bone is fixed, whose length is the palm with that which is rotated: and in two other boards is like that
Deinde stringe ligamenta quae strinxisti in pectore infirmi torno quod est apud caput eius: et ligamenta quae strinxisti in cruribus eius in torno quod est apud pedes eius.	And tighten the ligaments which you bound in the patient's chest around the ankle which is at his head: and the ligaments which you bound in his thighs around the ankle which is at his feet.
Deinde stet apud omne tornum minister, qui torqueat manum suam cum licinio, cum quo reuoluitur tornum: et medicus aequet Spondilem, secundum quod diximus.	And stay at every ankle minister, who will twist his hand with a loop, with which the ankle is rotated: and the physician will equal the spinous process, as we said before
Haec est forma torni, quae sequitur.	This is the form of the ankle which follows.
Deinde postquam redit Spondilis, et aequatur locus, tunc oportet, ut ponas emplastrum exiccatiuum cum albumine oui.	Then, once Spondilis has returned and the place is equal, it is necessary to place a plaster of dried exsiccata with albumin.
Deinde stuppam.	Then, plaster.
Postea pone supra emplastrum astellam ex tabula, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, aut circiter eos.	Then place above the plaster a bandage of tabula, whose width is three fingers, or thereabouts.
Et longitudo eius quantitas quae capiat locum Gibbositatis, et super partem Spondilis sanae.	And its length as much as covers the part of Gibbositatis, and over the healthy part of Spondilis
Deinde ligetur cum ligamento quod diximus.	Then it is bound with the ligament which we mentioned
Et utatur infirmus nutrimento subtili, donec sanetur.	And the patient is kept nourished with a mild diet until he is healed
Quod si remaneat quiddam eminentiae in loco in fine sanationis: tunc oportet, ut administrentur medicinae quae mollificant, et leniunt, cum administratione tabulae quam narrauimus tempore longo.	And if anything remains prominent in the place at the end of healing: then it is necessary to administer medicines which soften and soothe, along with the administration of tabula as mentioned for a long time
Et iam administratur in illo lamina plumbi.	And they are administered in that lamina plumbi.
Et quandoque accidit eminentia in postremo Spondilium dorsi: et putatur per eam dislocatio, et est illud os quod iam eminet.	And sometimes it happens that prominence appears behind the last part of the spine: and it is thought to be dislocation, and that is the bone which is now prominent
Quare non oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei cum hac medicina: fortasse enim accidere faciet mortem.	Therefore it is not proper to make a presumption of it with this medicine: perhaps because of that it may cause death
¶ De curatione Anchae dislocatae.	Of the treatment of dislocated Anchae.
Caput XXXII.	Chapter XXXII.
Scias, quod iuncturae Anchae, et iuncturae humeri, non accidit, nisi dislocatio tantum: neque accidit eis quod accidit reliquis iuncturis ex remotione parua, et concauitate.	You know that the dislocations of the Anchae and of the humerus do not happen except in dislocation: neither does it happen except in the case of a slight displacement and a concavity.
Et iunctura quidem Anchae dislocatur secundum quatuor partes.	And the dislocation of the Anchae is divided into four parts.
Quod est, quia dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	That is, because it is dislocated towards the front and towards the back
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur ad interiora: et parum dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	Most often it is displaced inwards: little displacement is to the front, and little to the rear.
Et curatio dislocationis eius ad interiora, est: quia quando tu coniungis crus infirmi sanum cum infirmo, est longius: et est genu eius eminens plus quam sani, et non potest infirmus duplicare pedem suum apud inguen: et est locus qui sequitur inguen apostematus apostemate calido, propterea, quod caput coxae iam peruenit illic.	The treatment of such displacement inwards is: for when you join the limb of the sick with that of the sound, the latter is longer: and the knee of the sick limb is more prominent than that of the sound limb, and the sick limb cannot double its foot at the ankle: and the place which follows the ankle after displacement is the knee of the hip, because the head of the hip is then carried there.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad exteriora est, quod sunt accidentia eius contraria istis accidentibus.	The sign of its displacement outwards is that its accidents are contrary to those of its displacement inwards.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad anteriora, est, quia expandit crus sanum secundum complementum: uerumtamen non duplicat ipsum absque dolore qui est in genu: et si conatur ad ambulandum, non potest super illud ad anteriora: et retinetur urina eius, et apostematur inguen eius, et apud ambulationem est calcatio eius super calcaneum.	The sign of its displacement forwards is that it expands the sound limb alongside its complement: truly it does not double itself without pain in the knee: and if it attempts to walk, it cannot do so forwards: and it retains its urine, and its ankle is displaced, and at walking there is swelling of its heel
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad posteriora est, ut non expandat genu, neque possit duplicare ipsum antequam duplicet inguen: et est crus eius etiam breuius altero: et inguen est mollificatum, et est caput coxae apud locum ilii.	The sign of its displacement backwards is that it does not expand the knee, neither can it double itself before it doubles the ankle: and its limb is even shorter than the other: and the ankle is softened, and the head of the hip is at the place of the hip bone
Reductio uero huius dislocationis specierum est, ut consyderes tunc, si dislocatio est uetusta, quae iam antiquatur cum habente ipsam.	The reduction of this displacement of various kinds is that it must be reduced immediately, if the displacement is old, which has become accustomed to its being there
Deinde si tu administres reductionem eius, et remanet secundum dispositionem suam: tunc non est in ea curatio omnino.	Then if you administer the reduction and it remains according to its position: then there is no healing in that treatment at all.
Non ergo oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei penitus.	It does not suffice that a presumption should be made of it.
In illo autem cuius dislocatio est recens, et est ex una specierum quatuor dislocationis: tunc propera ad hoc, ut uoluas iuncturam, et extendas ipsam ad interiora et ad exteriora, et moueas eam dextra et sinistra: fortasse enim redit, et non indiget alia cura.	In that case in which the displacement is recent, and is of one of the four kinds of displacement: then it is proper for this purpose that you wish to join, and extend it inwards and outwards, and move it to the right and left: perhaps thereby it will return, and no other treatment will be necessary.
Si autem non redit hoc modo, tunc oportet, ut praepares ministrum fortem, et extendat crus eius ab inferiori parte: aut cum manibus suis, aut cum ligamento, quod ligetur super crus eius supra genu: et minister alius extendat manum eius desuper, ita ut intromittat manus suas sub titillicis eius.	If it does not return in this way, then it is necessary that you prepare the strong minister and extend his leg from the lower part: either with his hands or with a ligament which is bound above his knee: and another minister extends his hand above, so that he may insert his hand under his buttocks.
Deinde stringat cum ligamento leni super radicem coxae, et teneat extremitatem ligamenti alterius.	Then bind it with a soft ligament above the root of the hip, and keep the extremity of the other ligament fixed.</start_of_turn>
Et sit extensio eius aut ab anteriori parte inguinis ad partem furculae, aut a posteriori ad partem dorsi.	And let the extension be either from the front of the groin to the part of the shoulder blade, or from the back to the part of the loin.</start_of_turn>
Et sit extensio eorum omnium uice una, donec eleuetur infirmus cum corpore suo a terra, et remaneat pendens.	And let the extension be all at once, until the patient raises himself with his body from the earth, and remains hanging.</start_of_turn>
Et haec enim species extensionis est species communis specierum quatuor.	And this is indeed a common kind of extension among the four kinds.</start_of_turn>
Si ergo redit dislocatio cum eo quod diximus, est bonum: et si non, tunc necesse est omni speciei illud quod dicam de curatione propria.	If, therefore, the dislocation returns as we have said, it is good: and if not, then it is necessary in every case to perform that which we have mentioned concerning proper treatment.</start_of_turn>
In reductione quidem eius propria quando dislocatio est ad interiora, oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super latus suum sanum.	In reducing it, however, when the dislocation has gone inwards, it is necessary that the patient be placed upon his sound side.</start_of_turn>
Deinde ponat ligamentum super radicem coxae, in eo quod est inter caput coxae, et locum qui est sub inguine.	Then bind the ligament upon the root of the hip, in that place which is between the head of the hip and the groin.</start_of_turn
Deinde extende ligamentum ad sursum a parte inguinis ad altiorem partem corporis, ad partem furculae.	Then extend the ligament upwards from the groin to the higher part of the body, to the part of the shoulder blade.</start_of_turn
Deinde accipiat minister alius fortis brachia eius, et minuat locum grossum coxae infirmae, et extendat ad exteriora extensione uehementi.	And then another strong minister grasps his arm and moves the lower part of the hip downwards, and extends it outwards.</start_of_turn
Iam enim redit ad locum suum.	And thus it returns to its place.</start_of_turn
Et haec species est facilioris reliquis speciebus curationis, qua reducitur hoc membrum.	This kind is easier than the others for treating this limb.
Si autem excusatur super te, et non obedit tibi ad introitum cum hac specie curationis omnino: tunc oportet, ut ligentur duo pedes infirmi simul cum ligamento forti, leni, super duos calcaneos, et super duo genua: et sit longitudo cuiusque a compare suo quantitatis quatuor digitorum: et sit crus infirmum extensum plus altero quantitate duorum digitorum.	If, however, it is excused beyond thy power, and does not obey thee at the entrance with this kind of treatment: then it is necessary to bind together both feet of the sick person along with strong ligament, soft and strong, over two calcanei and over two knees: and let the length of each be equal to four fingers; and let the limb which is sick be extended more than the other by the quantity of two fingers.
Deinde suspendatur infirmus super caput ligni, quod sit in domo: et sit longitudo eius a terra quantitas duorum brachiorum.	Then suspend the limb above the head of the limb: and let its length from the earth be equal to the quantity of two arms
Deinde praecipe iuueni forti, ut muniat caput coxae: et suspendatur cum infirmo inuenis alius: et impellat iuuenis alius, muniens coxam cum fortitudine, nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	Then command a strong youth to hold fast the hip: and suspend it with the sick limb together: and let the youth push the other limb forward with force, so that the joint returns to its place with speed.
In reditione autem eius propria, quando est dislocatio ad exteriora, oportet, ut iaceat infirmus super podium, secundum quod narrauimus in habente gibbositatem.	But in its return itself, when there is dislocation outwards, it is necessary that the limb should lie upon a cushion, as we have said in the case of a gibbosity
Et stringatur ligamentum super crus eius, infirmum proprie, et super pectus eius.	And bind the ligament over the limb itself, and over the hip.
Deinde ponantur duo ligna, unum apud pedes eius, et alterum apud caput ipsius.	And put two boards, one at the feet and the other at the head of the limb.
Deinde ponatur lignum additum in medio podii, fixum bene: super quod inuoluti sint panni humidi, ut non laedat infirmum: et sit lignum inter coxas eius, ut non attrahatur ad inferiora apud extensionem.	And put a board added in the middle of the foot, fixed well: over which are placed wet cloths, so that it does not irritate the limb: and let the board be between the knees, so that it does not draw towards the lower parts on extension.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem suam, et medicus aequet reductionem manu sua.	Then extend all the limbs to their proper parts, and the physician will equal the reduction by his hand.
Si ergo obedit ad reuersionem, erit bonum.	If therefore it obeys the reduction, it will be good.
Et si non, pone super ipsam tabulam, et preme ipsam, sicut diximus in gibbositate, aequaliter.	And if not, place over the limb itself a board, and press on it, as we said in the case of a gibbosity, equally
Verumtamen oportet, ut iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	The patient must lie upon his healthy side.
Et quando dislocatio est ad anteriora, tunc oportet, ut extendatur crus infirmi uelociter: et est secundum hanc eandem narrationem super podium: et ponat medicus palmam manus suae dextrae super inguen infirmum.	When the dislocation is forward, then it is necessary to extend the limb quickly: and it is in accordance with this that the doctor places his right hand over the patient's knee
Deinde coartet ipsum cum manu altera, et cum illa coartatione pone ipsum extensum ad inferiora ad partem genu.	Then he grasps the limb with his other hand, and when he has bound it in this way, he extends the limb downwards to the knee part
Et si dislocatio est ad posteriora: tunc non oportet, ut extendatur infirmus ad inferiora, et sit eleuatus super terram: imo oportet, ut sit positus super rem duram, sicut oportet, ut fit etiam si dislocatur ancha eius ad exteriora, secundum illud quod diximus de accubitu eius super duas anchas: et est super faciem eius, et ligamenta extensa: secundum quod diximus nuper.	If the dislocation is backwards: then it is not necessary to extend the limb downwards, but rather to elevate it above the ground: indeed it is necessary to place it upon a firm object, as it is also done when the dislocation is wide outwards, as we have said concerning its recumbent position upon two cushions: and this is upon its face and with extended ligaments: as we said a little while ago.
Et oportet, ut administretur compressio cum tabula etiam super locum ad quem egreditur iunctura, cum completur reductio secundum quod oportet.	It is necessary to apply a compress with a board also upon the place where the fracture has occurred, when the reduction is completed as it should be done.
Et signum reditionis eius non occultatur tibi: et est, ut extendas duo crura infirmi: et quando uides ea aequalia, et infirmus stringit crus suum, et expandit ipsum absque excusatione: tunc scias, quia iam redit membrum, secundum quod oportet: tunc coniunge duas coxas, et pone emplastrum, et stringe cum imemati, id est, rota: ita, ut non moueatur ancha ad aliquam partium: et adhaereat infirmus quieti tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	And the sign of its reduction is not hidden: and it is that you extend both legs of the patient: and when you remove these equal, and the patient tightens his limb and expands it without pain: then you know that the limb is returned, as it should be done: then you must join the two thighs together, and put on an bandage, and bind as before, that is, with a rotation: so that it does not move widely to any part: and the patient must rest quietly for three days, or four.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et emplastrum, et compara crus cum altero: tunc si uides ea aequalia in statu, tunc scias, quod dislocatio iam firmata est: absolue ergo infirmum ad ambulandum.	Then loosen the ligament and the bandage, and compare the limb with the other: then if you find them equal in position, then you know that the dislocation is fixed: absolutely so that the patient can walk again.
Et si uides aliquid mollificationis: tunc redi, et emplastra illud, et stringe illud secundum stricturam tuam primam: et dimitte illud etiam tribus diebus.	And if you find any softening: then rest, put on the bandage once more, and bind it as before: and leave it for three days.
Deinde solue illud et fac ipsum tardare in ambulatione super utrumque aliquot diebus, donec confortetur bene.	Then heal it and make it walk slowly over the next few days until it is comfortable.
¶ De dislocationis Genu.	Then heal it and make it walk slowly over the next few days until it is comfortable.
Caput XXXIII.	Then heal it and make it walk slowly over the next few days until it is comfortable.
Genu dislocatur secundum tres modos.	Then heal it and make it walk slowly over the next few days until it is comfortable.
Dislocatur ad exteriora, ad interiora, et ad inferiora, scilicet ad posteriora.	Then heal it and make it walk slowly over the next few days until it is comfortable
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora.	Then heal it and make it walk slowly over the next few days until it is comfortable
Et signum dislocationis eius, est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut applicet crus suum ad coxam suam.	Then heal it and make it walk slowly over the next few days until it is comfortable
Si autem non adhaeret cum coxa: tunc scias, quod Genu est dislocatum.	Then heal it and make it walk slowly over the next few days until it is comfortable
Et restauratio omnium modorum dislocationis eius est, ut facias sedere infirmum rectum, ita ut iam extendat crus suum si potest super illud, et adhaeret dorsum tuum ad faciem eius: et pone pedem eius inter pedes tuos.	Then heal it and make it walk slowly over the next few days until it is comfortable
Deinde adhaerere fac Genu eius cum palmis tuis, et recta eas inter digitos tuos super Genu eius.	Then heal it and make it walk slowly over the next few days until it is comfortable
Deinde applica cum palma tua duo latera Genu eius cum fortitudine.	Then heal it and make it walk slowly over the next few days until it is comfortable
Et minister alius extendat pedem eius, donec redeat Genu ad locum suum.	Then heal it and make it walk slowly over the next few days until it is comfortable
Et signum reditionis est, ut adhaereat crus cum coxa in lenitate, non laboriose.	Then heal it and make it walk slowly over the next few days until it is comfortable
Deinde emplastra ipsum, et adhaerere fac crus cum coxa.	Then heal it and make it walk slowly over the next few days until it is comfortable
Deinde liga ea simul cum uitta tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	Then heal it and make it walk slowly over the next few days until it is comfortable
Deinde solue ea.	Then heal it and make it walk slowly over the next few days until it is comfortable.
Et non utatur infirmus ambulatione aliquot diebus, donec sanetur.	Neither does the sickly man walk for some days until he is healed.
Si autem recusatur tibi reductio eius, tunc administra extensionem fortem cum ligamentis, quorum praecessit narratio in curatione anchae, donec redeat.	If, however, the limb remains immobile, you must perform reduction of the limb with ligaments, as has been mentioned previously in the treatment of fractures, until it returns
¶ De curatione dislocationis Calcanei.	Until it returns
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter XXXIV.
Calcaneus quandoque remouetur remotione parua, et quandoque dislocatur secundum complementum.	The calcaneus is sometimes remoulded with a slight displacement, and sometimes dislocates completely
Et dislocatio eius fit, aut ad interiora, aut ad exteriora.	It is displaced either inwards or outwards
Et signum dislocationis eius est, quod uides Calcaneum inflatum, procedentem ad partem ad quam dislocatur.	Its sign is that the calcaneus is swollen, proceeding to the part where it is displaced
Curatio autem remotionis eius, est facilis reditionis: et est, ut extendatur cum facilitate cum manibus, et aequetur, donec redeat.	The treatment of its displacement is easy: to restore it, extend it gently with the hands, and stabilize it until it returns to its place
In curatione autem eius quando dislocatur secundum complementum, oportet, ut facias sedere infirmum rectum: et teneat ipsum minister fortis ualde a posteriori parte dorsi eius, in medio ipsius.	When it is completely displaced, it is necessary to sit the patient upright: and hold the limb firmly from behind its ankle, in the middle of the limb itself
Deinde tene tu cum manu tua dextra pedem eius a superiori parte eius, et cum manu tua sinistra ab inferiori parte pedis eius loco cauillae.	Then hold your right hand from above the foot, and your left hand from below the foot at the ankle bone
Deinde trahe pedem ad tecum manu tua dextra.	Then pull the foot towards you with your right hand
Deinde cum sinistra duabus uicibus.	And with your left hand support the ankle bone with two fingers.
Deinde extende cum sinistra, et impelle pectus pedis cum dextra uersus crus absque labore.	Then extend with your left hand, and push the ankle bone downwards without straining.
Fac illud bis, sicut narrauimus.	Do this twice as we have mentioned
Deinde impelle pectus pedis ad crus in uice tertia, et tu trahis cauillam.	Then push the ankle bone towards the shin in the third space, and you pull the heel.
Si ergo redit in uice una, aut in duabus secundum hunc modum, et uides pedem aequatum, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera operationem super ipsum: quoniam ipse redit.	If therefore it returns to its place either in one space or in two, according to this method, and if the foot is equal, it is good: but if not, do the operation again over it: because it will return
